PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Abbott, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this bill is to give effect to the transfer of responsibility for the University of Canberra from the Commonwealth to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and to amend the Maritime College Act 1978.

The transfer of the University of Canberra from Commonwealth to ACT jurisdiction was first proposed by the University of Canberra. The university considers that its future is bound up with the growth and development of the ACT, since the university is a key provider of professional education and advice in education and research. The transfer will bring the university closer to ACT activities such as infrastructure and land development, health education and the ACT school system.

The Commonwealth and the ACT governments agree that there will be considerable benefits to the university and the Canberra community in the university being more closely identified with the city. The university's comprehensive undergraduate teaching programs and expanding presence in graduate education, research and international education services are of great importance to the continued economic and cultural life of the city. There are strong mutual benefits to be obtained from facilitating collaboration between the university and territory government agencies, businesses and community organisations.

BREAK.PARA: In order to facilitate the transfer, this bill:
‐ amends the University of Canberra Act 1989 (the act) where appropriate and necessary prior to the conversion so that the act will reflect the change of jurisdiction;
‐ amends the Australian Capital Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1988 to make the act an ACT enactment;
‐ provides consequential amendments to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973; and
‐ provides certain transitional arrangements in relation to preservation of the rights and accrued entitlements of University officers and staff.

The Commonwealth government is transferring the act with its existing framework intact. Any changes to it are appropriately made by the ACT Legislative Assembly after the transfer is made. However, any employee rights of coverage under Commonwealth occupational health and safety, industrial or administrative law for incidents occurring prior to the transfer day will continue. Coverage for incidents occurring after the transfer day will be determined according to the law of the territory.

This bill also amends the Maritime College Act 1978 to provide the council of the Australian Maritime College with the power to make statutes for or in relation to the regulation or control of traffic or parking. Currently, parking spaces at the Australian Maritime College are being used by others to the detriment of the college staff and students. The act is amended to allow the college to enforce car parking regulations. I commend the bill to the House and I present a signed copy of the explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Laurie Ferguson) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Somlyay, Alex, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the following report— Report 351—Advisory report on the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 .

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Charter of Budget Honesty Bill had its genesis in a recommendation from a previous report of the Joint Public Accounts Committee in the previous parliament. That report was tabled in November 1995. I believe that the government had adequate opportunity, if it wanted to, to adopt the recommendations of that report. It did not so do. It was left to this government upon election to adopt the principle of the charter of budget honesty. In adopting that principle, it then embodied the principle in the legislation of this bill. In the budget speech on 20 August 1996, the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: Before its election defeat on 2 March, the previous Government maintained that the budget would now be in underlying balance. The truth was nearly $10 billion to the contrary.

The reason why this charter of budget honesty is being introduced and given effect is so that no other government will ever be placed in that position again. As I said in my speech on this bill in this House, I did not believe that this bill ought to be referred to the JCPA; but the Senate in its wisdom so did and we reported.

As honourable members are aware, the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill was referred to the JCPA on 3 March for tabling today. As a consequence of this tight deadline, the committee held only one public hearing, taking evidence from the stakeholders in the public sector and from peak representative groups in the private sector. Those groups which were unable to attend managed to make submissions within our tight timetable.

The committee supports the framework in the bill as it implements mechanisms for improving the accountability and transparency of government fiscal policy objectives, strategies and outcomes. The JCPA believes that the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill is another element in the improvement of the overall fiscal accountability framework. Transparency is the essence of such a framework, and this bill legislates for the provision of regular published reports so that the public may be better informed.

Mr Speaker, it should be noted that there is no opposition to this bill as such in the House. The opposition has been supportive of the need for such a charter as was indicated during the second reading debate in this House. Although for 13 years they did not adopt one, they support the adoption by this government. It is very simple to support these measures in opposition, but it is another thing to have the intestinal fortitude to introduce them and to give them effect when in government.

During its review of the bill, the committee encountered widespread general support and very little criticism. However, there are several important aspects which I wish to draw to the parliament's attention.

Schedule 1, clauses 12(3), 16(3), 19(2) and 24(3): while the committee applauds the requirement for fiscal reports to be prepared in accordance with recognised external reporting standards, the committee believes firmly that the reasons for any deviations from those standards should be fully explained in the reports.

Schedule 1, clauses 12(4), 16(5) and 24(5): although the committee recognises the need to suppress information of a confidential commercial or national security nature, it believes that a statement providing a general description of the information being suppressed and its aggregate amount should be included in the reports.

Schedule 1, clauses 13, 17, 28 and 32: the committee is pleased that the fiscal reports being legislated by this bill provide an approximation of whole‐of‐government reporting. However, the above named clauses enable Commonwealth agencies to withhold information. Where this occurs, then a statement showing the effect of this omission and its aggregate amount should be included in the reports.

Schedule 1, clause 22: the committee notes that a pre‐election economic and fiscal outlook report is to be released within 10 days of the issue of the writ for a general election. Given that a writ can be delayed up to 10 days after the dissolution of parliament, the committee believes that it would be more sensible to have the pre‐election reports released within 10 days of the dissolution of parliament.

My final point, Mr Speaker, is to seek the agreement of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to include a review component in the schedule of the bill so that the full reporting process can be assessed after the next election. I am confident that our report reflects the concerns of the parliament. The JCPA looks forward to receiving the government's response to report 351.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am glad to be here today as Deputy Chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for the presentation of report 351, An Advisory Report on the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 . I concur with most of what the chair of the committee, the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), has said with regard to this legislation and this report. It certainly has the support of the opposition. I might say that in some of the discussions we had at the committee there was not always that high level of agreement. However, I think the report we have come down with is quite a modest but important contribution to the consideration of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of issues around this legislation which were mentioned by the chair, and some others that were not, need to be looked at with respect to its operation. I will briefly mention some of those in the short time that I have.

Certainly it is true that the comments regarding the bill that came before the committee either from witnesses or, in some respects, in submissions were generally positive. I think generally there was strong support out there. However, there is certainly a question as to just how this bill will actually work, and certainly some concerns were expressed at the hearings regarding the detail of that in practice.

The consultation process around this particular piece of legislation and the consideration of it by the committee was quite short. In the circumstances we only had submissions open for, I think, a matter of days because of the very tight time line placed on the committee by the motion through the Senate. As I understand the position of the government, they need this legislation through during this session. I think that has limited the capacity of many individuals and groups to go through the detail of how the operation of the bill will occur and what the circumstances will be of the actual utilisation of this legislation in the future.

Having said that, certainly there is an expectation publicly that this legislation is not only a good thing but that it will lead to a material change. I am not so sure about the material change aspect. As the chair mentioned, this is a bill more suited for opposition than for government, but certainly in my position I hope for significant change. But I remain to be convinced.

A number of issues were raised regarding this bill, and a number of them were covered by the chair of the committee, but I would like to pick up on a couple of comments. This legislation is largely a codification of existing practice. There are some improvements, and I commend those improvements, but it is largely a codification of existing practice. I think the circumstances were summed up best, from my point of view, by Professor Marc Robinson who made a submission to the inquiry. He said:
No legislation can compel fiscal responsibility . . . The most positive view of the Bill is that it is merely the latest in a long series of incremental improvements in fiscal reporting requirements.

What it does is largely build on what the previous government had done over some 13 years. It makes some improvements but, with respect to some of those improvements such as intergenerational reporting and the pre‐election statements, we will have to see how they work in operation versus the question of what the expectations are.

Another issue which came up during the inquiry is the question of forecasts made by Treasury particularly but also in general terms regarding the private sector. The thing about the forecasting of economic indicators and projections is that it is crucial in terms of the political debate, not only in terms of budgetary implications with respect to actual judg ments being made and produced by government and by departments as being where we are really going on a financial basis, but also in terms of the expectations of what will occur in the future. A comment was made by the Secretary of Treasury on this issue, which I quote:
. . . it is in the nature of forecasts that they will always be wrong and we have to do our best to minimise those errors.

Obviously that statement is self-evident, but I do not think it is a statement which is really understood in the broader situation of the media and the public. Quite often, things do go off the rails but it is not on the basis of some form of chicanery, as is suggested on occasions by some. It is more in terms of the fact that the detail that is there is not sufficient and the circumstances change.

TALK.START.PARA: —No more black holes.
—We have just had a recent black hole from the current Treasurer (Mr Costello)—which maybe gives an example of that, I do not know.

SPEECH.PARA: Another issue I would raise briefly is the question of the signing off by the secretaries to the Treasury or Finance with respect to economic and fiscal reports produced by the government. The proposal under this bill is for that to be done with the pre‐election report. That is fine, but members of the opposition raised the issue—and I believe it to be true—that other reports such as the budget ought to be done in the same way. It ought to be done on a regular basis.

If this bill is about honesty, then let us have that honesty out in the open. Let it not only be honest but be seen to be honest by having reports like that signed off. I will leave my comments there. I commend the report to the House and I wish the bill a speedy passage in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I will be very brief. The first point I want to get on the record is that I do not believe it was necessary for the Senate to refer the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill back to the JCPA, and certainly we were given limited time to have a look at some of the elements of it. So on that basis and on behalf of all members of the committee and the chair, I would like to thank the witnesses who appeared at short notice on the one day of public hearings we held. I suppose to a certain extent that was constructive.

SPEECH.PARA: As I commented yesterday when tabling the report on the Auditor-General's reports, the Department of Finance people reiterated that the process of introducing accrual accounting is very slow. This is not going to speed it up, but it is one area that is going to be very necessary in this process.

The one comment the committee has made in this extra review of the bill is that we believe a review component should be included in the bill so the full reporting process can be assessed after the next election to see whether the highlighted benefits that the bill will provide will actually accrue to the public. We believe they will.

I think the bill is an important step forward for the public management of Australia by government and as far as the transparency and accountability of the operations of government are concerned, particularly with the pre-election reports. It means the people of Australia will be able to understand clearly and know the economic situation of the country prior to elections. I commend the bill to the House and, along with the member for Bruce (Mr Griffin), trust it has a speedy passage through the Senate from here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been an agreement to bring the AIDC Sale Bill on at this time because we in the opposition have been pushing for a provision to be made to allow for grievances and 90-second statements today. There was a reluctance on the part of the government to embrace that and I know it is not listed on the Notice Paper today, but the understanding is that, between now and 2 o'clock, we will be aiming to complete the AIDC Sale Bill and allow 90 or so minutes for grievances and 90-second statements.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention that not only to reflect the agreement and our intent but to indicate that at some stage the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) or a representative may need to move a motion to enable us to get into grievances and 90-second statements. We on this side respect the importance of those debates for backbenchers, and they should not be crowded out by government business.

But turning to this bill. The bill was introduced into the parliament on 27 February. It makes legislative amendments to enable the sale of the Australian Industry Development Corporation—the AIDC as it is known. It was established in 1970 as an investment bank to finance Australian industry. Its role when established was essentially to fill a gap that was not then adequately covered by the banking sector and other financial lenders. It essentially was established to cover cases where the development would not otherwise take place or would have only been possible in circumstances, unless local finance was available, that involved ownership and control going to foreign investors.

Over the years the AIDC has pioneered infrastructure financing, and it has a unique capability of turning public policy into reality through reacting as a policy lever for national development. It developed widely recognised project, resource and infrastructure financing expertise.

Some of the many significant examples and developments which occurred with AIDC financing include the Woodside North West Shelf gas project, which involved $US1.6 billion of financing, and the Argyle Diamond project, where the AIDC was the only Australian financier. There would have been no Australian equity in it but for the AIDC.

I also mention the Eraring Power Station project, which was financed through AIDC, and the nucleus telectronics pacemaker, which AIDC underwrote the initial financing of. In addition to all of those very worthwhile and significant infrastructure investments, the AIDC has contributed some $130 million in dividend payments to the Commonwealth since 1983.

BREAK.PARA: The AIDC did undergo some substantial losses several years ago. As a consequence, it restructured its operations and it has subsequently recovered well, with annual after tax earnings forecast to be around $60 million this year.

We recognise it was the coalition election policy to privatise the AIDC. They confirmed this in last year's budget. It is against that background that, overall, Labor will not be opposing the bill. However, we do have some concerns about the legislation and the way the sale is to be conducted. Many of these concerns are reflected in our second reading amendment as well as the amendment we will move in the detail of the bill.

Overall, the AIDC has performed well. It did make a loss in 1991, but most banks reported major losses in that period. But it did not, through its difficult period, need to draw on the government guarantee. The loss occurred largely because in the mid‐ to late‐1980s the AIDC had moved away from its core business of infrastructure and resources. We, as a Labor Party, believe there is still a need for activity in this area.

It moved away from those core businesses—infrastructure and resources—towards a far greater emphasis on fee based merchant banking and business. Following its restructure, it did make pre‐tax profits of $175 million over the last four years. As I have already indicated, it expects to make a pre-tax profit of some $60 million this year.

The AIDC currently employs some 200 people. The Labor Party does not want to see overly generous golden handshakes—or, in the case of some, golden handcuffs—going to AIDC senior management. But, apart from that group, we are concerned that the ordinary workers in the organisation are not disadvantaged by the sale. I note that concerns were expressed about this during the Senate committee hearings earlier this week. Labor is pleased that assurances have now been given that the existing terms and conditions of employment for these workers will be maintained.

The AIDC is one of two Australian controlled and independent investment houses. There is a real chance that, through this sale, it could be purchased by overseas interests, particularly as there are no special provisions in the bill to deal with foreign ownership. Labor notes the assurances of the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) in the Senate earlier this week that, if the buyer is overseas owned, AIDC's 48½ per cent holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation could be excluded from the sale. We welcome that assurance but believe we need to legislate to ensure that assurance. That is the purpose of the amendment that we will be moving when we consider the detail of this bill.

We will be essentially moving at that stage that the Australian Submarine Corporation component be removed from AIDC Ltd and located within the corporation which is to stay in place under this legislative arrangement to manage the borrowings and loan portfolio and to manage such national interest assets as the Commonwealth's Australian Submarine Corporation shareholding. Essentially, the AIDC will remain in existence. It needs to manage certain activities. We are saying that this is where the Australian Submarine Corporation shareholding should be parked to ensure the guarantee, the assurance, that was given by Senator Kemp in another place. It will also ensure that the ASC does not become foreign controlled.

AIDC has also been a significant investor in Australian infrastructure development. I mentioned some very significant examples a little earlier. Approximately half of its activity in the infrastructure development field has been in regional Australia. The sale of AIDC, without a genuine effort to replace it, will be seen as part of the government's continued assault on regional Australia.

There are many reasons why regional Australia feels, rightly, that they have been betrayed by this government. The first act of the Howard government in relation to regional development was to cut $150 million in regional infrastructure projects, despite the fact that they promised during the election campaign that they would not do it.

When the announcement was made by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp)—he still calls himself the regional development minister but, as his first act, abolished his own department—the statement justifying this breach of election promise was that `there is no clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development'.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you this: this comes from a National Party member in this House, a person who is touted as a future leader of the National Party, but if the National Party does not stand for regional development what does it stand for? Yet he has come into the House and justified the abolition of $150 million of the regional infrastructure fund saying that there is no constitutional role for the Commonwealth in regional development.

Labor believes there is a Commonwealth role in regional development. We believe that there is a role for all governments in regional development. We are sick to death of this buck‐passing between levels of government when the issues become too hard for the government.

The simple fact of the matter is that what is good for regional Australia is good for the nation. It therefore requires, if we are to support regional Australia, all levels of government to get behind that work. Instead, what do we see from the present government and from the minister for so-called regional development? They are washing their hands as a government of involvement in regional development.

But it got worse. The first budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Costello), on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), confirmed the approach of a massive betrayal of regional Australia. Those who rely on regional roads and infrastructure are the big losers. Higher education funding has been slashed, with the cuts falling disproportionately on the regional campuses. Assistance to the unemployed has been cut by over $1 billion, again falling heavily on regional Australia. ABC funding has been cut. There has been a massive attack on regional welfare and service delivery, with cuts in areas such as dental services. We are seeing closures of regional CES, Tax and Medicare offices.

There is no doubt that there is an enormous sense of bewilderment and betrayal wide spread among regional Australians resulting from the cuts throughout regional Australia—a part of the nation that voted overwhelmingly for this government and expected better of it. But it has been dudded. It has been betrayed.

As to the cuts to regional infrastructure alone, first we saw in July last year this $150 million regional infrastructure fund totally abolished. I have mentioned the pretext used—there is no role for the Commonwealth in regional development, which are the words of the minister. Second, there was the axing of the infrastructure bond program with only the vague promise of a replacement program to be brought forward in the budget.

Labor indicated at the time that we would support any measure to remove unintended consequences from tax concessions. However, what we are saying is that the failure to announce a replacement program has put at risk billions of dollars of regional development.

Just understand the lethargy and lack of ideas resulting from this government. This issue of infrastructure bonds has been around now for over 12 months in this government's term of office. They indicated that they wanted to stop excessive use and excessive claims under the scheme. But what was the decision of the government after 12 months? It was to freeze the fund, to not allow any projects to go forward. After 12 months, having frozen 72 regional infrastructure projects, all around the country, the best that they could say is, `We'll freeze them—not that we have an alternative, not that we have really thought through a policy change; the best we can come up with after 12 months of looking at this issue is to freeze the funds, to stop further regional development occurring in this nation.'

So we have the scrapping of the $150 million infrastructure fund. We have the freeze now on infrastructure bonds with no alternative having been put in place. There are 72 projects sitting out there all waiting for approval—all necessary to regional development and all prepared to be financed by a combination of the private sector and government authorities. But, no, this government will not allow them to go ahead. No wonder regional Australia feels you have betrayed them.

It is not as if these are pie in the sky projects. These are essential projects to the regions of this country—road funding, infrastructure such as gas pipelines, and water supply. Yet we have a double whammy from this government: not only have they scrapped the fund that assist in getting some of these projects going but also they have scrapped the infrastructure bond program and have put nothing in place. On top of all of that, they are now coming along with the sale of the AIDC, again without any alternative being put in place.

The sale has been announced. But there is no hint of the government's plans to do anything to address the future need for private sector investment in our national infrastructure, except perhaps the institutional investor information service, which was announced with some understated fanfare by the Minister for Regional Development. He said it was a world first, but all he did was copy the original scheme of Brian Howe, who announced it back in 1995.

The only statement made in this chamber by the minister for so-called regional development after more than a year of activity and which gives any sort of hope is something that copies Labor's plan. They have broken promises all over the place. They have told regional Australia that they would support the infrastructure funds. They have told them that they would back them in regional infrastructure. All they have done is cut the very programs that give that support, and the best they can do is copy a scheme from Labor.

We thank you for copying Labor's scheme, but why do you not copy more of them? Why do you not reinstitute the regional development fund? Why do you not put a replacement up for the infrastructure bonds that enable these projects to go ahead? And why do you not put in place a replacement body for the AIDC to support the financing of infrastructure in important parts of this country?

The AIDC, it must be said, was involved in some significant infrastructure bond projects. For example, the Wyuna water project, with two water treatment plants in New South Wales, was funded and backed by the AIDC. Yet it is now frozen because of the government's decision on infrastructure bonds. There is also the Oakey power station in Queensland—a 270 megawatt gas‐fired power station, essential if you are about supplying energy source to regions to enable them to value add. This, too, was frozen out by Treasurer Costello's announcement on the infrastructure bonds. The Redbank power project in the Hunter Valley—a $300 million project which uses coal tailings as fuel—is frozen. I know that the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) has serious concerns about this particular project being put on ice.

What do we have from the Treasurer on this? We have an assertion that he has frozen the scheme because it was being rorted. None of these projects was a rort. I challenge the Treasurer to come into this House and identify where the rorts have been occurring. This was the same excuse he used when he wound up the syndication of research and development in this country. This is the classic dupe that Treasury and Finance always put forward. Wherever a worthwhile project overruns as to revenue forgone implications, Treasury says, `Minister, we have a submission for you. There is an overrun. Call it a rort.' Any time there is a project that is worthwhile and should be persisted with but Treasury does not like it, they get the minister all wound up and say, `Call it a rort.'

That is what the Treasurer has done in terms of R&D syndication. He has also said it in terms of infrastructure bonds, but he has not had the decency to come into this chamber on any occasion and identify and spell out those rorts.

I remember a debate that we were having in this House towards the end of last year on the scrapping of the research and development syndication. He had to sit in the same chair as the duty minister at the table is sitting in for some six hours of debate, squirming away—signing Christmas cards, as I remember, to try to avoid attention—because we gave him the opportunity, time and time again, to get up and list the rorts. He would not do it. He cringed because he knew, if he tried to do it, that he could be guilty of misleading the House. I challenge him again to come in and tell us where the rorts are in terms of the infrastructure bonds. In particular, I ask him why those three projects that I have just outlined cannot go ahead—the Wyuna water project, the Oakey power station in Queensland and the Redbank power project in the Hunter Valley. Let him explain why his mismanagement, his blinkered approach, is preventing these important aspects of regional infrastructure from proceeding to fruition.

We believe that government does have a role in renewing our regional infrastructure. We believe it does have a role in working with industry to build exports, smart research and jobs. There is still a need for the type of service that the AIDC was originally designed to provide. Although the details have changed to some extent, the need is still there, particularly because investors have a reluctance to put money into regional Australia. The AIDC moved away from that role. Unfortunately, its focus became directed to fee based merchant banking, which could just as easily be met by the private sector.

If you look at the Financial Review today on page 32, we have the AIDC entering vendor finance. The simple fact of the matter is that we do not need a body to enter fees and interest charges. We do not need another body to get into vendor financing, but we do need a body that supports regional infrastructure, a body that is prepared to back these significant projects where they matter to the development of our regions, getting value‐added up, making sure we do not rely on commodities as our sole basis for exports, supporting the huge surge in manufacturing which we have seen over the last decade. These things only happen because governments are prepared to play a role. We think that there is still a role for a body to be established to perform what was originally intended and commenced by the AIDC.

The fact of the matter is that there is a gap in patient investment capital in this country, both in relation to infrastructure investment and in meeting the needs of small high technology, export focused firms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that?

—I see the member for North Sydney does not think there is a role. You go and tell small businesses who come to you and say, `The banks won't lend me money. The banks are only interested in taking the full equity in the operation. The banks won't support us.'
—What will you do?

—I will tell you what we will do. We will back their interests and we will support them with structures which make sure they get that funding. The fact is, you talk big but you will not act. You get these representations from small business, yet you do nothing for them. So why don't you get real! Why don't you actually do something on behalf of your constituents and back our call for the government to establish an effective body which supports small business in this country? We know that, in the cosy climes of North Sydney, you would not know much about regional Australia. But I say to you, get out there and have a look at the place. Go and see some of these projects and see what has been begging.

BREAK.PARA: He incites me, Mr Deputy Speaker. I apologise, I will return to directing my comments through you.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House might return to a little bit of order.

—The reality is, the government is doing nothing to fill this gap because it does not believe that it has a role in this area. Worse, it is cutting away all of the existing support mechanisms—the R&D tax concessions, the bounties, the DIFF scheme, the export market development grants scheme, Austrade, AusIndustry—with a total of $3.9 billion cut out of the last budget. This year the axe looks set to fall further on the motor vehicle industry. We could see its demise if the government adopts the majority recommendations of the Productivity Commission. Textiles, clothing and footwear, pharmaceuticals, information technology and, once again, the research and development concession are all under, not a microscope, but this huge laser beam that the Treasurer wants to zap into industry because he does not believe there is any role for government. It is about time some on the back bench understood the destruction that the Treasurer is creating in terms of our manufacturing base in this country. It is about time they backed manufacturing industry in this country.

BREAK.PARA: The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr John Moore, from the safety of Hanover yesterday—he is not even in the parliament defending this, he is in Hanover, no doubt checking the stock exchanges to see what little bit of trading can be done on the side—said:
I'm not anticipating further cuts to government business programs because when you have a balance of payments problem the role of exports is vital.

I hope he is right, but it does sound a little bit like pre‐empting the budget process. We will find out when he returns to this parliament whether he has been successful in that regard. I hope he is more successful than in his discussion the other night at Canberra's most exclusive club with the Treasurer. There they were at the Commonwealth Club, finished dinner, and over port and cigars the Treasurer of the country and the industry minister were discussing the future of the car industry. The Treasurer said, `Minister, my vision for the car industry in this country is to wipe out Mitsubishi.' That was his plan, his secret vision for the car industry, to wipe out one of the manufacturers. This is the person who is running your government and it is about time people on the back bench stood up to him.

Labor recognises that, to some extent, the AIDC has moved from its original charter and that the need for patient capital and private sector investment in major infrastructure projects, while just as significant, does now need to be addressed in different ways. The AIDC itself has confirmed that there is no function that it now performs which cannot be carried out equally as well by the private sector. But there still remains a significant gap in the market. The AIDC is no longer specifically focused towards filling that gap.

Labor sought examination of the issue through the Senate legislation committee—and that took place on Monday. It was a process which yielded some useful informa tion, including the fact that the legislation had been drafted without reference to the AIDC board. This is a great government of consultation. It said, `We are going to wipe you out, board members, but we will not tell you about it. We will keep it secret. We will drop it on you in the parliament. You can read about it in the newspapers.' It was only through the hearings that we had in the Senate that the board was able to flag three problems that they had with the legislation.

Unless Labor had actually gone to the accountability exercise over there we would not have known about this. This government would not have sought to ask them about this. These difficulties should have been sorted out well before the legislation was tabled. It does reflect this undue haste, which the government seems to continually get itself into in introducing legislation, and its inability to manage the processes of government. Labor has a second reading amendment with regard to this legislation. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, and recognising that there were difficulties associated with the way the AIDC had moved from its original charter, this House:
(1) reaffirms its commitment to the principles underpinning the AIDC's creation;

(2) condemns the government for not putting a structure in place which addresses the failure of Australia's capital markets to provide sufficient long‐term, patient funds for industry development; and
(3) calls on the government to establish an effective means of supporting patient capital investment and to determine remedial strategies appropriate to today's environment".

I indicate to the House that, in addition to that second reading amendment, in the consideration in detail stage we will seek to move an amendment to require that the Submarine Corporation shares be parked in the AIDC to ensure that if the Submarine Corporation and the activities that spin-off from it, that have seen enormous leverage given to the defence systems and heavy engineering capacity of this country, and the critical mass that it established—that would not have been backed by Australian financiers but for the AIDC— are to be kept, they are kept properly through the corporation structure and ensure that it does not come under foreign control. I will seek the opportunity at a later stage to address the detail of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—It is my great pleasure to second the amendment and I reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On a more tempered and focused note I would like to initially reflect on the original goals of the AIDC and where the AIDC is at now. A little later I will speak about the management and board of the AIDC, which the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) raised in his speech in this second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, AIDC Ltd is now an investment house that provides infrastructure, resources and corporate advice and financing in Australia and Asia. It is a specialist in equity investment and funds management and financial markets and securitisation. The AIDC Sale Bill, which was introduced by the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), puts in place the commitment of the coalition government in the March 1996 election campaign to privatise AIDC Ltd.

The Australian Industry Development Corporation was set up in 1970 as a statutory corporation. Its mission was to facilitate and encourage the establishment, development and advancement of Australian industries. It is fair to say that the AIDC has had some great successes—for example, the North West Shelf gas project financing for Woodside Petroleum Ltd; the project financing for the massive Eraring power station in New South Wales; and, an issue that is very dear to the heart and mind of the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), the establishment of a consortium of institutional investors in Optus Communications.

AIDC's business activities have expanded to fee based merchant banking activities. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, AIDC experienced some substantial losses. In 1988, the AIDC went through a colourful period, including a recognised capital shortage by the Commonwealth government which led to the creation of AIDC Ltd and the Australian Stock Exchange listing of 19 per cent of AIDC Ltd in 1989. Of course the Commonwealth retained 81 per cent of the listed entity.

For some years, and particularly during the Labor years obviously, the government talked of selling off the remaining interest in AIDC Ltd. As a result, there was great uncertainty regarding the future of the company. It is fair to say that this does have a damaging impact on the morale of staff and management and also of the board and that that may have contributed to some of the less than profitable years towards the end of the 1980s and the early 1990s.

I am prepared to recognise that, particularly when in the 1992-93 budget the Labor government announced its intention to sell down, to 51 per cent, the government's share in AIDC Ltd. It was in August 1992 that the government recognised that this was going to prove very difficult and withdrew the sale. In 1993-94, we saw the Labor government do a backflip yet again on another issue when it said that it was going to pursue the sale. But then in April 1994 the Labor Party said that it may change its mind in relation to the sale process.

In 1995, the former Labor government announced that they were going to go into the market and buy back from private investors the remaining 19 per cent of AIDC Ltd, the minority shareholding. They suggested that this was going to take place so they could properly prepare AIDC Ltd for a full sale at a later date. The takeover offer closed in January 1996 and AIDC was delisted one month before the election last year.

The federal government wants to sell AIDC because it is a good idea. It experienced losses in the late 1980s and early 1990s. It had a profit turnaround in 1993 and significant before tax profits in each of the years since. In 1995-96, AIDC Ltd had a record $50.3 million profit, which I will talk about a little later. It is, however, not in the public interest to retain public ownership of a merchant banking operation. There are, of course, many other investment banking operations in the Australian financial marketplace, but the government should not be involved in an operating business on a commercial basis in a competitive environment, especially where that competitive environment is related to the issuance of capital and the use of capital for profit purposes. This is entirely consistent with the recommendations of the National Commission of Audit.

Further, it is fair to say that Australia enjoys very sophisticated financial markets and there is no public benefit for the Commonwealth in continuing to have an extensive involvement in the financial marketplace. For example, AIDC can enter into swaps agreements, foreign exchange agreements, forward rate agreements, option agreements, futures agreements and hedge agreements, all of which start to become complicated financial instruments once you start getting involved in derivatives of each of those and exotic agreements. These businesses have no place in the public sector other than to hedge the overall risk of the Commonwealth.

The government is pursuing the competitive neutrality principle. There is an existing funding advantage for the Commonwealth, and the AIDC has enjoyed access to the Commonwealth's AAA domestic guarantee, which means that it should be an even more profitable enterprise than it is at the moment. I understand that the AIDC does not pay any guarantee fees to the Commonwealth for the benefit of enjoying the AAA status domestically and AA status on S&P rating in international markets. The termination of access to the government guarantee facility will place the AIDC business where it belongs—on exactly the same footing as the rest of the financial services industry.

There is an issue that has been brought to my attention over the last few weeks as I have been researching the sale process for AIDC Ltd. It is a matter of grave concern not just to this parliament but to all Australians, who in fact have a stake in the future of AIDC Ltd. It comes down to the fact that the AIDC management has taken a regressive approach to the sale process. AIDC management has served only its own interest during the sale process and there is a good reason for that, which I would like to elaborate on.

As of the figures of 31 December 1996, a contingent liability for employee termination is in the accounts amounting to around $32 million. This $32 million—most of which benefits around 50 of the total of 200 employees, which would be a rule of thumb application—would suggest that management has set for itself amongst the most lucrative employment contracts in the financial services industry in Australia. The company has net assets of around $246 million. So up to 15 per cent of the net asset figure would have to be allocated to the termination of employees and, particularly, senior management. That is an extraordinary figure. But it goes further.

According to the 1996 annual report, the executive remuneration in AIDC Ltd has reached preposterous levels. As I referred to a little earlier, profits have improved. In 1994, the profit for AIDC Ltd was $47.3 million. In 1995, the profit was $25 million. In 1995, with a profit of $25 million, there were more than 10 executives in AIDC Ltd receiving over $700,000. More than 10 executives were receiving over $700,000 per annum in an organisation that has a total of 200 employees. That is an extraordinary figure.

It is even more extraordinary, if you take the levels a little bit further, that 16 people received more than $250,000, and that was on a profit figure of $25 million. On a 1996 profit figure of $50.3 million, 18 executives received more than $250,000. Some would say—and it is fair, and I agree with it—that it is only appropriate that executives should receive benefits on the basis of the profit projections. But my concern is the fact that the 1995-96 so-called profit is primarily made up of a write back of asset values and loans. So, essentially, what the management has done, or is seen to have done, is revalue everything upwards to create a profit result in 1995-96 of $50.3 million, which seems to be almost a 100 per cent improvement on the previous year.

I would not deny—nor would anyone, or very few, in this House—the right of senior management or talented people on the staff to have very generous salary packages based on the level of profit in the organisation. It is only appropriate in the financial services sector and particularly in the markets, where there are extraordinary pressures on individuals and there is extraordinary risk associated with decisions made less than every minute of every hour of every day. There are only too many examples where imprudent financial management has caused grave harm to organisations such as Barings, more recently Natwest in the United Kingdom, and a few other organisations. I think it was Nomura that was the unfortunate recipient of a billion dollar mistake.

But when salary levels are pitched at such a high point and the underlying profit of an organisation does not indicate that they should be, then what they are doing is ripping off the shareholder. And that is exactly what the AIDC management have done. They have ripped off the shareholder by taking such excessive salaries and putting in place extraordinary termination agreements.

In 1996, $25.9 million was the total salary package for AIDC Ltd—this puts it in perspective—and yet their termination agreements and the contingent liability in the accounts is $32 million, which would indicate that every employee in AIDC Ltd is guaranteed more than an entire year's salary for termination.

You and I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the hardworking personal assistant or hardworking secretary or the young employee who is running to and from the market or doing the courier service or working in the photocopy room is not going to get a year's salary. So what does that mean about the senior executives' termination payments?

And even now we need to ask the question: what is the motivation of the management and the board in impeding the smooth process to due diligence during the sale process? I will tell you what it is. It is an underlying arrogance. Professor Jeremy Davis was quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 18 March as saying:
The real core of AIDC's business lies in the relationship with our 80 to 100 clients. The exercise of this right to information could be damaging to the company.
The report goes on to say:
Professor Davis said AIDC was not looking for a veto but a limit to the due diligence process for buyers.

Professor Davis is showing an extraordinary arrogance and a lack of understanding of the most basic sale principles for any financial institution. Professor Davis seems to have forgotten some of the lessons of the past. The State Bank of Victoria was never sold to the Commonwealth Bank—they never went through any due diligence process. The State Bank of South Australia was never sold to Advance Bank—they never went through any due diligence process. Bankwest was never sold to the Bank of Scotland—they never went through any due diligence process. The Commonwealth Bank was never sold to the markets—they never went through any due diligence process.

And it goes on. State Bank was never sold to Colonial—there was no due diligence process. Metway was never sold into the Bank of Queensland and the Queensland government—there was no due diligence process. And it goes on and on and on. And the Chairman of AIDC Ltd has the absolute hide to come into this parliament and tell the Senate committee that the due diligence process might unveil confidential information about customers. He either does not understand the most basic processes of due diligence or he is guilty of the most heinous crime of obstructing the obvious will of the shareholders—the people of Australia.

If Professor Davis is not going to comply with the demands of this parliament and the demands of the shareholder, then he should resign and take his entire board with him. Because what he is doing is saying to us that AIDC should be absolutely separate from the normal processes of sale, including the due diligence process, which will reveal the true value of the asset.

As I have indicated, AIDC's profit result last year was not that good. They have chosen to revalue a few assets and inflated the profit figure but the underlying profit is disappointing—given that it has a AAA guarantee, which only three banks in the world have; only three banks in the entire world have an international AAA guarantee. And AIDC's domestic AAA and international AA give them significant benefits; yet on assets of $256 million last year their profit was $50.3 million with some revaluations tied in.

On behalf of the people in my electorate and on behalf of the people in this House, I urge AIDC management to make a contribution to the sale process. The only message I am hearing—and I am standing on the sidelines—is that AIDC management are impeding at every point the smooth sale process. You know why? Because they have set up for themselves the most cosy executive remuneration contracts anywhere in the markets. They like their cosy little arrangement—their AAA guarantee, their wonderful termination payments, their wonderful remuneration payments. They do not even have to rely on substantial underlying profits to deliver them good remuneration. It is greedy and it is grubby! The sooner AIDC is sold into the market, the sooner it will be accustomed to real market pressures, the sooner the executives of AIDC will realise that the gravy train cannot continue, especially at the expense of the people of Australia.

I call on the management of AIDC Ltd to lift their game. I warn them that not only am I am watching them, not only are the bidders carefully watching them, not only are the government and this House watching them but the market is watching them—and we are watching them very closely. If they are going to have that sort of attitude in this process, they are going to find it very hard to survive either the sale process or any process after that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean). Let me say a couple things about the contribution from the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey). It is all very well for the honourable member to draw these very serious concerns, which we agree with, about the operations of the AIDC and its management, but what does the AIDC Sale Bill 1997 provide to deal with your concerns? It does not provide very much at all. We have moved our amendment not just in relation to these concerns but in relation to a number of concerns that we have on the opposition side. We have a number of concerns about what is going on and about the way in which the government has dealt with this issue. Although we will not decline to give the bill a second reading, we will be moving amendments in the consideration in detail stage.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe the second reading amendment focuses on some very important issues. The first issue has to do with philosophy, with the reasons why the AIDC is being sold. The honourable member for North Sydney presented many of the reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he's left the chamber.

—He has left the chamber, but he presented some good reasons. Basically, the AIDC has moved away from the purposes and philosophy for which it was created. But the danger here is that we will throw out the baby with the bathwater. The danger is—and this is certainly the view of the government according to the second reading speech—that the government does not see any role for an organisation such as the AIDC.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a problem with an organisation. It is not performing the function for which it was originally created, so what do we say? `Okay, that's the reason to get rid of the organisation.' On top of that, we then say, `There is no reason for any organisation to perform that function.' We do not agree with that philosophically, politically and in terms of the economic development of this nation because the fundamental issue facing this nation at the moment is employment and unemployment. In order to effectively deal with that issue, we have to deal with the question of industry development. Industry policy is the crucial issue facing this House. It is a shame that it is so poorly addressed at the moment, with the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) not having a clue, not having any ideas and not having any suggestions.

On top of that, we have seen from this government a tax on programs designed to support and sustain industry. It is in this context that we have to understand this debate about the AIDC and the amendment moved by the opposition. We are saying in our amendment that we reaffirm a commitment to the principles underpinning the AIDC's creation. It might be reflective to talk about that for a moment. A document from the Parliamentary Library refers to the purposes for which the AIDC was formed. It states:

The AIDC was established in 1970 . . . the initiative of the Rt Hon. J. McEwen, then Minister for Trade and Industry, who saw the need to counter Australia's growing dependence on foreign capital to support its enterprises and industries. The AIDC is an investment bank which finances Australian industries and which also participates in enterprises and projects. McEwen was not opposed to foreign investment per se and, in fact, he acknowledged the importance of the availability of such capital in Australia. The AIDC was created to assist Australian residents match the share of capital required to create or maintain enterprises so as to avoid too often becoming the minor partner in an enterprise which was the target of foreign investment or takeover. At that time, the Australian motor industry was nearly 90% foreign controlled. The industrial and heavy chemicals industry, and the pharmaceuticals industries were over 80% foreign controlled. Overseas ownership of the electrical and electronic industries was around 50%.

The AIDC was created to fill a gap not then adequately covered by the banking and other financial lenders. The AIDC was there to assist in cases where the development would not otherwise take place, or would not be possible in circumstances where, unless local finance was available, ownership and control would go to foreign investors.

A piece of history, Mr Deputy Speaker. We believe those general underlying principles of the AIDC are still relevant. But the government, in getting rid of the AIDC, is not putting in place any structure which addresses the failure of Australia's capital markets to provide sufficient long-term patient funds for industry development. It does not address that.

This is a critical issue for us as a nation, as a people. We have to develop more broadly and, as the shadow minister said, develop our industries throughout the regions of Australia, otherwise our future as a nation is going to be glum. We must do more in industry development but, without an organisation or a structure that takes up this task, it is going to be very difficult. So we condemn the government for not doing enough, not thinking enough and not putting into place sufficient policies to help develop a structure of this kind that can assist in the injection of capital. There is no doubt that the government does not see any such need because according to the second reading speech:

Since its establishment as a company AIDC has been changing the direction of the business activity of the company. While still focusing on the development or advancement of the infrastructure and resource sectors of the economy, it is pursuing to a far greater extent fee-based merchant banking business. This government is firmly of the view that such activities have no place continuing in the public sector.

That is the explanation that we get in the second reading speech when we try to understand what the government is on about in terms of this concern with the financing industry. It is interesting to look at what the philosophical basis of this concern is. The second reading speech also says:

The government's decision to sell the AIDC Limited is consistent with the recommendations of the National Commission of Audit which considered that government business activities whose objectives are to provide goods and services on a commercial basis should only be retained in public ownership if there is a clear public interest case to do so. With the emergence and development of financial markets in Australia any public interest case to retain the AIDC in public ownership has disappeared.

First of all, I suppose that means they think that the provision of capital is a good or service. That is interesting. Whoever wrote this perhaps should go back and look at their economics texts. It seems to them that the provision of capital is a good or service.

They do not understand the fact that the banking sector does not sufficiently lend in regional areas, in risk areas, in new areas and in innovative areas. Yet in this country we have the problem that we have a large number of skilled people, a very highly skilled work force, but we do not have enough industry for them to be employed in. Is it because we do not have the general idea of what to do? Couldn't we in Australia produce whitegoods? Couldn't we in Australia produce electronic products? Couldn't we in Australia produce more telecommunications? Couldn't we in Australia have more processing of minerals? Couldn't we in Australia have more processing of food? Couldn't we in Australia have a whole range of other industries? Of course we could. Why don't we have a structure or a body which can actually help at least in the initial stages?

This is a matter that is going to have to be taken up at some point or another. I can tell you that we on this side of the House are determined to push this issue about industry development over and over again. If the government is not prepared to put into place a minister who is going to listen and who is going to be at least interested in the issues, if the government is not going to be prepared to actually start thinking in innovative ways about how we can proactively get our industries going, then we are going to be in a lot of strife. But we are going to make this an issue at the next election.

The honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), who is at the table, knows what I am talking about because we were recently in a parliamentary delegation that visited the Republic of Ireland. It was very instructive to see what can be done because in the Republic of Ireland they have converted from an agriculturally based economy 20 years ago—20 years ago only—into an economy based on high technology industries. And not only that; they have actually been able to develop those industries in the regions.

How have they done that? Do you think they have done it by allowing everything to enter the free market without government intervention? On the contrary. As the honourable member for Ballarat knows, we were all stunned to see the number of concessions and the number of active policies that were put into place by a government owned organisation designed to achieve manufacturing, high technology industries regionally based in Ireland.

I am not saying that all of these industries would be possible in Australia. By the way, we thought some of these were against the World Trade Organisation until we discovered how much you can actually do in the investment area. For example, some companies investing in manufacturing in Ireland have a reduced corporate tax rate to 10 per cent up to the year 2010. They are able to have a reduced tax for investment. There is a whole range of other initiatives—tax-free repatriation of profits in certain circumstances, tax exempt government securities, capital allowances and expenditure on scientific research—all sorts of measures put into place to ensure that you get the kind of investment that is required in industry.

There is another serious aspect to this issue, and we have had quite a few serious aspects raised so far. We also had the serious questions raised by the honourable member for North Sydney. I look forward to seeing what the minister intends to put into place to deal with the issues he raised.

There are also the matters raised by the honourable member for Hotham—the problem we face as a nation with so many regions spread out geographically, so many different places that need small and medium sized industries, industries where our people can work. Are you saying in the context of that that we do not need some kind of organisation? We certainly don't need the currently operating AIDC with all of its problems. But we need an organisation that is going to achieve those results.

Unless we hear some answers from the government, we are going to be not only insisting on our amendment, but we are going to be keeping them on their toes over and over and saying, `What are you going to do about a structure to provide capital for industry?'

The other amendments that we are foreshadowing for after the second reading debate stage have to do with the Australian Submarine Corporation. What is the government going to do about the Australian Submarine Corporation? This is a very serious question.

As the shadow minister for industry, the member for Hotham, has said, the opposition asked a few questions about this in the Senate committee hearings. It is instructive to read the text of key questions raised by Senator Robert Ray:

Senator ROBERT RAY —Minister, you would realise that the Australian Submarine Corporation was designed to always have an Australian majority ownership. I think Kockums own about 48.5 per cent approximately and AIDC and the other by a small Australian shareholder. Will this open the possibility—
that is the sale of the AIDC—
of the Australian Submarine Corporation being owned in the majority overseas?
Senator Kemp —That is not the government's intention, Senator Ray.

Senator ROBERT RAY —It is not the government's intention but is there a possibility of that if AIDC is purchased in part by foreign owners and you do not actually transfer their holding of the Australian Submarine outside it?
Senator Kemp —No. The advice I have is that that is not the government's intention and, clearly, if there was a potential problem in the area the submarine would be pulled out of the sale.
Senator ROBERT RAY —Have you identified an area that you would transfer the asset to?
An official answers:

Mr Hutchinson —The proposition is that the asset initially be held by the Australian Industry Development Corporation—the statutory authority—which would need to continue in operation for some time to manage the borrowings that are still in place and that run for some considerable period. So, in the first case, the corporation would hold the shares but it is possible to vest them elsewhere in the Commonwealth.
Senator ROBERT RAY —Would you have any idea where else you could invest those shares?

Mr Hutchinson —They could be vested in the Commonwealth directly so that the Department of Defence could hold them, or any other government agency so nominated by the administrative arrangements orders could hold them, or they could be vested in another Commonwealth entity, another Commonwealth GBE, if that was thought appropriate.

Senator ROBERT RAY —There would be a great deal of awkwardness if it went to the Department of Defence because then it would be part owner and client, similar to the problems they have with Australian Defence Industries. You would have to put up all sorts of Chinese walls. Where else in the government, apart from Defence, do you think you could vest them to avoid those problems?
Mr Hutchinson —If they were merely a financial asset they could be vested with the Department of Finance or the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism if that was appropriate.
This is the key point:

BREAK.PARA: The ministers have given no consideration beyond the possibility that they could be held in corporation for some time.

The ministers have given no consideration. The top official admits there is a problem and a very serious issue. The government says, `No, we don't want to get rid of Australian ownership of the Australian Submarine Corporation. We are going to sell the AIDC, but we haven't given any consideration about what we are going to do about the issue.'

What sort of a government is this? Here is a very key defence industry, the Australian Submarine Corporation. They say they don't want to put it out of Australian ownership and yet they have not done anything in terms of putting into place a plan to deal with it. Our amendments will deal with this issue directly. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are speaking on the bill that allows the Australian Industry Development Corporation Ltd to be sold off. We have had the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) on the government side intervene in this debate. I would just like to extend a general apology that there are no other government members speaking on the debate and, particularly, no National Party members.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it extraordinary that no National Party member is sufficiently motivated by the current pressing issues of this bill or the history of the bill, because the AIDC was established when Black Jack McEwen was Minister for Trade and Industry. I would have thought they would have wanted some pride of ownership on this and to make some comments about it.

It is interesting that, when it was set up back in 1970, it was proposed as a mechanism for countering Australia's dependence on foreign capital to support its enterprises and its industry. That was a very worthwhile thing in 1970 and I make the point that it has remained as relevant in the 1980s and 1990s as it was in the 1970s. From our perspective on this side of the House, we are unapologetic about wanting to say that we support processes and mechanisms that allow Australian industry to grow and not to be owned by or dependent on foreign capital.

BREAK.PARA: It is ironic that we are supporting a measure to effectively privatise something owned by the Commonwealth. But, like a number of organisations, this institution, regrettably, has long departed from the original vision and aims that were had for it. That is a matter of regret, but it is the reality. So, in selling off AIDC, we are not selling something that is countering Australia's growing dependence on foreign capital to support enterprise and industry. This is not an organisation that is supporting technological breakthroughs any more.

One of the things the AIDC can rightly claim some credit for is the fact that it funded the Nucleus Techtronics pacemaker. We need an Australian institution that is prepared to fund breakthroughs—the pacemaker, the cochlear ear implant or whatever the next generation of exciting products developed by our scientists and researchers may be. We do not have that institution. It is a great tragedy that, in a country so relatively small in size, we are and always have been capable of doing good research and providing breakthroughs but we have not been good at product development and getting things onto the market. In particular, all too often we have not been good at keeping things in Australian hands. People are getting more and more upset about this, as they understand that when these things go overseas or are bought out by foreigners, the jobs and the benefits go with them in the majority of cases. We have done all the hard yards to have that research breakthrough but another foreign company in another country will get all the benefits of it.

So, when AIDC was funding projects like the pacemaker, it was a very important institution to us on this side of the House, but critically important to innovative Australian industry. They have had some other very important investments—and I want to talk about one in particular in some detail—but they have long since gone away from that role. If you read today's Financial Review, it talks about the AIDC entering vendor finance and wanting to get into deep partnership, but that will not be for the things that John McEwen had in mind—that is, countering foreign investment. It will not be pumping a lot of money into these companies or doing something that a lot of other companies are doing already. So that is why I am speaking—with regret—in support of the bill, in principle.
It is important to read the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean). That says:
That whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, and recognising that there were difficulties associated with the way the AIDC had moved from its original charter, this House:
(1) reaffirms its commitment to the principles underpinning the AIDC's
creation;
(2) condemns the Government for not putting a structure in place which addresses the failure of Australia's capital markets to provide sufficient long‐term, patient funds for industry development;—
I say amen to that—
and
(3) calls on the Government to establish an effective means of supporting patient capital investment and to determine remedial strategies appropriate to today's environment.

That amendment sums it all up. We hope that on the government side they will exhibit a concern for and interest in Australian industry, funding the development and the product stage of research and development—although they have cut back research and development—assisting innovative Australian companies to grow, to develop and to export.

We cannot say, `The banks will look after it: we have banks and they do those things.' They have an appalling record. They are the most impatient providers of capital. In the farming sector, it has been an absolute tragedy to see customers who have had relationships of 20 to 30 years—or even generations—with one bank, only to see that bank squeeze them out of their property and inheritance. They have done that to the farming sector and to industry as well. I regret both events. We cannot look to the banks—they are failing us—and so we need to look to other institutions. I sincerely hope that the government will consider these issues seriously, because, after all, they are concerned with Australian jobs.

I particularly wanted to talk about the Australian Submarine Corporation. I suppose that in the heat of political debate lots may be said about a member of parliament. But when Kim Beazley was Minister for Defence he had an outstanding record of achievement, which I think no-one really disputes. I wanted to talk about what he did on the industry side. There were decisions made on things like transforming the docks down in Victoria and getting Transfield up and running and giving them the frigate project.

In relation to the Submarine Corporation a huge decision was made that, `No, we just won't sign up to an American submarine, a British submarine, a German submarine, or whatever. We want self‐reliance in Australia and we are going to build the submarine in Australia.' In fact it was in South Australia. That was a huge decision, a gutsy decision, and a quite right decision.

I do not want to quibble with that decision. But if you were to look at one element that you would wish to revisit, it would be the fact that there was not a majority Australian owner. The reason I say that is that the Submarine Corporation has never had the same ambitions for exports or exporting the submarine as I believe those who made the original decisions would have envisaged.

What was the Australian institution that funded the 48.5 per cent shareholding? It was the AIDC. Is it not a tragedy that you could not get the Commonwealth Bank, the National Bank, the ANZ or the super funds to come into such an important project in the national interest that added skills and technology exponentially to our defence capability and self‐reliance? We could not get any one of those; we had to get the AIDC. So if there is now another purchase of important equipment—and the current Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) says that it is vital, in the defence of Australia, in terms of self‐reliance, that we have this capability in country—who is going to fund it? Regrettably, there is no institution. That is why I say to the government that we need to think in terms of developing an institution that could fulfil that role, if not others.

As I say, it was a huge decision to build the submarine in Australia. I think the Submarine Corporation have done brilliantly. But my one area of criticism is the fact that they have failed to get into exports. I may even be as ungenerous to suggest that somehow Swedish options from Sweden seem to be more vigorously pushed in our region than were Australian Submarine Corporation options. What was the reason for that? We really never had tight enough control.

The most amazing thing about this bill to sell off the AIDC is that Kockums still has pre-emptive rights to buy out the AIDC shareholding. So, in other words, if you want to privatise the AIDC, including its shareholding in the Submarine Corporation, you actually have to give Kockums the first right of refusal. I would have thought that that was a difficult process. I do not really think that the government has thought through well how it is going to warehouse it. It may be a matter of, `We can put it here—Finance; we can put it in industry and science—DIST; or we can warehouse it some other way.' I would have thought that in relation to Australian taxpayer funds the people of Australia would expect the government of the day to more seriously consider the implications of this move and to have a very clearly thought out approach to this problem.

I am going to be followed in this debate by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson), who has got some important contributions to make to this debate—I might say almost scandalous. Mr Deputy Speaker, you are in the chair, so this is not directed at you, but it is disappointing to me that there is no National Party member making a contribution to this debate, given that Black Jack McEwen was the minister who actually established the AIDC, for reasons that I think were commendable in 1970 and for purposes in the 1970s which are still valid today.

Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, when I go around my electorate—I do not know what it is like in yours—people are concerned about the amount of foreign ownership. They are worried that there are not enough Australian owned companies. They feel that we as parliamentarians are not doing enough to assist, to push up and develop and grow our Australian owned companies and get them bigger and get them employing more Australians in jobs. This was one of the roles that Black Jack McEwen saw for the AIDC. But it has moved away from that original objective and vision, and that is why we on this side of the House are supporting its sale. So in particular I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham and I support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a role for the AIDC. As other speakers pointed out, it was originally established to meet real needs in this community, particularly the reluctance of investors to put their money into regional Australia. Many of us would think that there is still a need for the type of service that the AIDC was originally established to provide. But, as other speakers have also pointed out, it has moved away from that role and its focus on fee based merchant banking can just as readily be met by private sector banks. Therefore, the case for it remaining in the public sector diminishes accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to say that I think AIDC has lost its way in the last two or three years because of the focus of its own management on looking after themselves rather than looking after the purposes for which AIDC was established.
