Back in October 1995 there was considerable public comment and public concern expressed at the salary increases awarded by senior executives of AIDC to themselves of more than 200 per cent in a single year. The Managing Director of AIDC at the time, Mr Gerry van der Merwe, according to the Sunday Age, was paid a salary of $1.8 million, making him the second highest paid executive in the country. As I understand it, his salary was in fact $1.8 million, but he received $400,000 in options as well, which took him over the $2 million mark and made him the highest paid executive in the country.

The Sunday Age compared him with BHP's chief executive who received $1.9 million. But, on the other hand, BHP had a staff of 49,000 and a profit in excess of $1 billion, whereas AIDC had a staff of only 200 and a profit of $28 million. Mr van der Merwe's salary had been boosted from $320,000 to $1.8 million in a period when the bank's profits fell from $46 million to $28 million. It is little wonder that Senator Peter Cook said at the time that he was astonished at the level of wage increases awarded to him.

It was not just the managing director who was being paid these extraordinary salaries. By the end of 1995, the 10 highest paid executives at AIDC were earning between $700,000 and $1.8 million each. Their pay packets corresponded to 36 per cent of AIDC's after tax profits—a truly extraordinary amount when the company was only earning those small profits and only earning those small profits when it was the beneficiary of a government guarantee. This was at a time when the senior executives had sought and gained what were referred to as golden handcuff payments. They said they had to be paid these additional amounts of money because there was uncertainty surrounding the merchant bank's future. But it seems to me, looking at the AIDC figures, that the huge percentage which was ripped off for those top salaries meant that the company was in a considerably worse position than if they had left the company. In any event, Mr van der Merwe received two retention payments—the second of which was $400,000—and he resigned one week after receiving that second retention payment.

AIDC's profits were $28 million in 1994, $43 million in 1993 and $46 million in 1992 against a background where they had a preferential interest rate as a AAA rated beneficiary of the federal guarantee. So all they had to do was take money and lend it on to the National Bank, making use of the guarantee in order to make a return. The management in place at that time failed to generate new income streams and lived off the diminishing returns of the old AIDC income and that income was based on a continuously falling asset base. In my view, this amounted to a straight rip‐off of the taxpayer and amounted to conduct like kids in a candy shop.

It is against that background—of executives having negotiated uncommercial retention packages for themselves and highly profitable golden handshakes—that I think we have to ask a number of questions now surrounding the sale to ensure that the public interest will be protected. I for one am interested in knowing what assets AIDC has sold since the 1996 election and for what value; how do those sales prices compare with an independent assessment of the market value of those assets which have been sold; have there been independent assessments of market value; and was there a commercial reason for the asset to be sold when it was? It is certainly my understanding that bonuses being paid to AIDC executives related to asset sales. So AIDC had a motivation to sell assets, particularly prior to 30 June, irrespective of whether it was getting full value for money.

I think we need to understand whether there have been independent assessments of those asset sales. We also need to understand what kinds of golden handshakes or contracts for senior management are now in place. Would it be the case that we may get a lower price for the sale of AIDC due to lucrative golden handshakes and contracts for senior management in the event that the new owner of AIDC decides to get rid of the senior managers? Based on the retention payments that occurred in the past, it is quite possible that we would have arrangements in place whereby management gets golden handshakes of such a size that they would tend to diminish the price for AIDC. In my view these are important questions, and I would like to hear responses from the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) before this debate is concluded.

AIDC currently employs 200 people. While, as I have indicated, Labor does not want to see generous golden handshakes go to AIDC senior management, we are concerned that ordinary workers in the organisation are not disadvantaged by the sale. It is my understanding that concerns were expressed about this during the Senate committee hearings on Monday. I am pleased, as other opposition members would be, that assurances have now been given that the existing terms and conditions of employment for these workers will be maintained.

AIDC is one of two Australian controlled independent investment houses. It is likely that through this sale it will be purchased by overseas interests. There are no special provisions in the bill to deal with foreign ownership. Against this background, Labor notes the assurances of Senator Kemp that, if the buyer is overseas owned, AIDC's 48.5 per cent holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation could be excluded from the sale. We believe that better assurances should be given, and the amendment we will move to this bill goes to this point.

We will move that the ASC be removed from AIDC Ltd and be located within the AIDC corporation, which is to stay in place to manage the borrowings and loan portfolio and to manage such national interest assets as the Commonwealth's Australian Submarine Corporation shareholding. That would ensure that the Australian Submarine Corporation does not become foreign controlled.

I want to express some concern about the sale of the AIDC. While the points for the sale are understood by the opposition and we are not opposing the sale, if there is no effort to replace the AIDC, that does form part of a pattern of conduct by this government which is detrimental to regional Australia.

We have seen $150 million cut from regional infrastructure projects. That was justified by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, John Sharp, on the grounds that there was no clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development. In other words, he was saying, `We are washing our hands of involvement in regional development.'

We have also seen a budget which impacted massively on regional Australia. So people who relied on regional roads and infrastructure, people who relied on higher education—because the cuts fell disproportionately on regional campuses—and people who relied on assistance to the unemployed have all been massively disadvantaged. ABC funding was cut. There were massive attacks on regional welfare, with the closure of regional CES, tax and Medicare offices. Against that background, it is a matter of concern that the government looks to have some appropriate replacement for AIDC to continue investment in regional Australia.

I do want to repeat the concerns I expressed earlier in my speech, and I want to raise those questions about the kinds of golden handshakes which are involved for AIDC management and the kinds of asset sales that have been engaged in in recent times. What we have had is a situation where AIDC management knew it was the government's intention to sell AIDC—so they knew they were going—and, therefore, there was no incentive for them to behave in a way which was in the best interests of AIDC or the best interests of the taxpayer. It really was a situation which encouraged kids in the candy store behaviour. I am anxious to hear from the government the full details of arrangements concerning golden handshakes and asset sales which have been conducted during the past 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The AIDC Sale Bill is a bill to privatise a government entity. I think I should at least be consistent and express my concern—
—Pre-election or post-election?

—No. The honourable member for Ballarat could find plenty of examples of consistency on this matter of privatisation even before the election. If he is really all that interested in it, I refer him to my speech on the sale of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in October 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like briefly to address that aspect. I am quite happy to stand here in support of the second reading amendment moved by the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and indicate that we understand the reasons behind the government's decision to proceed with the sale, but we do not understand the total reasons as they were explained in the second reading speech.

The reliance in the second reading speech on the support this sale has from the National Commission of Audit is one aspect that would cause me great concern. The nature of that comment by the National Commission of Audit is to indicate that perhaps a government has no business in the types of activities that the AIDC involves itself in. I think there can be, in various ways, a case put for government involvement in a whole range of activities and that we should not shy away from that. They should be considered just as much as any of the alternatives that government has before it.

Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, you would understand the historical links and involvement of government activity in public enterprises, such as railways and other public utilities. As was said earlier in this debate, government ownership and involvement in activities like that has been very important, especially to the regions of Australia.

When we have gone through the sales we have had over the past few years, one of the arguments that has always been put is that the historical basis for government ownership of such organisations as the Commonwealth Bank or Qantas is no longer applicable—things have changed, and the nature of those organisations has changed. To a certain extent in the case of the AIDC, that is the basis for the reasoning on the move towards the total sale.

In the case of AIDC, it has acknowledged that it has moved away from its original charter. We should also look at that. In 1997 we should be looking at the reasons why the AIDC was created some 20 to 30 years ago and whether those reasons still obtain. We should look at vehicles like the AIDC as being important alternatives for involvement of government in ensuring that there is adequate fund provision for a whole host of projects, most particularly, as the shadow minister has said, infrastructure development.

An article in this morning's Melbourne Age discusses the superannuation tax—the so-called superannuation surcharge—and its unintended effect on the ability for funds managers to invest in major infrastructure projects. It indicates that the funds managers have some concern that their ability to provide funding will even further dry up, and we can take that in the context of the likelihood of the infrastructure bonds being scrapped. What needs to be asked is: how are we going to find these alternative sources of funding to ensure that major projects, the likes of which the AIDC has been involved in, and which have been outlined in this debate, will continue?

As I have said, I do not believe that the process of privatisation itself will make an organisation any more efficient. I do not believe that it is somehow inherent in the nature of the private sector to always do things more efficiently and effectively. I believe that there is always a role for government ownership as a form of government intervention in the economy, whether it be to achieve important social objectives that the private sector will not deliver on or because of the benefit in terms of the revenue that flows to government. Telstra is an example that fulfils both of these categories. I note in this context that the AIDC has provided more than $130 million in dividend payments since 1983.

Having said that about my concerns of public ownership vis‐a‐vis private ownership, some of the criticisms that have been made about the AIDC in government ownership likewise indicate that, on occasions, we have to be vigilant that organisations in government ownership do the right thing as well. The issue that has been raised most notably by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) is the matter of executive salaries.

I would have to say, having listened to the honourable member for North Sydney in his considered consideration of those matters, that the real danger is that this is symptomatic not just of behaviour within the AIDC as an organisation but of executive salaries across the board. This is an issue that I have taken up on other occasions. I do not believe that we can finger one organisation for what appears to be exorbitant behaviour in that regard.

The whole matter of executive salaries is a matter that government, on behalf of the people of Australia, should be looking into. It is something we should be doing all we can to put a cap on. If it is good enough for ordinary workers to have to put in work value cases to justify pay increases and to justify their level of remuneration, there should likewise be mechanisms that ensure executive salaries have the same constraints.

It is expected that government business enterprises perform to the same standards that are required in the private sector. As I have just suggested, it does not mean that they have to perform to the same low standards on some important matters. The selling of an enterprise in itself will not make the enterprise any more effective in doing what it does. There is no reason why these objectives are not able to be achieved in full public ownership.

The measures required to bring a government business enterprise to what is considered to be a more competitive standard can be just as easily implemented with the organisation remaining in full public ownership. A public enterprise is a way for governments to promote certain social objectives and act as models for private sector businesses in areas such as progressive industrial relations or providing goods or services to disadvantaged customers.

Privatisation always fails to take into account the fact that government business enterprises are often created to fill a need that was not being met by the private sector. This was the case with the former government's business enterprises like the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, which was designed to protect Australia's national interests by ensuring that Australia did not have to rely on other countries for sera and vaccines. This was the case when the Commonwealth moved into the area of telecommunications to ensure that all Australians had equal access to communications. I note that this is something which can no longer be guaranteed now that Telstra is to be partially privatised.

In the context of a debate about public ownership, I also have urged governments of, now, both persuasions to look at areas that they should pick up on. At the time when they are divesting themselves of ownership in certain areas, there is likewise a need to consider the important areas in the 1990s, going into the next century, where government can have a role.

Recently in a discussion about the cable roll-outs of both Optus and Telstra, I, in not just a flippant way, said that perhaps what we needed to do was nationalise the cables. If the cables were in direct government control, with access to the cables then being on‐sold to the telecommunication companies, we would have had greater control originally and could have greater control about the way in which they fulfil community expectations, the way in which it is an environmentally sensitive issue, the way in which they fulfil the necessary expectations about their capacity and the way in which they would be able to bring things into households.

The banking sector did not adequately provide the necessary capital to finance industries. This was the rationale behind the establishment of the Australian Industry Development Corporation back in 1970. It was envisaged that, in a case where development would not proceed, or would only proceed with ownership and control going to foreign investors, the AIDC could step in. The AIDC has a 48.5 per cent holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation. The rationale behind this investment was the same—there needed to be Australian investment in an undertaking of such national significance.

The issue of possible foreign ownership of such a vital holding as a result of AIDC's privatisation is of concern. As a consequence of this legislation, the AIDC could end up being controlled by foreign investors. While the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) has given undertakings that the Australian Submarine Corporation holding could be removed from the sale should this prove to be the case, the opposition would like to see that stated more clearly in the legislation. Therefore, the opposition will move an amendment, in the consideration in detail stage of the debate, which would ensure that the Australian Submarine Corporation holding will be removed from the AIDC and that it will not end up in foreign hands.

This is a clear example of my concern. Whilst the market forces apply in this—and market forces are all important—they do not necessarily act in the national interest. Market forces actually act in the interests of the market. Given that there has been a global isation of our economy and an integration into the international economy, we cannot be sure that, without proper instruments of intervention by government, market forces will prevail in the national interest.

When considering the privatisation of the AIDC, the original objectives of the organisation should be re-examined. The AIDC was established in 1970, as I said, to promote the development of Australian industry and Australian participation in it. There is agreement from both sides of this place that the AIDC has shifted away significantly from the original function that it performed. While the AIDC has progressively moved away from this over time to a more fee based merchant banking institution, the government needs to look at alternative methods of assistance. The movement away from its original role has been further exemplified in an article in today's Financial Review headed `AIDC enters into vendor finance', which the member for Hotham has referred to.

In privatising the Australian Industry Development Corporation, the government should not think this action absolves them of responsibility for assisting industry to access capital. This is because the problems facing many Australian companies in gaining access to capital still remain, and, as I have suggested, perhaps are getting much worse. The result of this is that many projects get under way only because of foreign investment, if at all. Given the government's current attempts to remove itself from every aspect of industry policy, I do not hold out much hope of the government recognising this.

Because the AIDC has moved away from its original objectives, it is now appropriate for the government to examine the creation of an organisation or an instrument that is more in keeping with the AIDC's original function or look at other measures designed to assist business in gaining access to capital. There is certainly a need for an organisation which has as its function the provision of finance for promoting and developing Australian industry.

When one looks at some of the infrastructure projects that the AIDC has been involved in, such as the two water treatment plants in New South Wales, one sees that in many cases they are projects of national significance. The government must ensure that a mechanism exists which allows such vitally important projects to be funded, and invested in, when they otherwise might not. One of the functions that the AIDC has under section 8A allowed the minister to provide the funds for investment in special projects deemed to be in the national interest. The sale of the AIDC will lose a vehicle that the minister had at hand to ensure that that could be so. It definitely would be in the national interest to have this function transferred to another body or taken up directly by the government itself.

As I said at the outset, I support the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham on the basis that it reaffirms the commitment of this House to the principles underpinning AIDC's creation and, further, condemns the government for not putting in place a structure which will address the failure of the capital markets to provide the sort of funding that the AIDC historically had provided.

It is now time that the government, through whichever minister wishes to take the reins—perhaps members in this debate are fast losing faith in the industry minister to provide adequate leadership—ensures that Australian industries continue to be able to not only maintain their market shares internationally but also grow, and ensures that we will not see further losses of Australian jobs offshore in important industrial sectors like pharmaceuticals and TCF.

For instance, I was told, from a briefing given to the opposition yesterday, that if the TCF tariffs are to go to zero levels early in the next century it would lead to a loss of 700 jobs in one of the municipalities in my electorate. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in my electorate we cannot afford to lose one job. There are thousands of people who are ready, willing and able to take up worthwhile employment. The government has to recognise that there are many regions, such as the electorate that I represent, that need the assistance and intervention from government to ensure that Australian industry prospers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the debate today and appreciate that there is a universal view that the subject of the AIDC Sale Bill, AIDC Ltd, is pursuing business activities which make it no longer appropriate to be maintained by government ownership. Whatever the benefit of this particular organisation when it was established—a number of speakers in the course of this debate have referred to various projects that were of benefit to the community generally in an infrastructure sense—it has long past being useful. It has lost its way somewhat simply because of the fact that there has been a deregulation of banking and there are other facilities available for the type of infrastructure that AIDC once supported.

SPEECH.PARA: The judgment that this business is not appropriate for government is one that has been held by both sides of the House—by the current government and by is predecessors—for a number of years. Sale measures had been initiated previously, but had not met with much success. The lessons from those previous actions have been learned and led to the legislation currently before the House which will enable this government to bring the sale of AIDC Ltd and its associated business activities to a successful conclusion.

The government will be opposing the opposition's amendments relating to the Australian Submarine Corporation holding. I made it clear during the second reading speech that the ASC holding would be quarantined from the sale. Therefore, this amendment is unnecessary.

This legislation was necessary because the existing legislative framework governing the operations of the Australian Industry Development Corporation did not provide the flexibility that is necessary to conclude a sale on satisfactory terms and conditions. In addition, despite the successful takeover proposal conducted by the corporation for the shares it did not own in AIDC Ltd, minority shareholdings in the company continued to exist for technical reasons. With the passage of this bill, it will be possible to deal with those holdings in an expeditious manner without in any way compromising the fair and equitable treatment of those shareholders. The bill clearly makes provision to protect the interests of those parties, consistent with the obligations set out in the constitution for the compulsory acquisition of property.

Another fundamental issue dealt with by the bill is that it provides the appropriate legal environment for the substantial financial interests of the Commonwealth to be managed both during and after the sale process.

A significant characteristic of the business activities of AIDC Ltd has been the added protection afforded its borrowings through the use of the Commonwealth guarantee. With the sale of the company, or its assets, the Commonwealth will continue to stand behind the guarantees that it has already provided, but in so doing it is necessary to ensure that the Australian Industry Development Corporation is provided with the appropriate legislative base to continue that task. The bill provides that base.

Concern has been expressed by the board of AIDC Ltd in relation to the power provided by this bill for the minister to require the provision of information to assist in the sale process. The concern was expressed on the basis that that may impact on the company's client relationship. I can assure the House that this power will not be used lightly by the government. The Commonwealth will be mindful of the need to protect commercially sensitive material and will ensure that commercial interests are not prejudiced during the sale process.

The bill makes provision for the protection of information obtained under this arrangement. However, it is also important to ensure that the Commonwealth's actions, as the beneficial owner of AIDC Ltd, are not unnecessarily constrained and ensure that an effective power of veto is not provided to third party interests.

In progressing this asset sale, in common with other recent asset sales, it is important for the Commonwealth to protect its financial interest and ensure that it receives full value from the sale. For this reason, the bill makes the necessary provisions to protect the sale from the imposition of stamp duty and cancels any residual franking credits that may exist in the company at the time of the sale. The approach to these provisions is consistent with provisions in other sale legislation which this House has previously passed. Similarly—and I note a number of speakers on the other side commented on this—employee interests have been protected by the provisions relating to long service leave and occupational health and safety. In other words, all the benefits that have currently accrued to the employees of AIDC Ltd will be protected through this legislation and will be passed on in appropriate circumstances to those employees.

With a maturing financial and merchant banking industry in Australia, it is important that the government progress this sale and thereby remove itself from this area of business activity. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 1 to 3:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 15 (after line 10), after the heading of Division 3, insert:

EMPHASIS.TAB: 33HA Minister for Finance to direct AIDC Ltd to transfer asset

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister for Finance shall, by written notice given to AIDC Ltd, direct that body to transfer all of its holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation to the Corporation.
(2) The direction may impose on AIDC Ltd requirements that are ancillary or incident to the transfer, including (but not limited to) any of the following requirements:

TAB.TAB: (a) a requirement that the transfer must be completed no later than 30 June 1997;
(b) a requirement that the transfer must be undertaken in a specified manner;

PARA.TAB: (3) AIDC Ltd must comply with the direction.
(4) To avoid doubt, nothing in this Act or in any other Act authorises the Minister to transfer from the Corporation its holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, page 15 (line 13), omit "The Minister for Finance", substitute "Subject to section 33HA, the Minister for Finance".
(3) Schedule 1, page 16 (line 4), omit "The Minister for Finance", substitute "Subject to section 33HA, the Minister for Finance".

We foreshadowed these amendments in the second reading debate because of our specific concern about what happens to the Australian Submarine Corporation shares. We believe that the Submarine Corporation and the arrangements that the Labor government developed in relation to it—its strategic partnership with Kockums, its involvement and establishment in Adelaide and the huge growth in industry development that occurred consequent upon that—are a shining example of what can sensibly be done if the leverage of government policy together with the financing that backed it from the AIDC can be brought together.

We believe there is still some potential future to build off the success of the Submarine Corporation. It is for that reason that we would obviously be reluctant to see the Submarine Corporation sold off as part of the arrangement that will sell off AIDC, the share package that the AIDC holds in the Submarine Corporation. That being said, we note that it is the intention of the government, in abolishing AIDC Ltd by the legislation, to still keep the corporation within AIDC ostensibly to manage the loans.

We are saying that, in addition to the management of the loans, the corporation should hold the Submarine Corporation shares. We think it is important not just for the strategic national interest that Australia control its own defence capability but that there be future opportunities for the development of a defence based industry in this country, and the ability to develop that clearly is going to be significantly limited if the government still is not in the game. Our approach is to keep the government in the game, not by taking the shares back but by recognising where they are held and by parking the management of those within the AIDC.

It also would require there to be some bipartisan discussion as to what the government's future intentions may be in relation to the shareholding of Submarine Corporation. We believe we can inject some sensible input and hope that the government might be prepared to embrace us in that approach in trying to develop a strengthened industry off our defence capability, off our shipbuilding industry, off our heavy engineering capacity, but really moving more into the strategic development, the high-tech industries, associated with defence and sense tracking, and recognising the significance that that has, quite frankly, for the manufacturing industry.

BREAK.PARA: When you think of the manufacturing industry generally, it is the software packages and the engineering dimensions that are important. It is not just a question of the physical infrastructure; it is the processes by which that technology is run. It is the systems running; it is the information technology. If Australia is to continue its growth in manufacturing exports, and that growth has already been significant, we need to use strategic inputs and strategic placements and the government needs to be in there as a partner with industry in securing a future direction for this nation.

We therefore think that this amendment ought to be supported by the government. It is still saying that it can look to deal with it as it would like but that there would be a requirement to have wider discussions as to what its intentions might be. We accept the assurance of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) that it is not intended to sell the Submarine Corporation into foreign interests, but we are seeking to secure the base in this country for the Submarine Corporation and that which flows from it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support these amendments to the AIDC Sale Bill. In my speech in the second reading debate I made a couple of comments about what had happened in terms of answers to questions in the Senate. In the answers I quoted from the Senate committee hearing, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), who was representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), made it perfectly clear after questions from Senator Ray that it was not the intention of the government to sell the Australian Submarine Corporation to foreign interests. But, after a series of questions, it came out that the government and the minister have not put forward any proposal as to how that is to be avoided when the AIDC is sold. We do not know what is going to happen. I hope the minister is going to tell us.

SPEECH.PARA: What is actually going to happen to the Australian Submarine Corporation? How is the minister going to ensure that that does not happen in the general context of the sale of AIDC Ltd? Interestingly, when asked what the options are, the top official said the government had made no determination. Even though the government have said on the one hand that they want to retain the 100 per cent—and they have brought the bill forward, they are saying they are selling the AIDC Ltd—they have not made a determination on this key aspect of the future of the Australian Submarine Corporation.

Given that situation, when asked, the official said, `Well, one option is to actually do what this amendment proposes', which is to hold the shares in the AIDC. So that is one option, and this is an option which we are urging in terms of these amendments. So we would urge the government to accept this amendment. They have been properly structured and their implications have been looked at. We urge the government to accept these amendments, to accept this approach, and let us give at least some security to the Australian Submarine Corporation in terms of its Australian ownership.

As the shadow minister said, as we move into further discussions on the future of Defence Industries, we can then have that body in that place at least for the time being until we determine some further important issues in relation to Defence Industries. I also think that we should have some kind of broad discussion in this parliament on the future of Defence Industries and what is to happen after the AIDC is sold.

We have supported the AIDC Ltd sale, but we are saying to the minister, `Look after the Australian Submarine Corporation. Let us clearly state what the intention of the government is, and let us adopt these amendments.'

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Submarine Corporation is particularly important to the Australian government and to the Australian people—both because of its importance to Australian defence and because of its importance to Australian industry. The government's significant holding in the Submarine Corporation via the AIDC is not something that should be allowed to go through with the passage of this bill without clear views being expressed by the parliament on that important matter.

BREAK.PARA: It is appropriate that the parliament place some restrictions upon the sale of the AIDC to ensure that the Submarine Corporation remains for the time being with a government stakeholding in it. The relevant amendment moved by the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean), clearly provides a mechanism through which that can occur to ensure that the Submarine Corporation's government shareholding is kept in the AIDC.

That opens up a number of opportunities further down the track as part of the development of Australian defence industry policy, and indeed, more broadly, industry policy for other sectors, because defence industry so often is at the cutting edge of technology developments and where defence industry goes so too does the broader industry sector.

Can I quickly say a couple of words about the Submarine Corporation and its importance to defence. The Submarine Corporation has now managed to construct three submarines as part of an order of six, which are without doubt amongst the best in the world and regarded by many as being the most significant non‐nuclear submarines anywhere in the world.

That is a capability that is important to Australia's defence. It is a capability that the opposition take very seriously. Indeed, it is a capability that was established during the period in which Labor was in office, when Kim Beazley and later Robert Ray as ministers for defence strongly supported the acquisition of those submarines and supported the Australian government's involvement in that project to ensure that it came to fruition and to ensure that there was a substantial Australian participation in the management of the organisation. I am not sure that that is a commitment that is shared by both sides of the parliament, and I would invite the minister at the table, the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), to take the opportunity in this debate to make that clear.

It is worth noting that in terms of the commitment on this side of the parliament to the Submarine Corporation and the defence importance of that program, we have made it plain that were we in government we would commit to the additional two submarines, 7 and 8. I invite the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan), who is in the chamber, to address that issue to see whether or not the government is serious about maintaining a significant defence capability in submarine development, maintenance and construction. It is important to the Labor Party. It was important to us in government and it remains important to us in opposition.

In relation to the defence industry implications of the Submarine Corporation, it is not just that the Submarine Corporation has produced an absolute world leader in submarine warfare; it is the long line of domestic companies who supply to the Submarine Corporation who have also benefited. The downstream suppliers to the Submarine Corporation number in their thousands. Many of those are local firms who have been pulled along by the submarine program into high‐tech areas and, as a result of that, are now competing successfully in world markets for the various components provision.

That is an important consideration in the long‐term sustainability, not just of the Collins class submarine but in terms of the development of new classes of warships and other platforms. That is a capability we should not see let go. It is important that in dealing with the sale of the AIDC the parliament places these strictures on the sale. The parliament should ensure through this particular amendment that the shareholding in the Submarine Corporation remains for the time being with the government, that it is parked in the AIDC. It is a very sensible and worthwhile amendment, and I do hope the government accepts it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate to express my concerns about the needs of older people in our community with disabilities and their older carers. My remarks will be based on a study carried out on behalf of the Mullauna Retirement Village at Blacktown run by the Uniting Church. I propose to quote at length from this report as the findings must surely be mirrored across Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Mullauna is seeking to extend its services to older people with disabilities and older people caring for people with disabilities both in the provision of accommodation and in home support. The Mullauna group believe they should be extending their services based on community needs in the following areas: both residential and in‐home; as part of a continuum of care; with consideration for affordability; with adequately skilled respite carers; with consideration for the needs of older non‐English speaking people and Aboriginal people; in more innovative forms, for example, accommodation for both carers and the person receiving care; and to develop its expertise to cater for older people with sensory disabilities and dementia.

The results of the report I am using today would surely apply equally to many other parts of Australia. The Blacktown local government area could be described as a financially constrained area based on the evidence of the relatively high proportion of people living in public housing. This group represents 14.9 per cent of the Blacktown population, which is well above the state average of 5.6 per cent. There is also a relatively high proportion of older people on very low income support. This low income support would be an impeding factor in obtaining assistance from community and privately based services for domestic and personal care support. The report says:

Blacktown has a relatively high proportion of residents (33.6%), 65 years and over, who were born in a non‐English speaking country (NESC). Blacktown is the 4th highest LGA in the state regarding residents, 65 years and over from NES countries.

The Western Sydney Area Health Service, in a study of older people in western Sydney from NES countries, stated that it is estimated that in five years time, 25% of all older people in Australia will be from a NESC.

In Blacktown there are seven retirement villages comprising self‐care and hostel units. There are 10 nursing homes. In total there are 17 establishments which have either self-care, hostel or nursing home places or a combination of these forms of accommodation. The Department of Community Services manages four group homes for people with intellectual disabilities and funds a further 13 homes managed by community or church organisations.

This group home accommodation mainly caters for a younger population. In total there are fewer than 10 people over 60 in these homes. A coordinator of a number of these group homes stated that these older residents often suffer from early forms of dementia. As a result they are not able to manage in the group homes because of staffing numbers. The report went on to say:

The extent of community outreach services by retirement villages in Blacktown was not investigated, except to note that Mullauna manages 30 community aged care packages. It is known that some of the community and church managed group homes provide support to assist people with intellectual disability living alone or with carers in the Blacktown area.

Accommodation is sought in mainstream hostels and nursing homes. Service providers say that it is very difficult to find such hostels or nursing home placements. They are often forced to seek placements out of Blacktown.

There is a strong demand for respite accommodation. The resultant waiting list for planned respite means that there is little opportunity for emergency residential care. Also, people with disabilities often have complex care needs that cannot be met in available respite facilities, thereby increasing the concerns of carers of these people. This very important report I am quoting from went on to say:

While nursing homes and hostels may be inappropriate forms of accommodation for people under 65 years with disabilities, they have often been the only forms of respite for carers of people with disabilities.

Carers support groups report that in recent times even these `inappropriate' forms of respite are becoming less available, even though there have not been any changes to legislation or departmental policy in this regard.

This report indicates that there is still a significant number of older people with disabilities or handicaps in Blacktown who are managing to assist each other or are being assisted by some family member without any outside help.

The older Aboriginal people's needs in this area have never been addressed; they are unique because the elders are much revered. Supply the hostel with the appropriate skilled staff and the families will do the rest. They also have a significantly shorter life span than other groups.

Non‐English speaking older persons have special needs with dementia in any form that sets in. The first, of course, is language. Therefore the need for hostel and nursing home care in their mother tongue is absolutely essential.

Stroke victims are also there in very high proportions, another horror for the victim and the carers. Stroke debilitates different sections of the brain. Persons who lose the power of speech can be locked into a world we dare not envisage. Then others lose use of limbs and cannot feed themselves or control their bodily functions. Carers are usually the partner until either the carer burns out or ceases physically to be able to perform the needs of the victim.
The conclusion in the report is that there is considerable scope to extend services to support older people with disabilities, especially older carers. The report says:

The potential for expansion of residential services in Blacktown is virtually non-existent. It seems very unlikely that the Commonwealth government (which administers and funds hostel, nursing homes and community aged care package programs) will extend these forms of care in Blacktown.
In the report, service providers pinpoint the greatest area of unmet service needs for older people with disabilities and older carers as:
. respite care, both regular and emergency, both in residential care and at home;
. community transport, more extensive and more appropriate;

. assistance to overcome housebound isolation for both those with disabilities and carers. This isolation was also linked to associated needs of more information on available services and the provision of training for carers; and
. more networking of services to promote complementarity and flexibility of service provision.

Finally, the Mullauna report indicates that more than 50 per cent of the older population of Blacktown with its multicultural character has some disability. Service providers in Blacktown indicate that there are some urgent unmet needs for older people with disabilities and older carers in the area.

By far the greatest need was for more respite services both in residential care and in-home respite. The demand for respite is constantly increasing, leading to long waiting lists and diminishing opportunities for emergency respite. Further needs include more flexible and more extensive community transport, the alleviation of housebound social isolation and the development of better networking of residential and community based services.

I hope that this report on the needs of older people with disabilities and older carers will lead to improved services for those most deserving people, and I compliment the Mullauna village on their important work. I would be happy to table the report for the information of all honourable members.

I will conclude by referring to a statement by Ellen Long, who is the secretary of the National Seniors Association at Blacktown—this being Seniors Week in New South Wales—and let her have the last say on this issue. I have asked Ellen Long to make some submission to me relating to this particular matter, and I will read her short comments:

Group homes in Blacktown LGA—there are many. Most of these homes have intellectually impaired persons, some have one or several disabilities. Most of these houses have three to five residents, one only has ten. The problems applying to these are many and complex . . . Aging process in our intellectually impaired persons is an enormous problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I am not sure how close you were to the conclusion of that quote.
—I was very close to the conclusion.
—Then I would be prepared to allow you to complete the remainder of the quote.

SPEECH.PARA: How can we place into nursing homes persons with such multiple disabilities, they require high level and specific care. Often they are aggressive and make a lot of noise. Their needs must be met in a caring sensible manner that is cost effective.
