TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate today to speak to the House about one of the most tragic and distressing problems facing our community; that is, the abuse and neglect of children. We are all aware of the extensive media coverage recently of the sexual abuse of children by paedophiles. This is obviously a serious problem in our society. However, today I want to speak about the abuse and neglect of children by their families, because the most common child abuse offenders—both sexual and non‐ sexual—are family members.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, a national study by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare showed that natural parents were responsible in more than two-thirds of abuse and neglect cases. Yet the fact that abusive and neglectful behaviour towards children most often occurs at the hands of family members, usually in the home, by no means makes it a private matter. Rather, the abuse and neglect of our children is very much a public issue—one that has tremendous social and economic consequences for our society.

BREAK.PARA: The magnitude of this problem is impossible to illustrate with hard statistics; thus the real incidence of child abuse and neglect is unknown. However, in 1995, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare reported that, based on substantiated cases, the annual rate of child abuse in Australia is 5.7 per 1,000 children. The national committee on violence has reported that the age group at greatest risk of violent death in Australia is infants up to 12 months of age. In addition, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare study showed that, based on substantiated cases, the age group with the greatest incidence of abuse and neglect were 13‐ and 14‐year olds. Furthermore, although female children represent three‐quarters of substantiated sex abuse cases, both sexes are equally at risk of abuse and neglect. No-one knows for sure whether the incidence of child abuse and neglect is growing, but many law enforcement officials, social workers and members of the clergy who deal with this problem on a daily basis are of the opinion that it is.

What sort of factors put a child at risk of abuse or neglect? While it is true that child abuse affects individuals representing all socioeconomic levels, most research suggests that it is the stresses caused by poverty, unemployment, under‐employment and social isolation. A child is also at risk if his or her parents suffered abuse or neglect as children.

The abuse and neglect of our children entail tremendous social, personal and economic costs in our community. The long-term impact on abused children is grave. These children grow up to have poor self-esteem. They grow up unable to trust others. They often grow up not knowing how to deal with conflict other than through aggressive means, thus setting up a cycle of chronic abuse. Indeed, it is an unfortunate fact that in the area of child abuse violence begets violence.

Although the majority of abused and neglected children do not become delinquent, criminal or violent, studies have shown that being abused or neglected as a child significantly increases that child's risk for delinquency, adult criminal behaviour and violent criminal behaviour. Research based on large surveys overseas suggests that severely abused children are two to three times more likely to have higher rates of academic and disciplinary problems in school, physically violent behaviour at home and outside the home and, of course, substance abuse. Victims of severe child abuse are four times more likely to be arrested.

The tremendous economic costs to federal, state and local governments associated with the abuse and neglect of children include costs of medical treatment, family law services, social security, education and law enforcement. Furthermore, overseas research suggests that arrest and imprisonment by law enforcement officials often does little to deter offenders, particularly amongst those groups that are already highly marginalised in our society.

Given these distressing and costly consequences of child abuse, I have a major concern that the way in which we are dealing with this problem is seriously flawed. What I mean to say is that way too often we depend on social workers, police officers, lawyers, judges and health care workers to pick up the pieces after irreparable damage has been done. Surely we have an obligation to do all that we can to facilitate the prevention of and early intervention into the abuse and neglect of our children.

In this regard, we could learn from some of the community service groups in Australia who are preventing child abuse and neglect by offering supportive services to at risk families. In New South Wales, the real pioneer group in this area is the Child Abuse Prevention Service, known as CAPS. CAPS commenced operating its 24-hour crisis and support line in 1973, three year before the New South Wales Department of Community Services introduced its crisis telephone service. Since that time, CAPS trained counsellors—the majority of whom work without pay—have provided this service 24 hours a day, 365 days year. Remarkably, CAPS has not been off the air, so to speak, since its inception.

In addition to its hotline service, CAPS has six drop-in facilities—at Wyong, Orange, Ashfield, Liverpool, Umina and Tuggerah—for stressed parents, primarily mothers. Ser vices provided at these facilities are aimed at the management of stress, resolving conflict in non-violent ways and promoting attitudes and behaviours which nurture and support children through, among other things, discussion groups, nutrition classes and workshops aimed at boosting self-esteem. CAPS trained counsellors also frequently make home visits to at risk families.

It is not an overstatement to say that CAPS has saved the lives of countless children in New South Wales since it commenced operations in 1973. What is truly remarkable is the degree to which CAPS provides these services in spite of extremely limited funds. Other than around a $100,000 annual grant from the Commonwealth government, CAPS relies totally on private donations and the efforts of numerous unpaid staff. CAPS receives not one cent from the New South Wales state government.

CAPS and similar community sector organisations play a crucial role in the prevention of child abuse and neglect. At this time, I want to acknowledge the contributions of the Children at Risk Committee, which has since 1980 provided a significant community education program in my electorate. We cannot, however, depend too heavily on these organisations. CAPS, the Children at Risk Committee and similar organisations are seriously underfunded by governments at local, state and federal levels.

I believe we all have a responsibility and a moral obligation to do more to prevent child abuse and neglect. As law‐makers in this House, we must ensure that a deaf ear is no longer turned towards the cries and screams of Australia's generations of abused and neglected children. Apart from the existing support for child abuse services, we must be mindful that our policies should bring families together. After all, a safe, loving and stable family unit is the best environment for the nurturing of Australia's greatest and most precious asset—its children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to pursue the issue of the dumping of aviation fuel over the residents of Grayndler and Lowe. It is something I raised in the House two days ago, but as yet we still have not seen a response from the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) or the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) or in fact from anyone on the other side of the House. I did think that the chair of the Sydney Airport Community Forum might have taken the opportunity today to raise it.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation on 15 October 1996 where an Evergreen Airlines flight left Mascot airport at approximately 12.59 p.m. and sprayed raw avgas over the residents of Grayndler and Lowe—in fact, from the end of the runway right up to Russell Lea, which is near Drummoyne, a distance of 10 kilometres—required, indeed demanded, an immediate response from the minister to show that the residents of the inner western suburbs of Sydney could be confident that some action would be taken to ensure that this did not happen again.

I raised the issue yesterday in a meeting of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform with the head of Airservices Australia. I was assured by Airservices Australia that they will get back to me with a plan to ensure that these occurrences do not happen again. I would have also thought that we needed an urgent political response from the government to ensure that this does not happen again, because the response I received from the minister to question on notice No. 927, I think, is clearly inadequate. It is clearly inadequate to simply say:
(4) Should any future incidents occur, the issue will again be raised with the operator as a matter of urgency.

That someone will pick up the phone and ask the operator to explain their actions is appalling and is really a tickle and slap approach to a very real problem which has the potential to be a health and environmental catastrophe. So today in this House I am raising again the fact that we do not really have a response from the minister on this, and I call upon the government to implement a program of real action.

The minister's response indicated that there were three similar alleged incidents in the previous 12 months. I read on page 3 of the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday, 19 March 1997 that those incidents occurred on 30 July, 13 August and 14 January and involved Evergreen Airlines once again. It is a pity, I must say, that the minister gave a response to a question on notice of some five months standing to the Sydney Morning Herald and not to the parliament before the residents of the inner western suburbs of Sydney were given an answer as to what had occurred.

There has been massive concern since I raised this issue in parliament. I spoke yesterday on radio 2BL, 2GB, Today FM and Triple M. Residents throughout Sydney were calling talkback radio yesterday, telling their stories about oil and petrol fumes being dumped on their schools, their homes, their children, their parks and their clothes and about the black filter of soot they have to wipe off their cars in the morning at places such as Sydenham and Marrickville in my electorate. Unfortunately, we still have not seen a government response.

If it is the case that Evergreen Airlines have committed these serious offences—four times at least over a 12-month period—then I think there is a case to say that Australia does not want them. The Australian aviation industry deserves better than to put up with shonky US airlines. US registered airlines have an appalling record on safety and on their mechanical administrative operations.

It is now up to the government to say, `Enough is enough: repeat offenders will be told they are not welcome in Australia.' For any offence, as a minimum there should be action to bring in very severe penalties which will ensure that there is action on the lackadaisical attitude of these airlines—in this case where five broken fuel valves were spraying fuel all over residents of my electorate and the electorate of Lowe.

I have been very disappointed with the lack of response from the government on this issue. We see a lack of response on the fuel dumping. We see residents of my electorate in weatherboard houses which cannot be insulated who are still waiting for a response as to what will happen to their homes— whether they will be voluntarily acquired or what the government will do now that it has acknowledged that those houses cannot be insulated properly. In just the same way, the people in small businesses in Sydenham who have had to shut up shop and have had their livelihoods taken away are still waiting for a response from the government. Whether that response is positive or negative, it is not good enough to leave them hanging for months and years before there is action. When it is an issue of the millionaire aviator mates of the government, such as Dick Smith, then we see action. But when it is an issue of the health and safety of residents in inner western Sydney we see nothing. We do not see trials of weatherboard housing insulation or of fuel dumping or any of these issues in the ministerial entrance such as we saw with the PAD system. I am very disappointed.

I am pleased that the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) is in the chamber, because I hope that he will respond with his concern about fuel being dumped on his residents. As yet the member for Lowe has not participated in the aviation debate, because he had a function—and I understand that—for the member for Braddon (Mr Miles), the leader of the ultraconservative Lyons Forum, who is obviously a very important colleague to him. But, frankly, I would have thought last night when the member for Lowe attempted to attack me and the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) in an adjournment speech—it was a bit like being hit with a wet lettuce and we are still waiting for any issue of substance to be raised—he might have mentioned the fact that aviation fuel was dumped on his residents for about four kilometres. I would have thought there might have been one word expressing concern about that in the speech. But, if you look at the Hansard for Wednesday, 19 March 1997, you will see no mention of aviation fuel nor of Evergreen Airlines.

That is the substance of this debate. This is an important debate which requires action from those on both sides of the House who are fair dinkum about representing their electorate. I hope the member for Lowe has something to say about this issue and makes representations to his government to make sure that his minister pulls his finger out and shows he is fair dinkum about preventing further incidents.

What we have seen is a trigger. We have anecdotal evidence raised by residents around Sydney airport being taken up now in this House. Not only should action and penalties—and if needs be the banning of airlines—be brought in but there should be regular reporting to the Sydney Airport Community Forum of these incidents. Whenever this occurs, you should not have to put a question on notice and wait five months to get details about it. Nor should you have to get a response which just says, `Three similar alleged incidents have occurred,' with no details whatsoever. The residents around Sydney airport have a right to know when carcinogens are being dumped on their heads. They have a right to know, and they have a right to be informed by the minister. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to draw members' attention to a very unrepresented section of the community, the self‐funded retirees. This group of elderly Australians amounts to about six to seven per cent of the population. They are about a million people, so I am not talking about a small group but a significant one, living not only in my electorate but all over Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The growth in the number of Australians in the over‐65 bracket dictates that some drastic measures have to be taken if the Commonwealth aged pension is to be retained as a safety net for those unable to provide for their own retirement. With living conditions in Australia some of the best in the world, with excellent nutrition and with skilled medical facilities, elderly people's life expectancy is getting longer. People in good health can function quite efficiently into their mid‐80s, and a fair proportion will live to be 90 plus. This means that, with a conventional retiring age of 65, people will live in retirement for an average of 20 years. This is a quite significant lifespan at a time when you are no longer getting regular earnings from work.

BREAK.PARA: From talking to groups of self‐funded retirees in my electorate, it is painfully obvious that these people feel overlooked and neglected by successive governments. I submit that the time has come to take positive action to attend to these people's needs. I again draw members' attention to the fact that over six per cent of the voting public can easily change a government and one million discontented elderly Australians can be ignored at our peril.

Self‐funded retirees are a special group. They are independent and self‐sufficient. They do not participate in the welfare system, they are not a burden on the public purse and they are a group of people who have always paid their taxes, abided by the law, conformed to government regulations and generally contributed in their working lifetime to the good of society. In many cases, I am sure they have given much of their personal time—and maybe even their money—to their local community, welfare and political organisations. I believe they should be given a fair go.

Consider some other aspects of this group of a million elderly Australians. In America they are known as the `grey lobby'—an apt and evocative title. Their investments represent a major proportion of national savings. These investments are a major source of funds for national development and, I would like to emphasise again, save the taxpayer many millions of dollars because their investors do not take DSS payments.

In addition, you may find that self‐funded retirees have helped their families during times of major unemployment. They often assist with education of grandchildren. They support the Treasury in the payment of their taxes. They do much voluntary work for senior citizens' groups and community groups, such as Meals on Wheels. Also, most have retained private health insurance and, therefore, relieve the strain on the public hospital service.

I was approached recently by a branch in my electorate of the Association of Independent Retirees and had the privilege of addressing a meeting at which more than 70 people attended. I have since had the opportunity of discussing with the president, Mr Bob Sedgewick, and the vice‐president, Mr Bill Turner, a number of their concerns of which I seek to inform the House.

The crux of the self-funded retirees' problem lies in the fact that governments in the past have not granted this group any status. There is no classification for self‐funded retirees in the government's census form. Can you imagine that we actually have today, in the last stages of the 20th century, a million elderly Australians without classification, unrecognised in law and unprotected in attempting to maintain the lifestyle they have worked so hard to achieve? The first thing we must do for this group is put them on the next and subsequent census.

These Australians see themselves as a great asset to our nation. They ask for recognition of the following basic objectives: tax relief for pharmaceutical expenses, inflation protection for investments, such as tax‐free bonds; tax deductibility for private health insurance; simplification of criteria for the seniors card and for the card to be made national so that it is accepted by all states.

I now would also draw the attention of the House to a risk factor involved for self-funded retirees. Unlike those who live off the state, who receive a regular fortnightly payment which is indexed for inflation, self-funded retirees have no mechanism open to them but to invest in income producing marketable securities. Fixed interest securities are subject to variable interest rates and ordinary shares are subject to market movements, the profitability of the company and the generosity of the directors. Self-funded retirees do not have the security of a defined income or of cost of living adjustments.

In the taxation area these people are taxed as if they are still working. Only those with incomes under $20,000 have recently received a tax rebate equivalent to that available to pensioners. Furthermore, they have concerns that the current policy is gradually destroying one of our greatest resources—it is not encouraging current wage earners to save for their retirement. The follow‐on from this is the attitude of the younger generation to saving. They are often heard to say, `What's the use of saving? We will be better off on the pension.'

It is painfully obvious that these one million elderly Australians need attention. They need a member of the government through whom their requests and suggestions can be funnelled. I suggest to the House that a minister be appointed to look after the interests of self-funded retirees. Obviously, with such a large group of people, their problems will spill over to many departments. Therefore, the appointment of a minister to intervene for them, to coordinate all their needs and requests is warranted. Furthermore, an appointment of a minister would be recognition of their status in the community.

As I said earlier in this speech, the self-funded retirees have nowhere to go, no-one to represent their cause or interests. Mr Deputy Speaker, consider the Aboriginal people who number around 300,000 and have a full-time minister, consider the pensioners who have the Minister for Social Security; but self-funded retirees, who number one million, have no minister, no representative, no-one to talk to and nowhere to go.

This group of elderly Australians have never had recognition, yet they are deserving of as much recognition as pensioners, veterans, Aboriginals, migrants, sportsmen, sportswomen, small business, defence personnel, and families, all of whom are recognised and have ministerial representation. These Australians are not a burden to the community; they are not a burden on the welfare system; they are not wealthy—and the longer they live the poorer they get.

I shall end by drawing the attention of the House to the fact that one million voters can easily swing an election, and it would be calamitous if they were turned into an electoral burden. Action to help self-funded retirees in a meaningful, ongoing way should be taken and should be taken now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Snap Printing company in Western Australia recently launched its new television advertising campaign. While images of the modern working world flash frenetically across the screen, a company spokesman observes that, `The world has a new currency, and it is called information.' That proposition is not a new one, but it should be a timely and necessary reminder for this government. The last 12 months have seen regular exposes in the media which suggest that Australia will not be able to maintain its claim of being a clever country if we do not start to take seriously the issues of research and development and of intellectual property.

SPEECH.PARA: The first year of the coalition government has been an interesting one indeed. On the one hand, we have a government led by the departments of Finance and Treasury that have savaged industry assistance programs, most notably the R&D program, on the grounds that they are not cost effective. On the other, we have industry experts like Mr Jon Stanford, the former Director of the Bureau of Industry Economics, observing:
Knowledge is a key factor in underpinning faster growth. Knowledge‐intensive industries generate substantial spin-offs to other activities by their contribution to economic growth.

It is high time that we acknowledge our overreliance on extractive industries—industries that have performed well in the past but which are neither sustainable in the long term nor able to keep pace with the industry of knowledge. As one visiting academic to Australia observed last year, `The only way to create wealth is through raw technology and the people who deliver it.'

Australia has proven itself to be world class in the mining industry, but only after the investment of huge sums of time and of money. Why are we not prepared to take the same level of risk with intellectual property? Putting knowledge back into technology should be a priority for any Australian government.

In my contribution to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) debate, I referred to one example of Australia's blase attitude towards the protection of intellectual property and research rights. In September last, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on a team at the Sydney Children's Hospital Cancer Institute and its cutting edge experimentation into the treatment of cancer and the AIDS virus. If research such as this were to develop from pure experimentation into a marketable drug, the spill‐over effect it could have in Australia, in both human and economic terms, cannot be overstated.

Regrettably, the main gist of the article was to note that several key scientists producing this research had opted to relocate and continue their studies in Canada because of the unfavourable research and development environment in Australia. In short, it will be Canada and not Australia that will reap the rewards of years of painstaking research if the drug is marketed.

Less than six months later a similar story hit the papers. Headlines such as `Flu pill trials leave us in the cold' and `Giants in battle for flu cure' dominated the front pages of the national press. A story frighteningly similar to the one I have just mentioned emerged. A United States drugs company revealed that an anti-influenza pill, which was described as `the drug that could be the most profitable in history' was in its final stages of testing. It was also noted that this wonder drug was the product of years of research by a team of Australian scientists at the Australian National University. This was a team of scientists who managed to obtain foreign funding for its research but who were rejected by the Hawke government when it applied for a research grant.

Because of successive Australian governments' lax attitude towards patents on intellectual property, an English pharmaceutical company now stands to become the world's biggest drug company early in the next decade. Dr Graeme Laver, an Australian scientist involved in the initial investigation of this influenza drug, noted that this was yet another instance of local scientists moving overseas to further world‐class research—and all because of a lack of funding for research and development and inadequate protection of patents in Australia. He said:
If it—
the flu pill—
works, the market is staggering, unbelievable. But . . . no money will flow back—
into Australia—
which is a pity because the whole thing started in Australia and Australia should profit from it.

What a pity indeed. Australia is already overreliant on imported drugs. If this does not change, our ageing population will see this dependence further burden our ailing current account balance sheet.

Last year the World Competitiveness Yearbook showed a substantial drop in Australia's international competitiveness. Overall we rated No. 21—a drop of five places on the previous 12 months, and the largest drop of any OECD nation. Of particular concern was our lack of competitiveness in the areas of entrepreneurship and innovation. Not surprisingly, our shabby performance in these fields meant that we also scored poorly in our ability to promote exports and enterprise overseas.

Australian research and development companies have struggled to secure adequate support for as long as R&D has featured in the Australian vocabulary. As a result there has been an imbalance between the amount of time, talent and money that has gone into new R&D compared with the successful marketing of new technology. But that is only part of the problem.

The government's minimalist approach to the protection of intellectual property has meant that Australia has continued to fall behind our Asian and OECD counterparts. As Mr Tom Forgan, the founder of Australian Technology Park, observed in an interview with the Australian last July:
The question is, if the government puts $4.5 billion into research and development each year, what have we got to show for it?
He continued:
No one is actually making any products—it's a waste of time and money. We're selling the technology for nothing and we can't afford to keep funding research that we lose the benefit of.

While most overseas nations recognise and protect patents on pharmaceutical products for up to 15 years, Australia has lagged way behind. We are yet to hear whether the coalition government plans to bring our `intellectual property regime' into line with current international standards.

BREAK.PARA: It has been argued that Australia wants stability in an increasingly chaotic world. As a result venture capital, a key ingredient of the success of American research and development, is missing in Australia. Australian governments and capital markets have been reluctant to take the necessary gamble when it comes to most R&D projects. In those cases where the risk has been taken and the research successfully marketed, insufficient property rights have seen Australian firms lose their patents to aggressive overseas players.

The key to success for technology firms is the getting of, and the marketing of, information speedily. But the protection of intellectual property is equally as important. Without the protection of property rights, companies do not have the time to reap the rewards of their research and development before the patent term lapses.

Why would any Australian business be interested in funding R&D in Australia under those terms? The earlier mentioned examples of companies researching cures for cancer and the flu show that they do not. They merely move offshore. The current government has to start looking at the bigger picture. It must review its policies towards research and development and patents immediately, otherwise it is probable that Australia will feature even more poorly in this year's world competitiveness year book.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne, Chris, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words in support of a vital Australian industry that has under trying conditions served its sentence, rehabilitated itself, improved and re-educated itself, but is sadly still under threat of yet further punishment.

SPEECH.PARA: If Australia's car manufacturers drew up Christmas wish lists last year, those lists certainly would not have included the majority draft report of the Industry Commission on the automotive industry. The majority report recommended an annual reduction in tariffs of 2.5 per cent after the 15 per cent level is achieved in the year 2000, thereby reducing them to 5 per cent in 2005. The dissenting opinion written by associate commissioner Ian Webber calls for tariffs to remain steady at 15 per cent until 2005 and a further reassessment down the road before deciding on arrangements post-2005.

Of the two conflicting recommendations, the latter is eminently the more palatable choice for my state of South Australia and also for Victoria which are home to the bulk of the car assembly and ancillary industries. In 1988 the tariff on imported vehicles was 45 per cent. It is now down to 22.5 per cent and by the turn of the century it will have been reduced to 15 per cent. The local industry has responded by becoming more efficient and more export oriented and directly employs over 45,000 people, representing 4 per cent of the nation's manufacturing work force and 17 per cent of South Australia's. In the broader sense, 3.5 per cent of the Australian work force relies on the automotive industry for employment.

In accepting the Button plan, car manufacturers were promised micro and macro economic reform as an offset to the tariff reductions. In the area of tax reform, the performance of federal and state governments has been disappointing, to say the least. For a number of years, business, labour, welfare organisations and politicians of all stripes have been calling on governments to alter the crippling tax structure and I cannot remember a state government coming to power without promising some form of tax reform. Yet all too often the reforms have not been forthcoming and the federal government gets the blame because it will not promise to deliver the shortfall to states' coffers. The time for buck-passing is long gone.

The coalition tried and failed to initiate tax reform at the 1993 federal election, but that failure says a lot more about the desirability of consensus than it does about the undesirability of tax reform. We know how difficult it is to achieve consensus when ambition of party holds sway over the national interest and commitment to necessary reform. Experience tells us it is far easier to divide the people than it is to unite them. Now that Paul Keating—who had all the divisive skills of Solomon, but none of the wisdom—has moved on, it is the time for federal, state and local governments to sit down with business and labour to thrash out meaningful reform to Australia's tax base. The bandaid approach to taxation has failed us time and again. The system has become more complicated and open to abuse.

Wholesale sales taxes and others such as FID and BAD—and what a superb acronym that is for an inappropriate tax—as well as income and company tax, should be reviewed with all of the possibilities put on the table for consideration. Let us finally look at ending payroll tax. It is incomprehensible to me how any government can justify Australian corporations paying taxes on the people they employ when lack of jobs is such a devastating national problem.

The federal government should realise that one of the most costly business inputs for car makers is tax. If the automotive industry is expected to compete in a less protected world, then it is up to the government to dramatically ease that adjustment by changing the current tax system. Without tax reform, lowering of tariffs will not be a means to an end, but become an end in itself. Taxes alone are not the only problem. Reforms are needed in many areas and I am pleased to see that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) has set his sights on the wharves after achieving significant change in the labour market. Reforming the waterfront will certainly assist with exports, but a vibrant domestic market is the key prerequisite for a continued and expanded investment and presence of car manufacturers in Australia.

Australians drive a fleet of vehicles older than that of most western nations. This may be due somewhat to our benign climate, but more so to the cost of our vehicles. Government must assist local manufacturers in bringing down those costs to make new cars more affordable. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry believes that full account should be taken of the economic, strategic and social impacts of any further tariff reductions. While they support the continuing removal of tariff barriers, they too argue that reductions be part of a wider reform package.

BREAK.PARA: The improvement in efficiency and quality of the Australian product has resulted in a more outward looking industry. However, that pioneering spirit is in danger of being stymied by trade barriers that prevent maximising overseas sales. A level playing field in terms of trade is an admirable aim and international accords are leading every nation in that direction. But there are certainly no prizes for being the first nation to cross the finishing line and our haste to get there will hardly influence any other nation to follow suit as swiftly.

There are some protectionists left in Australia today, but I am certainly not one of them. l oppose the tools of protection, including tariffs, in the belief that our nation should become more productive and more competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, you are. We know. You can come out of the closet now.

—And one of the protectionists is still sitting on the front benches of the opposition. But reform in the automotive industry should not and cannot be a one‐way street. Government therefore must send a signal that we support the automotive industry.

BREAK.PARA: As someone who has witnessed my state hit rock bottom because of the mismanagement of successive Labor state governments, I will not compound the problem by jeopardising the jobs of another 17,000 South Australians and 24,000 Victorians by supporting the recommendations of the majority report. We regularly hear about the need to attract new business and to develop new technologies and state governments compete with each other to provide homes for emerging commercial ventures. This is well and good, but let us not ignore that which we already have.

Politicians are constantly reminded by the campaign professionals that we must protect our base. In the same way, we must continue to protect our existing industrial base, as well as seeking out those new avenues of opportunity. Prior to Christmas I wrote to all coalition members and senators from South Australia and Victoria suggesting a united approach to the framing of the government response. I am pleased to say that I have re ceived favourable replies from most of my colleagues on this issue. As elected government representatives of those who will be most adversely affected by the adoption of the recommendations contained in the majority report, it is our responsibility to ensure that the government implements policy that will allow and encourage the future prosperity of this vital segment of Australian manufacturing.

While we must of course wait on the commission for its final report, our constituents have not been as patient. They remind us every day of the dire consequences for the industry, for their jobs and for ours should the automotive industry go under. The coalition was elected on the promise of a better deal for regional areas and industries. There are few, if any, regional industries as important to both local and wider communities as our motor vehicle industry. South Australia under Labor suffered an exodus of manufacturing. Holden and Mitsubishi are still there and we must ensure they stay.

The South Australian Centre for Economic Studies believes the Industry Commission erred badly in underestimating the importance of the car industry to South Australia. Contrary to the Industry Commission, the centre found that South Australia actually loses from tariff reductions. If tariffs are cut to 5 per cent, the centre calculates that there would be a reduction in my state's GSP of 0.18 percent. It might sound minuscule, but that translates to around $60 million and about 2,500 jobs. That is only the minimum case scenario. Incidentally, the centre is not recommending a halt to tariff cuts either, but merely pointing out the need for accompanying measures to adequately compensate for the tighter regime.

Now that we are making cars of which we can truly be proud, it would be tragically ironic if this vital industry were to disappear because of a blind commitment to dogma found in some text book. Should the final majority report echo the sentiments of the draft, South Australians and Victorians should know that I will be firm in my resolve to support the automotive and ancillary industries that would be affected by that report. I am determined that the automotive industry and the jobs of many thousands of Australians will not be sacrificed at the altar of ideology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In May last year the new government within weeks of taking office announced that, rather than proceed with the development of a second airport for Sydney at Badgerys Creek, it would also examine the possible location of the airport at Holsworthy. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) indicated that this was simply as a means of insurance because of the EIS process that was going ahead with respect to Badgerys Creek and that, in order to ensure that there would be a location for the new airport for Sydney, there needed to be a fall-back option.

SPEECH.PARA: Consequently the government decided to hold an EIS into the Holsworthy option as well. We were told time and time again by the minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that nothing sinister had occurred. The government was simply making sure that it did not have all its eggs in one basket and that there was another option available to it with respect to the location of the airport.

At the time the opposition indicated that its view was that the government's decision indicated very clearly that it intended to build Sydney's second airport at Holsworthy for a number of reasons: primarily because it would be cheaper, because the land involved was already Commonwealth owned whereas there was substantial land acquisition already occurring at Badgerys Creek; and because it was closer to existing substantial road and rail infrastructure. The fact that there are one or two marginal Liberal held seats around Badgerys Creek did not escape the opposition's notice either.

The government kept insisting in spite of these suggestions that Holsworthy was simply a fall-back and that Badgerys Creek was the preferred location for the second airport for Sydney. As the days passed the true evidence of how crazy the suggestion of siting an airport at Holsworthy actually is started to emerge. Some things were obvious immedi ately. The fact that there is a vast amount of unexploded ordnance throughout the Holsworthy area as a result of its having been used as an army bombing range for a very long time was well known. The fact that much of terrain, particularly in the southern area, is full of very deep ravines that will make any form of construction of an airport extremely difficult was already well known. Then other facts began to emerge: the existence of many Aboriginal sacred sites in the area; a number of rare fauna species, endangered species and other things like a very substantial koala colony that would be threatened by the airport development; the existence of the Woronora Dam and catchment area immediately adjacent to the proposed airport site; the presence of the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor nearby; the fact that the proposed Olympic Games shooting range was at one end of where the airport would be located; the obvious presence of Defence facilities that would have to be relocated; the fact that Bankstown airport, the busiest airport in Australia, would almost certainly have to close down because of flight path complications; and other issues such as the fact that one of the world's premier hang gliding locations at Stanwell Tops would have to close because of flight path complications if the southern option for the Holsworthy airport was adopted. Of course, on top of all of these issues there is the very obvious impact on people living in the southern suburbs of Sydney immediately adjacent to the Holsworthy area.

Throughout this fiasco Labor consistently stated its strong opposition to any airport being located at Holsworthy. Holsworthy is in effect the lungs of Sydney and has been very aptly described as the lungs of Sydney. When you look at the map of Sydney you will see this substantial green area sticking well into the main developed built‐up area of Sydney. That is Holsworthy and the opposition believes that that is how it should stay.

Community reaction to the proposal has been unbelievable. I have spoken to numerous local groups, councils and representatives of councils. I have driven around the area. I have flown over the Holsworthy area in a helicop ter and received a vast number of letters from concerned residents in the Holsworthy region. I am sure that the government and the EIS process have received even more. I think it has gone well into the thousands. The honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) submitted a petition to the House several months ago and he almost needed a truck to carry it in because it was so large.

The government deceit in this whole process has been absolutely monstrous. First the fact that within weeks of an election and after an election it indicated that it is considering building an airport at a site when it said absolutely nothing about this proposal prior to the election and won the seat of Hughes partly as a result. It is clear absolutely deceit. Secondly, people were buying land from the Defence Housing Authority within days of the government's announcement and asking the Defence Housing Authority and various other authorities, `Is there any truth in the rumour that an airport is going to be built here?' They were being told, `No', but when they then proceeded with their contracts they got the shock of their lives to discover that yes, the government was contemplating building an airport at Holsworthy. They were then told when they complained, `Sorry, we could not tell the Defence Housing Authority because that would have given it a commercial advantage against people it competes with in the housing market. Sorry, bad luck. The fact that you have bought a piece of land that is going to be substantially devalued as a result of what we are doing is just by the by.'

Over the weekend, an even more outrageous piece of deceit—and the final illustration of what this government has been on about—was uncovered. It was in a memo from an adviser to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) to the minister, in which he details a discussion he had with Mr Lachlan McComish, who is an adviser to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp). This discussion occurred in June last year. Yesterday, in the House, the minister for science confirmed the existence and authenticity of this document.

A couple of quotes from the document should suffice to illustrate precisely how mendacious, deceitful and duplicitous the government has been on this issue. Remember, this discussion took place in June last year, within weeks of the minister having told the House repeatedly that Holsworthy was simply a fall‐back position, a form of insurance, and that Badgerys Creek was the real option. The document says:
Lachlan made it clear that Badgerys Creek was dead as a viable option for the airport.
It continues:
He believes that Holsworthy will be selected as the preferred site, subject to a satisfactory outcome of the EIS.

He then says that this makes it `impossible' for the nuclear reactor to continue at Lucas Heights, or for a replacement reactor to be built there. The document indicates that money from the sale of Badgerys Creek land and from Bankstown airport could be made available to help pay for the airport at Holsworthy and, more to the point, that removing the nuclear reactor from Lucas Heights `may partly negate the negative impact of the new airport'.

According to this document there is a financial pay‐off and a political pay‐off. The reason specified as to why the government was abandoning Badgerys Creek was the growth of residential housing in the vicinity of Badgerys Creek. What it failed to point out—and it is well known, particularly to people who live there—is that there is a substantial amount of residential housing within a couple of kilometres of the runway locations proposed for Holsworthy, so the deceit and the hypocrisy is absolutely naked.

The memo tells us precisely how deceitful and duplicitous this government has been on the second Sydney airport issue. Holsworthy has been its real option all along. Badgerys Creek was abandoned from day one. The EIS process purportedly comparing the two is clearly a farce. The senior adviser to the minister for transport is on the record within the processes of the government, in a document which has been accepted as authentic by a fellow minister, stating that Badgerys Creek is dead—and that was within weeks of the Holsworthy proposal being announced. And yet, to this day, the chimera is maintained. The government says, `Holsworthy is just the fall‐back position.'

The government ought to come clean. It ought to state what its true intention is. The minister ought to explain to the House why his senior staffer was telling other government officials, within weeks of the Holsworthy announcement, that that was the government's preferred option, if that is not the case.

The minister has a lot of explaining to do, not only to the House but also particularly to the people of Holsworthy and the suburbs in the southern area of Sydney. He has to provide answers to the concerns of residents on the impact of that airport. He has to provide answers on the numerous environmental issues associated with the construction of an airport at Holsworthy.

He has to explain, in particular, his outrageous and duplicitous behaviour, both in the House and outside it, in maintaining that an airport is going to built at Badgerys Creek, and that only if the EIS process is unsuccessful there will Holsworthy be considered, when this document makes it abundantly clear that from day one the real agenda of this government was to build an airport at Holsworthy.

The Labor Party believes that Holsworthy is a ridiculous site for an airport. The more I look at it, the more I wonder why it was even on the short‐list of 10 that was considered by the former government 10 or 12 years ago, let alone the primary target for an airport. This government should stop trying to deceive the people of Sydney. It should stop its outrageous, duplicitous behaviour, come clean on precisely what it intends to do, and take proper account of the communities, through consultation with local residents and associated groups, and work through the issues. It should deal honestly with the issue of a second airport for Sydney. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to grieve for the oyster industry in New South Wales and, particularly, for the Wallis Lake oyster industry in my electorate, which is based on Wallis Lake at Forster‐Tuncurry. Unfortunately, the industry has been hit by disaster in recent times with the outbreak of hepatitis A, with about 300‐odd cases around Australia. Allegedly, 70 per cent of those cases have been traced to oysters, some of which came from Wallis Lake.

SPEECH.PARA: The worst thing about trying to address the problem has been the unbelievable comments made along the way by the Minister for the Environment in New South Wales, Ms Pam Allan. To date she has not been prepared to admit that she was wrong in some of the statements she made, nor has she apologised to the people of the Great Lakes area, based in Forster‐Tuncurry, for the damage that some of her comments have caused during a very difficult time.

Those people have been trying to manage, along with the local council, the local member, the New South Wales Department of Health and the EPA. While preparing for the grievance debate this afternoon, we were listening to the news in the office, and we heard that, only this morning, the Premier of New South Wales announced a package of measures to assist in the crisis in the Wallis Lake area. Those measures include an oyster quality assurance program, a financial assistance package, and criteria that will be used for future oyster harvesting, through which the health department will make the final determination on the basis of present scientific evidence.

On a number of recent occasions, contrary to the comments made by the environment minister in New South Wales, the health department has said that there is no suggestion that the risk associated with swimming in Wallis Lake is greater than anywhere else. It has cleared Wallis Lake for swimming, yet that is exactly the opposite to what the Minister for the Environment in New South Wales said earlier this month.

She has not apologised to the people in the area for the comments she has made, and now the Premier of New South Wales has had to rectify the situation on behalf of his government, albeit a little late when you look at the time frame. On 14 February, the hepatitis outbreak was announced. On 24 February, a man died from the virus, allegedly from contaminated oysters taken from Wallis Lake. In New South Wales, 300 cases of hepatitis A have been notified since January 1991. Allegedly, 70 per cent of those cases are from oysters, one third of which are identified as coming from Wallis Lake.

On 25 February, Pam Allan attacked the council. She claimed that the Great Lakes Shire Council was guilty of gross negligence by failing to comply with an EPA order from last November to close down two sanitary depots. At the same time, Pam Allan declared Wallis Lake a non‐swimming zone. In yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, in an article headed `Minister stands firm after oyster poisoning bungle', the lead paragraph says:

The Minister for the Environment, Ms Allan, was forced yesterday into an embarrassing admission she wrongly accused a mid‐North Coast council of triggering a hepatitis A outbreak by ignoring a State Government order to clean up two sanitary depots.

She still will not apologise to the local community. On 28 February, a preliminary EPA report ruled out the depots as the source of the outbreak. Her own department has ruled them out and proven her comments wrong, but the minister will not apologise to the people of the Great Lakes area.

Today, the Premier tried to prop up the situation and defend his minister, who has been negligent and irresponsible in the comments she has made about Wallis Lake. She claimed that there was a swimming ban on Wallis Lake and that signs would be erected to warn swimmers, and yet the council has had no such instructions from any minister, and the lake has never been closed.

As Great Lakes Mayor, Councillor John Chadban, said on 28 February in the Sydney Morning Herald, we expect professional help from the government rather than random criticism. This was a very serious situation which required a professional attitude from the state government. It has not received it. I commend the work done by the local council during this crisis, particularly that done by Councillor John Chadban. They have been very professional in the way they have gone about it.

The oyster farmers have acted responsibly. I applaud the local oyster growers for their responsible actions in voluntarily withdrawing product from the market and closing down their fisheries until the crisis is resolved. They took that action immediately. I hope the state government will now provide meaningful assistance.

I welcome the announcement by the Premier of New South Wales to assist the community and the industry in resolving the problem that has unfortunately arisen at Wallis Lake. There are two issues here. There is the issue of the alleged contamination of the oysters and what that cost is: the Wallis Lake oyster industry is worth $13 million. There is that element. There is the health element: some 300 people across Australia have been affected by the outbreak of hepatitis A; and there has been one fatality—and that is extremely sad.

We have a $13 million industry, an outbreak of hepatitis A, one fatality, a $35 million flow‐on effect to the local economy, 250 local jobs in the oyster industry, and a tourist industry worth tens of millions of dollars to the region. That industry has been affected by the irresponsible public comments of the Minister for the Environment in New South Wales about the closure of the lake to swimming.

The New South Wales health department has advised that all activities, including swimming and water skiing, are permitted within Wallis Lake and tributaries. The only qualification is that, within the Wallamba River, caution should be exercised during periods of heavy rain. That is the view of the New South Wales Department of Health.

It is incumbent upon the media in this country to make it abundantly clear to the general population that that is the view of the New South Wales health department as far as Wallis Lake is concerned. The media in this country ran this issue very hard, and it has been very damaging to the local community. The media has a responsibility to get that message across.

The New South Wales health department has said that there are no restrictions on Wallis Lake as far as water sports and activities in the lake are concerned. It is very important to get that message across in the lead‐up to the Easter break. The communities in Forster and Tuncurry rely heavily on the oyster industry, the fishing industry and the tourism industry. That has not been taken into account. I give marks to Premier Carr. He has taken it into account in his response, although it could have come a bit sooner. However, I still criticise the Minister for the Environment, who will not acknowledge the profound effect that her irresponsible comments had earlier this month in regard to the alleged closure of the lake. It did not happen.

A survey of 100 seafood retailers in New South Wales was undertaken by the Master Fish Merchants Association. Following this disaster in Wallis Lake there is evidence of a 30 per cent drop in seafood sales and an 85 per cent drop in oyster sales, which may have resulted in a loss through the restaurant trade of $15 million to $20 million. This is all within New South Wales. Thankfully, the Premier has recognised it.

The allegations are that the contamination has come from effluent treatment plants. In the 1980s I was involved in the Greater Taree City Council, and in the mid‐1980s the Labor Party was in government in New South Wales. When we tried to augment sewage treatment schemes by implementing dry land disposal, the engineers with the Department of Public Works in New South Wales and the Department of Public Works itself—and this was when Bob Carr was the Minister for the Environment—would not allow local government to take that effluent out of the rivers, the tributaries and estuaries, and dispose of it on dry land, because they were philosophically opposed to it. They would not consider any option other than dumping that effluent into the tributaries. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir
It gives me great pleasure to write to you regarding the help and assistance given to me by AQIS Staff, particularly Garry Garreffa and Geoff Wood, in Perth.

DR J D McDERMOTT

Country Furniture; companies that are exporting and increasing their production. SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Andrea, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House the recent flagging by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) of the possibility of new inservice training for teachers. Inservice training has always been an important and integral part of ongoing quality assurance in the teaching profession. Speaking as a former teacher, I can only concur and support this consideration as the benefits are considerable for everyone involved in teaching and learning.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, may I recommend that those recently retired teachers in the 50 to 60 age bracket be engaged to lend their considerable years of experience and expertise to this very exercise of assisting current teachers in literacy and numeracy skill development. These recently retired teachers have a vast range of teaching strategies that were successful in the classroom and they overcame many difficulties and learning disabilities associated with teaching children to read and understand the written word.

Over recent years, with changing emphasises within the whole school environment, most teachers have been taken away from their primary role of learning facilitator to deal with a wide range of non-teaching duties. —My question is to the Prime Minister. First, can the Prime Minister assure the House that the reasonable alternatives the government has offered Sir Julius Chan are conditional on an absolute commitment from the Papua New Guinea government to revive the Bougainville peace process—not just a commitment in words but a commitment to concrete measures designed to get all parties to the Bougainville conflict back to the negotiating table? Second, given the growing problem with mercenaries worldwide—as instanced by today's reports of horrific atrocities in Zaire—will the government take up our proposal for Australia to sponsor a UN resolution calling on the international community to condemn all use of mercenaries and strengthen global efforts to eliminate the use of these forces?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for the question. In answer to the second part of his question, can I say that I will have a look at that. I share his distaste for the use of mercenaries. They have been a wholly sordid and unsatisfactory development in our part of the world. Can I say that the indication at present that the mercenaries may in part at least be starting to withdraw from Papua New Guinea is something that I very warmly welcome. I am sure all members of the House join me in expressing that welcome.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as the first part of the question is concerned, can I assure the Leader of the Opposition that the reasonable alternatives I put to Sir Julius Chan last Sunday week were based upon three elements. The first element was that the mercenaries not be used in Bougainville, the second element was the disavowal of a new military offensive in Bougainville and the third element was a genuine commitment to a resumption of the peace process. So in general terms, I can answer in the affirmative to the Leader of the Opposition's question. I am sure he and his colleagues will understand that it is not really in the interests of a further satisfactory progressing of this issue for me to be any more specific.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen the latest Westpac‐Melbourne Institute leading index of economic activity? Does the index support the view that economic activity will continue to strengthen, resulting in an improving environment for business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Boothby for his question. I can inform him that the index does support the view that economic activity will continue to strengthen, resulting in an improving environment for business.

ANSWER.PARA: The Westpac‐Melbourne Institute leading index of economic activity rose one per cent in January, reinforcing an upward trend in the previous three months and bringing the smooth growth rate to around four per cent, the strongest rate of growth since October 1994. Of course, in October 1994 monetary policy was tightened at that period.

The leading index is a function of a range of other indicators that feed into it which are beginning to show a picture of rising activity. For example, building approvals and housing finance approvals both increased markedly in January and there was strong growth in corporate profits. In addition, recent business surveys are suggesting increases in overtime.

These are also consistent with the release this morning of the DEETYA skilled vacancy survey for February. This showed that skilled vacancies have risen in trend terms for the last five months and are now 11 per cent above the level of October 1996. They can be taken together with other leading indicators.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do they relate to March 1996?

—I know the Labor Party, from their increasingly volatile interjections, love to see the Australian economy picking up! Nothing seems to ruin their day more than the Australian economy picking up pace. ANZ job vacancies were up 1.8 per cent in February. As I said also, the other leading indicators are increased building approvals, household finance approvals and retail trade.

ANSWER.PARA: I said that the leading index is the strongest since October 1994 which brought a monetary policy response at the end. I have also said previously that was not without its benefits in relation to keeping inflation under control.

The good thing about this pick‐up in activity is that it is on a very low inflation base. The other good thing about it is that in the last year we have accomplished an enormous structural change—a structural change in the Commonwealth fiscal position of $7.2 billion. So we come in to this pick‐up in activity not just preserving low inflation but with a structural change in relation to fiscal consolidation of $7.2 billion by this government.

I regret that the Australian Labor Party fought it tooth and nail. The Australian Labor Party, with fiscal irresponsibility unseen in Australia in recent times, fought that fiscal consolidation. This government was pleased to put it in place. The structural change which we accomplished was at a time of low inflation and increasing economic growth, a matter which should be welcomed by both sides of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. I am happy to let him wallow in the glory of getting the economy back almost to where it was last March. Has the Treasurer seen the report that he will at tomorrow's Premiers Conference propose a new wholesale sales tax regime to be applied to many state, territory and local government functions? Does he agree that such a proposal would be yet another breach of the government's commitment not to increase existing taxes or impose new taxes? Will the Treasurer rule out imposing this new tax on other levels of government? And while he is about it, will he also rule out any further cuts to specific purpose payments to the states?
—I have not seen such a report. I have no idea what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is on about, and, I suspect, nor does he.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Is the minister aware of reports in today's media regarding plans by the government to cancel the payroll deduction of union dues in the Australian Public Service if unions act unreasonably in the workplace? Can the minister clarify for the benefit of the House the government's initiative on payroll deduction of union dues in the Public Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. As I think most honourable members would be aware, one of the most important aspects of the Workplace Relations Act is that, under part 10, we have provided for the first time an absolute guarantee for Australian workers that they have absolute freedom of choice as to whether or not they are a member of a union, so much so that we have preserved one of the items proscribed under the act in respect of unlawful termination. You cannot victimise a person because they are a member of a union. In fact, we have increased penalties against employers who victimise somebody because they exercise that choice to be a member of a union.

ANSWER.PARA: The great debate in Australia is that those on the other side of the House do not believe that people should also have the right not to be a member of a union if that is their desire. One of the great things is that, under the Workplace Relations Act, we have abolished compulsory unionism in this country. There is no safe haven for compulsory unionism either within the state or federal jurisdictions across the country.

The government, when it comes to the Australian Public Service, acts not just as a legislator but as an employer. We simply want to reinforce the provisions of the new act which came into operation on 1 January. We want to be satisfied that those members who have chosen to be members of a union within the Australian Public Service have provided us with a current and genuine authority that they wish their union dues to continue to be deducted.

The system will be that we are writing to people within the APS. I have informed the unions. I spoke with them a couple of weeks ago about the policy and advised them of it. We are seeking from APS members a genuine, current, fresh authority from them to that effect. If that is what people wish to do, then, consistent with that principle of freedom of association, we are prepared to collect those union dues.

We also say, as has been the case since the day we were elected, that this is a discretion ultimately in the hands of the government. We welcome and support responsible unionism where that is the choice of members. Where people are acting irresponsibly, then of course that is a discretion—namely, the capacity to collect those dues and pass them on—which we reserve unto the government. We think that is fair and reasonable.

We believe that where people want to be in a union that is fair enough. We are prepared to talk with the unions who are genuinely representing the interests of their members. Most members of the APS who are in unions will see this as a very fair decision on the part of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government representing the Minister for the Environment. I refer to reports that National Party MPs have been telling the media and the tourism industry in North Queensland that the Howard government's tourism visitor tax—the second instalment of the reef tax announced by Senator Hill—will be too difficult for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to collect and, as a result, the government will not proceed with it. TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the reports, but we have had the debate in this chamber about the Great Barrier Reef charge. It was varied after detailed discussion with members and the industry. It built on the charge that the former government put in place, so I am a little surprised that the member rose to ask that question. We are putting in place a system for contribution by visitors to meet the cost of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park arrangements. There have been no reports that I have seen to date that indicate there will be any change in the government's approach.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, a very dedicated and hardworking minister. I draw the minister's attention to the government's commitment to provide the most effective possible assistance to unemployed people. Can the minister outline to the House what actions the government is taking in my electorate of Robertson and throughout Australia to reform employment placement services and how these reforms will assist schools and ensure that school leavers will get real jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Robertson for his question. The government is involved in very major reforms to help unemployed people at the present time. Yesterday the work for the dole legislation was introduced into the parliament. Of course all sides of this House will be aware of the enormous public support that there is for this legislation.

BREAK.PARA: In the next three months the government will be embarking on an historic reform of services for unemployed people. One billion dollars worth of services currently provided by the Commonwealth Employment Service will be tendered out. This will have significance for around 500,000 clients of the Commonwealth Employment Service. The tender is expected to close at the end of May. Contracts will be signed around September.

This is one of the most significant social reforms that this country has seen for many years. The new system, which we believe will be a much more effective system for helping unemployed people, will be in place by the end of the year.
Mr Crean interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great deal better than you were able to do in 13 years, when you had unemployment at the highest level since the Great Depression. It is worth making the point that there is an enormous contrast between this government's clarity of purpose and determination to help unemployed people and the utter confusion which prevails on the other side of the House. We saw that in respect of work for the dole. First they opposed it, then the Leader of the Opposition said that they would amend it to blazes, then they said they would support it, and then the member for Hotham said that they had had one any way so it did not make any difference. They simply cannot get their act together.

BREAK.PARA: Now we have the member for Batman, on the employment services reforms, saying that they disagree with these reforms because they would like to have completely unlimited access to these services. Of course, that is a very different position from the position they took in government. It is not surprising, of course, that it is a different position because they seem to have a different position on everything that they took in government. They do not seem to be able to sustain any position.

It is not that they did not have any trouble spending money. The Two Billion Dollar Man over there, the member for Hotham, had no difficulty spending great wads of money. But the member for Batman, the clone sitting down there, is going to do much better. The member for Hotham lost only 200,000 union members; the member for Batman lost 600,000. You spent $2 billion; he wants to spend about $6 billion. It is no wonder that the Australian—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the money coming from?

—It is coming out of the pockets of battling families. That is where the money is coming from. It is obvious that the member for Hotham is having a very bad effect on the member for Batman. This cloning process is going on and on. We have Woolly Head here, and Dolly down there. They are clones, and they do not seem to be able to get any sense of direction whatever.
—Minister, please direct your remarks through the chair.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: there is absolutely no point on relevance as far as this is concerned. This man in his position has presided over a 40,000 increase in the long-term unemployed—
—You are not going to debate this.
—As a result of getting rid of the member for Hotham's programs. That is what he has done and he is proud of it.
—Order! There is no point of order. Resume your seat.

—The government's reforms are of particular interest to schools because they provide the opportunity for schools to take a much more direct interest in the employment prospects of their students. I am very pleased to say that, under the jobs pathway program, Marsden High and Acacia Ridge High in Queensland are already successful tenderers.
—And one of them is in my electorate.

—Indeed, there is a school in the Prime Minister's electorate which is very much interested in these opportunities. In the new round, schools could tender to provide labour exchange services and entry level training services, and there will be something like $75 million available for which schools can tender. As schools gain this increasing interest, we are going to see put into place yet another step in the comprehensive approach the government is putting in place to help young Australians get real jobs.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment. I ask the minister whether he is aware the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has offered inducements to tourism operators in Queensland to collect the Howard government's new visitors tax when implemented in 1998. Has the government authorised this action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen any reports and do not have any information about whether or not the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has acted in the way that you suggest. But it is quite clear that government policy is that there will be a collection of a charge to meet the costs of visitation to the Great Barrier Reef.

ANSWER.PARA: That has been accepted by a majority in this place. It is government policy. It builds on, as I said in the last answer, the decision that you took to have a charge. I might say that the member for Cunningham was involved in the committee report that recommended in part that there be such a charge. It is fair. It is equitable. There have been detailed consultations with the industry and with members about the appropriateness of the charge and how it should be proceeded with.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of the fact that tampons that do not comply with Therapeutic Goods Order 51 are still being sold today, some 14 months after the final date of compliance with Therapeutics Goods Order 51, which, among other things, requires all primary packaging of tampons to be clearly marked with a warning that toxic shock syndrome is a rare but serious disease that may cause death? What efforts is the government taking to remind retailers of their responsibility to conform with TGO51, and what action is available to the government against those retailers who refuse to comply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Yes, I am aware of the situation, and I thank the member for Leichhardt for alerting both me and the Therapeutic Goods Authority to it. There has been quite a deal of interest in toxic shock, and it principally relates to the third inquest into the death of a 13-year-old Mount Isa girl who died in a swimming pool in December 1994. That inquest has just concluded, and it is not proper for me to discuss that at this point in time.

ANSWER.PARA: However, Australia manufactures or imports some 400 million tampons a year. Tampons are required to be very clean, but they are not required to be sterile. As far as I know, no country in the world, other than Japan, requires sterile tampons, and Japan only does it for imports which might have an intent other than simply safety.

Toxic shock syndrome, as the honourable member said, is very rare. Its occurrence is probably fewer than one in five million women. Nonetheless, it does happen and it does have nasty consequences. Even though tampons are very safe, women do have the right to have informed consent. That is why Therapeutic Goods Order 51 was introduced by the previous government in 1995, and it was something that I, when shadow minister, supported.

We were expecting there to be a bit of a changeover time of two to three months between the old tampon boxes, which had no warning, and the new boxes, but the honourable member found, on visiting a number of supermarkets in North Queensland, that there were, in a number of cases, tampons with the old box numbers. We were able to trace these. I find it disturbing that tampons manufactured in October 1993 are being sold in North Queensland in January 1997. That clearly reflects bad stock turnover and stock control. I would not want to suggest that these tampons are in any way dangerous. There is no evidence of that but, again, women do have a right to have informed consent and be aware of the small risk.

At a federal level, the Therapeutic Goods Authority controls tampons and has done since 1991, but it only controls their manufac ture. Australia has one large manufacturer—Johnson & Johnson—which has about 60 per cent of the market. They have a national sales network which ensured, in early 1996, that there was no product left on the shelves. But smaller companies do not have a national sales network and cannot institute that measure.

The Commonwealth does not control wholesaling and retailing; the states do.
