I am afraid that we do not have capacity to do anything there, but I will write to all state and territory health ministers and alert them to the fact that, clearly, in some parts of Australia there is poor stock control and product over three years since the date of manufacture appearing on the shelves. I will ask that they use what power they have to ensure that this does not continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, is the decision to redefine real jobs an admission that the government is finding it too hard to kick goals on the employment field? Why is the government shifting the goal posts? Is it the case that a person working 20 hours a week is regarded by the Howard government as a full‐time worker? Why has the government defined part‐time workers as full‐time workers? Why has the government fiddled the figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a bad question from the greatest kicker of own goals, the man pledged to lead the trade union movement of Australia, who, together with the then Labor government, created the circumstances that drove over 11 per cent of the Australian population out of work—the worst since the Great Depression. That was the own goal you kicked—and you helped your former government colleagues to kick—when you, as head of the ACTU, and the then Labor government ran the affairs of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: My advice is that the legislation to which the honourable gentleman refers does not redefine what is regarded as a part‐or full‐time job. It merely spells out the benchmark in terms of obtaining employment options that must be reached before certain payments become payable.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The minister would be aware that accidents in the home, particularly burns and falls, are becoming far too common as the veterans community ages. As many of these accidents are preventable, will the minister take steps to address this problem and assist veterans and war widows to improve their health and quality of life?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Wide Bay for his interest in the veteran community. Accidents—particularly as the member for Wide Bay highlighted—burns and falls, poor nutrition and medication misuse do cause pain and suffering to our veteran community and our war widows in this nation. They can often lead to a lengthy stay in hospital. Anecdotal evidence suggests that preventative care visits to the home of the elderly, incorporating education, advice and referral to health professionals, often lead to an improvement in the health, wellbeing and independence of the veterans and the elderly in our community. That is, of course, an absolute priority of this government.

ANSWER.PARA: This government, and my portfolio in particular, will have an Australian first in this area. Incorporating research with the University of Newcastle, it will trial home based preventative care visits to the homes of veterans and war widows in metropolitan Australia and rural Australia in Queensland and New South Wales. The trial will involve approximately 1,500 veterans and war widows. I can advise the member for Wide Bay that these visits and trials are likely to include veterans and war widows in the cities of Maryborough and Hervey Bay, and in that lovely rural town, Gayndah, in his electorate.

The trials, I must stress, are voluntary. That is extremely important because we will also be selecting nurses from within the community who are specially trained to visit the homes of veterans and war widows. This is extremely important because they will be able to identify, where necessary, where some of the ills which befall our veteran community are able to be prevented. It is much better to prevent an accident by taking preventative action rather than waiting for it to happen.

This will create a stronger link between the doctor, the veteran and the community nurse. If we can prevent illness and injury to our veterans and war widows, we will make sure that they have better health and more independence. That is in the best interests of our veteran community. I will keep the House informed as to the results and the progress of the trials.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: World War II: Misappropriation of Money

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Recent evidence has shown that it was not only stolen Jewish gold that was misappropriated with the connivance of Swiss banks but also large amounts of money deposited in Swiss banks by the allies for prisoners of war was misappropriated by the Japanese and used in fact for their war effort. This money was deposited in the Swiss National Bank and with the connivance of the Yokohama Species Bank, now the Tokyo Mitsubishi Bank, was diverted to Japanese forces. Since it is likely that Australian money was involved in the ally deposits, does your government intend to pursue this matter and seek to recover this money? If not, why not?
—I will analyse the question.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice. Is it correct, as reported by Michael Millett in today's Sydney Morning Herald , that the government is looking at a radical proposal involving the amalgamation of a raft of merit review bodies including the Veterans' Review Board, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fisher for his question. It is in fact correct that the government is actively considering such an amalgamation. That amalgamation was recommended in the Better Decisions report of the Administrative Review Council. Cabinet has agreed in principle to amalgamate the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the Veterans' Review Board, the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal into a single tribunal which would be called the Administrative Review Tribunal.

ANSWER.PARA: The amalgamation contemplated would streamline administrative structures and enhance the operations of the tribunal system. It is envisaged that separate divisions of the proposed ART would develop and maintain flexible, cost effective and non‐legalistic procedures relevant to their jurisdictions. An interdepartmental committee comprising senior Commonwealth officers will devise a strategy for implementing the amalgamation. The basis and scope of administrative review designed to reduce the number of applications, the overall costs of merits review and excessive legalism will also be looked at. Detailed implementation of the recommendations for improvements to process and procedures of merits review tribunals contained in the Better Decisions report will also be considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I seek clarification of an aspect of the work for the dole bill and refer the Prime Minister to his minister's second reading speech yesterday when introducing the bill. Is it a fact that the wage rates for hours worked under the work for the dole scheme will be at the training award wage rate but that there will be no requirement for 20 per cent of the time to be spent in structured training? Does this not mean that workers will be required to work 100 per cent of the time but be paid only 80 per cent of the award rate?

—The purpose of the government's work for the dole scheme is to provide for the target group, which initially and overwhelmingly will be between the ages of 18 and 24, the opportunity to acquire some work skills in circumstances where nobody can possibly allege that those people are being exploited. I want to make it very clear that there is nothing in the legislation which in any way gives rise to charges, either direct or implied, that people are being exploited. The principle is that people are going to be properly remunerated for the time that they spend on the job. I regard that as being a proper working out of the principle of mutual obligation. The principle of mutual obligation is that we look after people who cannot get a job and it is only fair and reasonable that they do something in return.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I draw the minister's attention to an article in today's Australian in which Frank Devine says, `We need standardised testing if we are to end illiteracy.' I ask the minister: what is the progress to date of the implementation of national standardised testing for literacy? Is the minister aware of teacher opposition to the literacy testing program? Can the minister advise the reasoning behind the introduction of a national literacy test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for La Trobe for his question. No-one in the parliament, I venture to say, has done more to draw attention to the literacy needs of young people than the member for La Trobe.
—He chaired the committee.

—He chairs the House standing committee. Indeed, he is one of the authors of the minority report, brought down by that committee some four years ago, which drew attention to the need to test all young people in the early years of schooling in order to establish their literacy needs.

ANSWER.PARA: The historic agreement that I was able to reach with the states and territories last Friday for a national literacy and numeracy plan which specifically addresses the needs of young people in the early years of schooling can in many ways be seen as a culmination of the work that the member for La Trobe has been engaged in. I am ready before this House to acknowledge my indebtedness to him for his work.

A very key part of this plan is that all students should be tested against national standards or national benchmarks. We will know for the first time whether or not the policies that have been put in place to teach young people to read and write are in fact working and we will know where the greatest progress is being made in the states and territories around this country.

I have to say that it was deeply disappointing to read the remarks of the federal president of the Australian Education Union, who described this decision, which has been hailed, I think it is fair to say, around the country, as `one of the most disappointing decisions ever for quality education'. The Australian Education Union is, of course, the body which gave the Labor Party its education policy.

It is because the Labor Party has followed the dictates of the Australian Education Union and the teacher unions for 13 years that we have the current situation where 30 per cent of 14‐year‐olds cannot read properly. We have seen the opposition of the unions to the learning assessment program in Victoria, which has the overwhelming support of parents. We have seen the continuing opposition of the unions to testing in New South Wales, where the situation is in fact very little better than in Victoria and where the union has banned the basic skills tests.

This government is committed to providing Australian parents with the information they need to determine whether their children are gaining successful education and building up the skills that they need for life. It does teachers no service, it does parents no service and it certainly does children no service for the education unions of this country to stick their heads in the sand and try to keep parents and the community in the dark about the performance of Australia's schools.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, yesterday you quoted from my speech at the National Press Club on 14 August 1991, so you will not mind my quoting from a press conference you gave just six days earlier when you said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is my opinion that we will never in my lifetime . . . go below an unemployment level of five per cent.
Prime Minister, do you stand by your statement that a five per cent unemployment rate will not be achieved in your lifetime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no reason to doubt for a moment the veracity of what I said then. Let me repeat what I have said repeatedly since I became the Prime Minister of Australia. That is, I will do all in my power to implement policies to reduce the level of unemployment in this country, but I am not going to hitch myself to a particular target as Prime Minister. I have said that repeatedly, and I repeat it again.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to make it very plain on behalf of the government that we are absolutely committed to policies that will bring down unemployment, but we are not going to get ourselves attached to a target. While on the subject of employment, the member for Hotham invites me, because he goes back a little—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you went back.

—No, you went back first, so I am going to go back again. Perhaps the member for Hotham will remember giving an ABC interview on 4 February 1992 after the closure of a car plant which was located in the electorate of Hotham. He gave this interview on 4 February 1992. So in the context of the member for Hotham seeking my views on jobs, let me remind the House what the member for Hotham had to say, and it sits rather at odds with the crocodile tears he and his colleagues have been shedding in recent times about manufacturing industry in Australia. This is what he had to say:

ANSWER.PARA: Now, the Button car plan has done that for the automotive industry.
This is what he said to say:
It was always recognised that there were going to be job losses.
That is what he said. When he was a minister in the government, he was saying, `You've got to have job losses,' and now he is taking every little debating point he can. He said:

It was always recognised that there were going to be job losses. Whether it's closure of plants or job restructuring, there have been significant job losses in the automotive industry and that has been accepted as a necessary part of making the industry competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order, which goes to relevance. Is it relevant for the Prime Minister to point these out in relation to the question that was asked of him and not mention the fact that that same Button car plan produced a 400 per cent increase in exports?
—No, we are not going to debate the issue. There is no point of order. Resume your seat.
—It gets even better. On the World Today on 28 February 1991, this is what he had to say, and this is a real pearler:

ANSWER.PARA: I think that many in the media do not appreciate it that all tariffs did was to make us look inward. All the tariffs did was to protect local production. There was no basis upon which there was international competition to drive innovation.
The absolute core of the interview was when the interviewer said:
So you and Paul Keating are now at one on the direction of industry policy?

And he replied, `Yep.' So, can I say that over the last few days the Labor Party have been desperately trying to de‐Keatingise themselves. They have been trying to get rid of the ghost and here we have the arch hypocrite of the lot because he said `Yep,' when asked, `So you and Paul Keating are now at one on the direction of industry policy?'

I do not think the workers in the car industry in South Australia take any notice of you. You promised you would not privatise the Commonwealth Bank, and you did. You promised you would not privatise Qantas, and you did. You are promising something on manufacturing industry, and they are not even listening.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. The minister would be aware of the employment needs of Melbourne's outer eastern suburbs and that the decision to locate a one‐stop apprenticeship shop in Ringwood has been well received. Can the minister inform the people in my electorate of Deakin how the implementation of one‐stop shops is progressing and what effect they will have on the availability of traineeships and apprenticeships?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Deakin for his question and I acknowledge his very strong commitment to the young people in his electorate. The government is streamlining arrangements for apprenticeships and traineeships, and one of the most important initiatives in this regard has been the establishment of one‐stop apprenticeship and traineeship shops. Agreement has been reached by the government with all the states and territories to establish 18 demonstration projects which will combine Commonwealth and state entry level training functions.

ANSWER.PARA: Three projects have already commenced—in Cairns, in the Australian Capital Territory, and in Launceston—and the rest will be opening over the next month. I hope that I will be able to be present in the member's electorate to assist in opening the one‐stop shop in his electorate.

There will be four such shops in New South Wales, four in Victoria, three in Queensland, two in Western Australia, two in South Australia, two in Tasmania and one in the Australian Capital Territory. These shops are part of a very substantial simplification of the training system which the government is putting in place.

This has been necessary because of the extremely complex and bureaucratic nature of the system under the Labor Party. What we tragically saw under the previous government was an emphasis on short‐term training programs which did not lead on to real jobs and the lowest number of apprentices and trainees as a proportion of the work force for three decades. This government is determined to revive the apprenticeship system, to produce quality training for young Australians, and this initiative is a very important step in this direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen reports of yesterday's speech by South Australian Premier, John Olsen? Does he agree with the Premier's view that:

BREAK.PARA: If the Productivity Commission's program were accepted by Canberra the local automotive industry would not survive.
And another quote:
And I doubt the federal Liberal government would survive being the executioner of our automotive industry.
Prime Minister, will you be the executioner, or will you back Labor's plan to export Australia's cars rather than Australian jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Labor plan? The plan you had when you were in government or the plan you have when you are in opposition? Your problem on this—and it is your leader's problem on this and it is the problem that all of you have—is that the people who deserted you in March of last year deserted you because they no longer believed you. And they did not believe you because you promised things and then ratted on them after you got re‐elected.

ANSWER.PARA: You promised the Australian people that you would not privatise Qantas. You promised the Australian people that you would not privatise the Commonwealth Bank. Your former leader wrote a letter to the members of the Bank Employees Union promising across his heart and on a stack of bibles that you would not privatise the Commonwealth Bank—and what did you do when got re‐elected? You privatised the Commonwealth Bank. And it is burnt across the brain of every defected Labor supporter who voted for us in March that you were a group of people that could no longer be trusted.

Can I make it very clear to the House and to the people who are employed in the motor manufacturing industry in Australia that I have said repeatedly that this government remains strongly committed to the maintenance of a motor vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia. As to the response that we deliver to the recommendations of the Productivity Commission, I might gently point out to everybody who comments on this issue that we do not have the final recommendations of the Productivity Commission yet and, until we have the final recommendations of the Productivity Commission, we will not be amusing ourselves with the little games that are being played opposite.

BREAK.PARA: That is all you can do—you can play little games on this subject. When we get the report of the Productivity Commission, we will take a decision that is in the interests of all of the Australian people. We will naturally have regard to the interests of people who work in the motor manufacturing industry. We will not gloat about the impact of change, as you did when you were in government. We will not treat people as commodities to be shifted around, as you did when you were in government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Oh, you express indignation. Have you forgotten what happened to manufacturing employment when you ran Australia? Have you forgotten that in 13 years you drove unemployment to a post‐Depression high? Have you forgotten that it went over 11 per cent? Have you forgotten the devastation that your policies and those of Joan Kirner and John Bannon and Brian Burke caused to the economy not only of Australia but to the economies of Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia?

BREAK.PARA: You come into this House now and parade yourselves as the born‐again believers in the battlers of Australia. The truth is that you ratted on them, you deserted them, and that is why they threw you out.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education—excuse me—the Minister for Industrial Relations. Minister, you will recall participating in a recent workplace relations seminar in my electorate hosted by the Peninsula TAFE and the Monash University's Key Centre for Industrial Relations. What is the government doing to inform employees and employers of the new opportunities for better pay for better work, enhanced productivity and for improving the balance between work and home responsibilities under the Workplace Relations Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for his question. I am not sure whether I am elated or insulted—and that is no disrespect to my colleague the member for Goldstein. In fact, there is a lot of activity that the government is involved in in telling people about the Workplace Relations Act and the opportunities it provides to both employers and employees. The member for Dunkley and I were both at a seminar the other day, and there were a lot of people there—a lot of small business people. I know that the member himself is getting out and about in the community. He is fighting for small business people; he is getting the message out to people about the opportunities, particularly for small business, because we see tremendous opportunities for small business in this.

ANSWER.PARA: The government is doing its bit. The Australian workplace agreement being an individual agreement that you can have at work without a union and without the commission, which is fair to employees and good for business, is an historic change which we are keen to see. We have opened the Office of the Employment Advocate in the last week or so. There are advertisements in the national press.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the whole state.
—I warn the member for Brisbane.

—There is a hotline you can ring to obtain the information kit. That information kit contains information for employees and information for employers. There has been a huge response to it, Prime Minister. Within the first few hours we had 500 requests for the kit and I think as of the last couple of days we have had 2,600 requests. We have even had one of the opposition member's staff ring for a copy of the kit.

ANSWER.PARA: So the employer organisations are backing up what we are doing. They are working hard with seminars. The National Farmers Federation is working hard. We have had some very interesting reports of people who are keen to take up the option of AWAs and we are encouraging them.

The Office of the Employment Advocate is slowly building up its numbers. It is there to help people and to provide people with this opportunity. Lastly, it is not only the member for Dunkley who is doing a great job but also other members. I was in the electorate of the member for Makin the other day. There is a lot of interest in it. I was with the member for Griffith the other day. He is pushing hard. We are looking forward to a good year of providing a lot of opportunities for small business to create jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen reports that South Australian Ministers McLachlan and Downer refuse to state their view on car tariffs because it would breach cabinet solidarity, but that two other ministers, Hill and Vanstone, have put their position on the record? Have Ministers Hill and Vanstone breached cabinet solidarity by going public with their opposition to further cuts in car tariffs? If not, why won't you also let Ministers Downer and McLachlan spell out their position?

—The answer is yes, I have seen reports. Like many of the reports in this area, they are bizarre and inaccurate. Can I say that I have total confidence in all of the ministers. I take the opportunity of recording the fact that, since the colonies of Australia federated in 1901, we have the largest representation from South Australia in the federal cabinet since Federation. I pay tribute to the outstanding work of those four members of my cabinet. I am proud to have all of them as colleagues; they are all doing a great job.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to reports that the government intends to build a new international airport at Holsworthy with the consequent need to close the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights. Will you now rule out the construction of any nuclear facility—including a reprocessing plant—at Jervis Bay? Will you give a commitment to this House that any decision to build a new reactor on an alternative site will only be taken after extensive public consultation as to the need for a reactor, possible alternative methods for the production of radioisotopes and the proposed site itself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I correct the first part of the honourable member's question, if I heard it correctly, and that is that we have decided to build another airport at Hols worthy. We have not taken any decision. We are waiting on the results of the EIS on that. So don't try to slide a little misrepresentation into your question.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as Jervis Bay is concerned, it is my understanding that it has already been ruled out on umpteen occasions, but I do so again. As to the rest of the question, I think the government's position was eloquently and effectively stated by my colleague the minister for science when he answered a question on this matter a few weeks ago. I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Speaker.
—Proceed.

—Today in question time the Treasurer (Mr Costello), in response to what you correctly pointed out was probably a disorderly interjection of mine, suggested that I was—by interjecting—criticising or deploring the improvement in the Australian economy reflected in the skill vacancy survey. What in fact I was pointing out was that the survey which he was applauding in March 1997 has merely reached the same level at which it stood in March 1996. The survey at March 1996 stood at 155 and at March 1997 it also stands at 155.

—Mr Speaker, I have a question for you. Earlier this week you announced that you would be tabling a report on the proposed amalgamations of the parliamentary departments. Could you advise the House when you intend tabling that report, as this session is fast coming to a close?

—I thank the honourable member for Watson. I know this is likely to be a consuming passion for many of us over the coming months. Some of our discussions continue. I did say that I would distribute the report shortly. That remains in place, and I fully expect that it will be distributed before the House rises next week.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Reith)—by leave—proposed:
That the House take note of the following paper:
National Crime Authority—Parliamentary Joint Committee—Report—Organised criminal paedophile activity, November 1995—Government response.
Debate (on motion by Mr Crean) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the government to make real progress in solving Australia's worst problem: the unacceptably high level of unemployment at 8.8 per cent and its serious impact of metropolitan and regional Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the House today goes to one of the most important issues that Australia as a nation has to come to terms with at the moment, and that is the question of unemployment—a question that is worrying both metropolitan and regional Australia. As has become the case with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) when questioned about these matters during question time, he now seeks, rather than to answer the questions going to the deteriorating employment situation in Australia, to deliver little homilies from the dispatch box.

SPEECH.PARA: It is that type of approach that he took in response to a question that I raised in the House on 10 October last year. It went to the deterioration in the employment situation. It was last October that the Prime Minister yet again gave me one of his little homilies. In essence, he effectively told me to sit down because he does not like to be questioned about the issue of jobs. He told me that I shouldn't dare ask him a question about the most important issue facing Australia today: jobs and the rising job queues.

I know that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) also likes to run away from this important issue. Instead of answering questions about the issue of employment he comes up with policies on the run that will not deliver any real opportunities to reduce the deteriorating situation of employment in Australia at the moment. He also told me to wait 12 months before I asked him a question about the job queues.

The simple answer to the Prime Minister today is: time's up. Yes, time's up. We are 12 months into a three‐year parliament. One‐third of this parliament's term has now gone. Do you know what the real problem for the Prime Minister and the Howard government is? It is not just the Australian Labor Party raising these concerns any more: it is the people in the outfield, the people in metropolitan Australia, the people in regional Australia. The mob that he likes to refer to from time to time: the people who go to the cricket games, the people who go to the netball, the people who go to the football. Unfortunately, people in every suburb of Australia today know someone who is unemployed. People who are part of families in Australia today unfortunately know of a family member who is unemployed. That is the mob, that the Prime Minister likes to refer from time to time, which is concerned at the moment.

Yes, time is up. The Howard government has had 12 long months—one‐third of a normal parliamentary term—to start achieving on the jobs front, to do something about the critical issue of creating real jobs in Australia. But the problem for the Howard government and the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training is that the ledger shows no results at all.

BREAK.PARA: I think the Australian community has a right to expect some results. I'll tell you why the Australian community has a right to expect some results. The Prime Minister, just 12 months ago, went all around Australia. The truth is that the community was listening at the time of the Prime Minister's speeches because there was in the minds of the Australian community a need to try something new.

Our leader said, in the wind‐up of parliament last year, that the Australian community was willing to try something new. They acknowledged the progress and the great change that occurred over 13 years for the betterment of Australia. They also acknowledged that significant progress had been made on the jobs front.

The Prime Minister was, in essence, elected on the promise of creating real jobs. That is what his promise was to the Australian community. He said to all those who would listen, `I will create real jobs.' He talked about the question of job security and promised to resolve the issue of youth unemployment. He told Australians at large that was what he was concerned about. He said he was going to find jobs for our young people. He was going to find jobs for the people in remote and regional Australia. He was going to find jobs for one of the real problems on the unemployment front at the moment—middle‐aged men. He was going to find jobs for all sections of Australian society.

He wanted Australians to believe that he was Mr Real Jobs. In a National Press Club speech on the eve of the last election, this is what Mr Real Jobs said to the Australian community and to all the media assembled:
We have gone into this election campaign committing ourselves above all other things to do something effective . . . to reduce the level of youth unemployment.
That is what the Prime Minister—Mr Real Jobs—said. He then went on to say:

I will be a very disappointed man if I have not made very serious inroads into the level of youth unemployment in this country because I would like to see our performance in that area as being the mark of what we have been able to do as a government.
Interesting words, interesting promises.

The Australian community, 12 months into the life of this parliament, expects some results. That is why the Australian community is saying today in very harsh terms to the Prime Minister that time is up. What is the score? Have you got any runs on the cricket board? Out there in ordinary voter land, out there amongst the battlers, the young and the families, the score looks pretty bad and it is looking worse month by month as we go into the life of this parliament.

This government is pretty good about chasing the headlines. But when it comes to issues of substance, actually trying to put in place practical programs that are going to produce results and assist in creating opportunities in industry, attract investment and get Australians back to work, it is an abysmal failure.

As an alternative, we are not talking about real jobs in the parliament this afternoon. In a range of questions put to the Prime Minister today, we had an opportunity to see what his real program is to create real jobs in Australia. What did he talk about? I'll tell you what: he is pretty good on the headlines but awful on the issue of substance. All he could refer to was a pilot work for the dole project or, more recently, what we had floated in the newspapers of Monday last week—boot camps. That is what we have resorted to—boot camps.

Even the Australian military forces, which have been known to be pretty supportive of governments in the past and to be disciplined with respect to public comment, were forced to say in fairly stark terms to the Prime Minister, `We are pretty tolerant of your action on a lot of activities, but, I'll tell you what, we can't wear boot camps.' They rejected it out of hand. When you consider the results, you have to come to some conclusions.

Let us take the issue of youth unemployment. The truth of the matter is—the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training knows this—that the youth figures have not moved down one iota in 12 months. In reality, more importantly, they are slipping up and up—they have now reached 28 per cent. Well might the minister hang his head in shame.

Then we go to the question of long-term unemployment. We slashed labour market expenditure with respect to these desperate cases. We are no longer concerned as a nation in investing public resources in getting those people back to employment. What is the scoreboard on the long-term unemployment front, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) reminded the Prime Minister today? Long-term unemployment is at a 17‐month high. That is the result that the Prime Minister thinks his government ought to be proud of. There are an incredible 14,200 more people on the long-term unemployment queue as a result of one month's performance—the last month's performance of the Howard government.

The Howard government slashed what I thought was a pretty good investment. It was about Australia as a nation saying to all of us, `If you are unfortunate enough to lose a job, then we are prepared to invest in your future because we are not prepared to tolerate a situation by which there are some Australians who have got jobs, and a significant group of other Australians who do not have that second opportunity, that hope for the future—the long-term unemployed.' They slashed labour market expenditure last May. I know they like to doctor the figures about the performance of Working Nation, but the facts speak for themselves on that front—especially the facts that came out of the mouth of the minister for education at the Senate estimates hearings in recent times. More than 40,000 people have joined the long-term unemployment queue since last May.

Then we go to the issue of regional Australia. This is where they have really achieved—in regional Australia! Youth unemployment has gone up. Long-term unemployment has gone up by 40,000 in less than 12 months. What is the story in regional Australia? I know they are not interested in regional Australia. We no longer have a minister for regional Australia. We have got a minister for unemployment, who is sitting in the House today, but we do not have a minister for regional Australia. What are the results?

Sixteen per cent of those on the New South Wales north coast are jobless. That figure was 11.8 per cent when we lost government. We found a job up there recently for one of their mates, Doug Anthony, but we cannot find jobs for the unemployed on the north coast of New South Wales.

Let's go to Bendigo and Ballarat. There is a big black hole in Bendigo, where they promised an art gallery that would have assisted in creating jobs. The member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) is absent from the chamber at the moment, as is the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson). Perhaps they are out looking for the black hole. In the Bendigo area unemployment is at 10.4 per cent. In the Ballarat area it has jumped not by half a per cent in a month but from 8.3 per cent to 10.3 per cent. If I were either the member for Ballarat or the member for Bendigo, I would be looking for that black hole very quickly. There is a stark reminder in the city of Bendigo about the importance of job creation and Working Nation. There is a stark reminder in the city of Ballarat about the importance of industry policy and making sure that we protect decent industries that create real jobs, such as the textile clothing and footwear industry and the vehicle industry.

Then we go to South Australia—another state that depends on a decent industry policy. In regional South Australia in just one month we lost 1,000 jobs. In the New South Wales central west 4,600 were thrown onto the jobless queues. I could go on but, unfortunately, time does not permit me to do so this afternoon.

That takes me to the real solutions offered by the Howard government. What do we get? Work for the dole, with discounted wages on the training wage proposal that was producing the results. It was the member for Goldstein himself—the minister responsible—who admitted in the House yesterday afternoon that it was not going to produce a real job, that it really would not seriously assist in reducing youth unemployment in Australia. I suppose he is now going to suggest that it is not even a labour market program. Unfortunately, the Australian community might see it as being fairly popular at the moment, but I suggest to you that 10,000 places, 70 pilot programs, will not really assist in reducing youth unemployment in Australia.

The Australian public are now starting to see what is really behind this proposal. Before the election they did not support work for the dole. A couple of weeks ago when we had to hide Senator Woods the government announced it, and it was just for young people. As we questioned them in question time it went from being for 20‐year‐olds to being for 25‐year‐olds, and now we have ended up with an open ended scheme. I suppose that is what happens when you are more concerned about creating jobs for Senator Short or Doug Anthony, or even Peter Nixon. What is Peter Nixon's real job? It is investigating the economic situation in Tasmania and how they might create jobs. Unemployment in Tasmania is pretty bad, so that is why we have got to try to create an impression that we are creating real jobs, full-time jobs. So what do we see in the media today? We are going to redefine full‐time work.

I think we did pretty good as a Labor government. We have got a terrific record on employment, with the creation of real part‐time jobs and real full-time jobs. Importantly, that created great opportunities for women, but now we are going to try to distort the situation by the redefinition of part-time and full‐time work. The facts will speak for themselves.

This government has failed. The Australian community does not feel secure as a result of the election of the Howard government. They are tense and scared. They are tense and scared as unemployment numbers go up and their jobs are placed at risk. I suggest to the Howard government that the time has come to change its budget strategies for the sake of all Australians. Promises were made and promises are being broken. Do not let Australia down on the most important issue at the moment. All Australians are entitled to a real job. It does not matter whether it is a part-time or a full‐time job. Do not seek to create a hoax by now redefining the issue of part-time as against full-time jobs. Invest in Australia, invest in labour market programs and invest in industry policy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALKER.NAME: Dr KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, unemployment is certainly one of Australia's greatest social problems. It is probably the single most damaging legacy of the previous government. The previous government showed itself absolutely unable to address the problem and to provide Australians with real jobs. It spent taxpayers' money, money earned by the hard work of the working families of this country, and it spent that money like water in an attempt to solve the problem through government schemes, mickey mouse training schemes and by churning the long‐term unemployed through these schemes to redefine them as short‐term unemployed. It tried every stratagem in the book but it was unable to make any significant progress whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last six years of the Labor government's administration, the net additional full‐time jobs that it created numbered 7,100. And the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) has the effrontery to get up in this House, after 13 years of atrocious policy failure, to criticise this government for not solving, in 12 months, the problem that they left. At no stage throughout those 13 years did the Labor government attempt to address the fundamental reasons for unemployment in this country. I will go through those fundamental reasons one by one and look at Labor's failure on each one. They were full of rhetoric then; they are full of rhetoric now.

The fact is that there has been job creation since the last election. In fact, employment in Australia now is the highest it has ever been. There are more people in jobs now in this country than there have ever been at any previous time in Australia's history. We do not claim that that is good enough. We do not go around the country trumpeting that fact and pretending that somehow or other that solves the unemployment problem; we know that there are fundamental issues that need to be addressed, that are being addressed by this government, that were not addressed for 13 years.

BREAK.PARA: Firstly, policies need to be put in place that will encourage Australians to save and invest in job creation. No government in Australia's history did more to destroy savings than the Labor government. Over the last six years they accumulated something like $70 billion worth of deficits: $70 billion they did not have, they spent. And did that produce jobs? Did that produce a prosperous economy? Did that revive small business? Did it bump up investment?

No, of course it did not. It destroyed jobs because it pushed up interest rates to some of the highest real interest rates in the world. They drove small business bankruptcies to record levels. They imposed on small business industrial relations laws which absolutely bound and tied the enterprises of this country so they could not invest and have confidence in employing people. They put in place an unfair dismissals law that discouraged small businesses from taking on full‐time employees. They thought they could solve unemployment by spending, but they could not.

In that respect, of course, they were being absolutely true to Labor Party tradition, because that is exactly what Labor has always done. It is what they did under Whitlam; it is what they did under Hawke; it is what they did under Keating, and it is what they still want to do because they will not face up to the fact that, unless you create an environment in which small business is willing to create jobs, you will not solve the unemployment problem.

I will digress a moment to say that last week I had the honour of speaking on behalf of, and to acknowledge the achievements of, Bert Kelly, the former member for Wakefield. Bert was known in this House for his wit in puncturing the pretensions of the hypocrites on the other side of the House. On one occasion he asked this question of Jim Cairns as Treasurer:

Last week the Treasurer told us about his policy of using deficit financing to lower the present level of unemployment. How is this solution of burying unemployment under a mountain of money actually working out?
Bert Kelly wondered:
If printing money is a good solution for the unemployment problem, why not print more of the stuff and get rid of the unemployment problem altogether?
Kelly recalled this—and it is from his book, One More Nail , at page 188:
And Jim Cairns, with his kind heart brimming over with love and affection, just could not resist agreeing with me and replied that that was just what the government had in mind.
And many keen political observers pinpoint the beginning of Cairns's decline from that point.

Here are his successors—not one, but two of them—the two big spenders, the believers in deficit financing, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and the member for Batman. The member for Hotham is the person who probably spent more money on labour market programs than anyone—churning the unemployed through, trying to redefine them as short‐term unemployed and not offering them any real jobs. No‐one in this parliament has ever had so much experience in spending other people's money to achieve nothing as has the member for Hotham, the man who has pretensions to becoming the leader of the Labor Party.

Sitting next to him is his clone, the member for Batman, who berates the government today for its failure to deal with this problem. The member for Batman has plans to spend even more money. He has plans to ensure that there will be absolutely unlimited access to the labour market services provided by government. That is why he criticises this government—because we are not planning to provide unlimited access to these services. The Labor Party in government—not even under the member for Hotham—did not provide unlimited access, but the member for Batman thinks that there should be unlimited access. He is prepared to spend not merely $2 billion but maybe $4 billion or $6 billion, and all of that money will come out of Australian small business. He is not going to get it all through the tax system but, to the extent that he does, it will come out of the pockets of battling families. To the extent that he borrows to get it, it will push up interest rates and we will be back in that whole destructive cycle the Labor Party was responsible for that has left this country with the unemployment problem that it now has.

These schemes that they put in place to address unemployment, because they had no way of creating real jobs, were tremendously destructive of the morale of those who went through them. Of course, the member for Hotham knows that very well because he attended, as I did, the Jobs for Young Australians conference in South Australia in August last year. There was one very clear message that was given by the hundreds of young people at that conference and that was, `Stop putting us through Simon Crean's short‐term training programs. We do not all want to be horticulturalists. We are not all interested in the history of dance in this country. We do not see careers in that. We want training that leads to real jobs.'

That is our commitment, and that is why we have picked up that great historic program, the apprenticeship program, which Labor, at the behest of its union mates, did so little about. Of course, the member for Hotham and the member for Batman know all about that because they were the union mates. They have come out of the closet and they are sitting there now trying to sell us the same old snake oil medicine that the Australian people rejected at the election last year. They so despised the traditional apprenticeship system and did so little that in 1995 the number of young people in apprenticeships and traineeships as a proportion of the work force was the lowest for three decades. We have put in place the foundations of a new national apprentice system which will—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which equals traineeships. Traineeships equals new apprenticeships.

—Which does not equal traineeships, although I fully recognise the fact that traineeships are an important thing in this. You simply put in place, after 10 years, the beginnings of a traineeship system and there were very, very few people in that system when you left office. You had 13 years to address this problem and you did not address it successfully.

BREAK.PARA: The new Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system will provide young people with quality training not just in the traditional trades but in a whole range of new industries: in communications, in information technology, in the finance industry. It will build up the status of traineeships and we, for the first time, will provide school students in the senior secondary years with the opportunity to move straight from school into those quality training opportunities. Indeed, under the reforms we are putting in place, they will be able to begin traineeships and apprenticeships in school. It will be a national system, with national qualifications, nationally recognised—

TALK.START.PARA: —We started it.

—Which you never put in place—which will provide opportunities that young people in this country are looking for. One has to say that the member for Batman is probably—and I say this with full deference to the member for Hotham—the greatest snake oil salesman of them all, because if you asked him what his proposal is to provide jobs you come down to schemes like job sharing.
—And industry policy.
—Oh, and industry policy! We can see the labels on the snake oil bottles along the Labor Party policy shelf there.
—Where do you stand on tariffs?
—Order! The member for Batman has already had his say.

—He could take any of them off the shelf. But let us just have a look at what the Labor Party thought about job sharing in government in former years when we were in opposition. In December 1993 the discussion paper `Restoring Full Employment', commissioned and published by the Keating government, said that job sharing may, in some cases, increase employment in the short term but leads to a poorer long-term employment result, primarily because it lowers overall productivity levels and, therefore, per capita incomes. That was the conclusion of the policy analysts of the Labor Party when they were in government. They were not proposing job sharing at that time. The Sydney Morning Herald , on 6 February of this year, reported:

BREAK.PARA: The ALP's largest affiliate union, AMWU, has come out strongly against a proposal by the federal opposition—
that is by the member for Batman, the shadow minister for employment—
to encourage job sharing, arguing: `It will not support the sharing of poverty.'

That, of course, is precisely what the member for Batman does support. That is what job sharing amounts to: the sharing of poverty. They have given up on creating real jobs. They have no idea how to create real jobs, so they say, `Let us share around the jobs we have currently got; let us take away a third or a half of the jobs of people currently in employment and give them to somebody else.' It is the kind of nonsense that the Australian people hear from the Labor Party.

Of course the reason they are hearing this nonsense is that there is no policy direction in the Labor Party. The Labor Party have no idea whatever where to go. They do not know what to do about work for the dole. They do not know what to do about employment. They are wandering around in the darkness clutching at anything, because in the end they have a leadership which has no purpose and direction. They have weak leadership. The only person who thinks there might be a job for himself out of that weak leadership is none other than the member for Hotham. Job sharing is something he is right into, and he would like to share 100 per cent of that job as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have finally revealed the solution of the Howard government to create real jobs: redefine them. It is to take part-timers and call them full‐timers. Now we have a situation where so long as you work 20 hours a week you have a real job. What a sham. Where does this come from? It comes from the master of obfuscation, the master doctorer. No wonder he has the title Dr Kemp—this Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training—because he doctors every figure going, and he is at it again.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that history has a way of repeating itself. In the back of my mind, there was this little recollection about the Fraser government years when they were having trouble with rising unemployment. What did they seek to do? Redefine the problem. Here we have, in the Melbourne Age of 11 September 1978, the heading `Jobless figures can be what you make them'. The Canberra Times: `Lies, damned lies and statistics: the conflict of figures on jobless.' This was Malcolm Fraser in 1978. Who was his adviser? Dr Kemp was the adviser. Here was this man in Malcolm Fraser's office, the arch idealogue of the Fraser government, the author of the reactionary right wing ideology of the Fraser government.

This minister is a recycled man. This is the man who gave us all that talk about dole bludgers and vouchers; the speech writer who helped stigmatise the unemployed. This is the same man, recycled from 1977, back to his old tricks. Now he has modern equipment. He has the white‐out. He has the tape to patch up figures to re‐present them in different ways. He recycles the same tired slogans, the same divisive attacks on the unemployed. He is a master of right wing ideology, but the fact is he is a failure as a minister for employment.

Not only is he a failure but the budget strategy is a failure. He has been parroting on about the jobs that have been created since their budget. Today we had the Treasurer (Mr Costello) come in and talk about employment—the first time he has actually come in and talked about employment in this House—and he relied on the DEETYA leading indicator, because he said that it had finally turned up. It is true it has turned up, but it has only turned up to what we left them. This is the record that they would criticise us on. Now they are claiming credit for merely having achieved that which we put in place.

To give some real impact of the budget strategy, let me just say this: since the last budget, job growth in this economy has been 6,000 a month; one-third of what Labor achieved. We have also seen a circumstance in which since the last budget they have lost 34,000 full-time jobs. No wonder he is redefining them. The only way they can get their commitment to any sort of job activity is to call 20 hours a full-time and real job. What a grubby little exercise coming from the master of obfuscation, the doctorer of statistics, the person who was driven by ideology but who has no commitment, no compassion and no intention of doing anything for the long-term unemployed.
Mr Wilton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The very program he gloats about and laughs about every time he says that we are spending $2 billion on the long‐term unemployed. We make no apology for that because it was a program that worked. What we have seen since you have been in office is 40,000 more long-term unemployed back on the dole queues. This is a great achievement, Minister, in the space of but 12 months. We all know this has always been your intention. The trouble is you just wanted to hide it from people. But we will not let you hide it, Minister. You have an obligation to stand up in this place, as a minister committed to getting unemployment down, and come up with real programs.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember you saying that at least the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, said on the record at one stage that there was no intention of forcing mature age people—that is, those who are over 50—to do voluntary work to receive their benefit. That was a promise made with the attention of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) at a meeting. What did we see in your legislation yesterday? No age limit. It is not just a question of forcing young people into boot camps; you are also forcing older people into meals on wheels. What sort of dignified approach is that?

Also, your work for the dole is a part-time activity. At least this is consistent with your attempt to redefine the problem away. But why won't you give young people full-time activity? Why won't you give them real training? Why won't you involve the private sector in this activity, as the premier from Victoria has been suggesting you do? If this argument about work for the dole is worth doing, do it properly for God's sake! Young people deserve more, and so does everyone else in the work force looking to get back into employment. They are not getting eco nomic activity from you and they are not getting any compassion.

Green Corp was the other program that was much heralded to provide environmental action. It resulted in 2,000 jobs. Labor was creating 27,000 environment jobs a year, and this little grubby exercise comes up with 2,000 over three years. But it gets worse. Of the people who have been placed so far—only 254 of them—most of them were employed. This is their program for the unemployed. Give the programs to the employed! What foolishness are you carrying on with over there in the department? You cannot get away with simply continuing to doctor the figures.

Let me come to the motor industry, because this is vital to employment prospects in both Victoria and South Australia. We have the circumstance in which this government will not stand up and be counted in backing the car industry. We have the situation in which we have ministers from South Australia prepared to come out and stick up for the car industry—that is, Ministers Hill and Vanstone—but not Minister Downer and Minister McLachlan.

Minister McLachlan not only has difficulty spelling out the program for the car industry but, in his defence, also has difficulty spelling his own name. The Adelaide Advertiser of the other day had an article headed `PM backs silent MPs on car industry'. I bet their electorate doesn't. There is also a picture here of the Bananas in Pyjamas twins. B1 and B2 sitting over there, silent as ever, cannot even get their position up. B1 and B2: the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) and the member for Mayo (Mr Downer). We all know that the member for Mayo is very keen on these characters. He probably has copies of them in the doll's house on the family property.

We know what the strategy for the car industry is by this government. The outcome of this cosy little dinner at Canberra's most exclusive club, the Commonwealth Club, was revealed to us a couple of weeks ago. John Moore actually stays there, so he did not have too far to go home. Minister Costello was able to get into the ministerial limousine. So they could indulge themselves a bit in the cigars and the cognac.

BREAK.PARA: There they were, late in the evening. John Moore said, `Can you give us your vision for the car industry, Treasurer?' The Treasurer said, `I have a vision for the car industry: it's to close the Mitsubishi plant in Adelaide. This country can't afford four car manufacturers. We should reduce it down to three.' The simple facts of the matter are that there is room for four car manufacturers in this country, only if you get the right policies in place.

That is Labor's commitment. It is not just about freezing tariffs and it is not about winding back the clock; it is about giving them security. It is about ensuring that we help them to get into export markets, so we need to keep the export facilitation scheme. But, at the same time, we have an agreement from the industry that if we put in place this plan we will create 10,000 new jobs and we will double exports.

For a government that said that it was trying to correct the current account and for a government that said it was trying to create jobs, why would it look this gift‐horse in the mouth? Yet it does. It stands there dumbfounded. The only solution for the car industry in this country is for this government to get behind Labor's plan for the car industry. If they do, they will get real security in the work force. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, well, well. We have two ex-members of the ACTU standing up and trying to tell us how to run the government. The Labor Party—which embraced privatisation, embraced enterprise bargaining, embraced union power in the accord and sold out on tariffs—now expects their party faithful to come running back to them all of a sudden as new Labor. Well, they did not six months after the 3 March by‐election in Lindsay. Now, 12 months after the by-election, I am sure we would get another five per cent increase in our vote.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor is going absolutely nowhere. It has gone nowhere since the 1990 recession where we had 11.2 per cent of Australians unemployed, and the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) professes concern. Oh, he is terribly worried. His heart is breaking for the battlers—for the people at the football. What about the battlers of Lindsay? What about the guys who had to sit there as Labor doled out a 40 per cent increase on sales tax, as they were strangled by the regulation that the Labor Party put on small business, as they suffered tax hike after tax hike, as they suffered ridiculously high interest rates and as the Labor government destroyed Commonwealth savings?

In 1992 the Labor government spent $11½ billion more than they collected. In 1992‐93 the budget figures show that they spent $17 billion more than they collected; in 1993-94, another $17 billion more than they collected; in 1994‐95, another $13.2 billion more than they collected. Evidence that they were still on the same track—if the Liberal Party had not returned to government—is Beazley's black hole. The 1995-96 figures came up with a $10.3 billion deficit.

How did the Labor Party pay for this—the party that stood for government enterprise, the party that stood for non‐privatisation? They sold off Qantas, they sold off the uranium stockpile, they sold off ASTA, the sold off the FAC, CBA and ANL. There is not really much left for us to sell when it comes to fund the $5.6 billion deficit we are facing this year.

The deficit is slowly coming down. We are slowly getting Commonwealth savings back into government in Australia. This government will slowly get money in the bank so that, if we do suffer a hiccup such as a recession, we do not have 11.2 per cent unemployed as we did in 1992. We will have savings. We can spend our way out of a recession. That is why Labor could do nothing about the deteriorating labour figures.

Despite an economic upturn from December 1995 until March 1996, unemployment went from 8.1 per cent to 8.5 per cent. Australia was in a mess, and the country knew it. The numbers in parliament are proof of this. Those very same ex‐ACTU members and ex‐union bosses, who sit there with their fancy deals and sell their members' interests out to big business to keep themselves a nice cushy job through the union movement into parliament, stand here today and betray the very people they were sent to represent. What happens? Those people turn to people like me—an ordinary Australian, a PAYE taxpayer—to come here and represent their interests, and, I tell you, they are very happy with what we are doing.

Instead of coming up with a solution, Labor came up with NWOS, new work opportunity schemes. They cost $10,000 a head. They had a 21 per cent success rate, and the rest of it was wasted money. Do you know what the beautiful thing about that is? Those people did not count in the unemployment figures. Those people were counted as training, so they were not unemployed. At the end of their LEAP project, new wave project or any of those other government sponsored programs, they went back into the short‐term unemployed.

Talk about fiddling the figures. If you are worried about how statistics lie, let us have a look at what Labor were doing to the unemployed: they were not counting these figures in the unemployment statistics. They make wild allegations that our minister had anything to do with those figures in 1978. He was not even there.

If you work for one hour a week, even if it is in a family business, then on the ABS statistics you come up as not unemployed. The distinction between employed and unemployed has not changed. The facts and figures we are talking about here are exactly the same, and the changes in the definition of part‐time and full‐time work have only occurred for administrative reasons in the employment placement enterprises. They will receive government sponsorship for their money, if the person they have placed has entered full‐time employment—defined as more than 20 hours a week for six months. I do not know why the ACTU is making such a big thing about this. It stands to reason that, if this enterprise has got these people into a job—and let us define job—they should get paid for it.

But the facts and figures that the ABS uses to come up with full‐time and part‐time statistics have not changed. There has been no diddling of the unemployment figures. We have crystallised the unemployment figures. We have not hidden them in programs; we have crystallised unemployment. If you are on the dole now, we know you are. We have a work for the dole scheme, you can join the army, you can do a whole bunch of things, but we recognise that you are unemployed.

And we recognise that another of Labor's solutions—`give them a government job'—is not a solution. Under Labor, one out of every five jobs was in the state government, local council or Commonwealth public services. Again, the people in the other four jobs had their hands heavily in their pockets to pay for the person in the fifth job. We have recognised that those are not real jobs. You cannot hide unemployment figures and stack the books that way. In the end, we have to pay for our public servants and, if there is no money, there is no money to do that.

The other solution the opposition has come up with is job sharing. Let us share a job—you beauty! `Wow, I can have a full‐time job and bring things home for my kids and my family and my spouse, and we can go away on weekends, or I can have a part‐time job.' What do you think workers want? They want full‐time jobs. In the last 12 months we have crystallised unemployment and we have set some very strategic groundbreaking measures in place to get out of the rut and off the track to disaster that we were on on 3 March 1996.

It has not been easy. It has been a long haul. We have not had much help from the opposition in the Senate. We have not been able to act quickly. Even so, we have balanced the budget. We are heading towards a target in 2000 where we will have government savings to help kick‐start us out of recession. With that has come a certain amount of offshore confidence which has lowered interest rates. Do not underestimate what impact that has had—the flow‐on effects are just coming now.

We now have low inflation and we have flexible workplace relations, which only came in January. Given time, both of those will see an increase in jobs. We have also got individually tailored assistance for the unemployed: they can get the skills that they need and they are still recognised as unemployed and counted in the unemployment statistics. We are not fudging things here. This is a very open and transparent government, and we are not going to dress up any facts and figures for the public. They are entitled to be treated as adults and not as patronised children—as the opposition used to treat them prior to 3 March 1996. We have also spent an enormous amount of time reinvigorating small business and reducing red tape. We have a task force report coming in next week. We have got reduced provisional tax, the capital gains rollover relief and relief in sight for FBT. (Time expired)
