DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS SURCHARGE (ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 March, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Upon which Mr Gareth Evans's moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) condemns the Government for:
(a) breaking solemn commitments made before the election not to raise the rate of existing taxes nor introduce new taxes;
(b) attempting to deceive the Australian public by not admitting that this measure is a tax;
(c) deliberately inflicting on the superannuation industry an impossibly cumbersome, inefficient and expensive collection method;

(d) ensuring by that collection method that superannuation providers incur enormous administrative expenses which will in turn be borne by their members, the great majority of whom are low and middle income earners;

(e) ensuring by that method, and in particular the requirements for notification of Tax File Numbers, that over one million Australians, the overwhelming majority being low and middle income earners, will become liable for the full 15 per cent tax;
(f) creating major new compliance burdens for small business, at the same time that the Government has been promising to dramatically reduce red tape; and

(2) urges the Government to withdraw and re‐draft this legislative package, and re‐introduce a new package that will meet the objective of imposing an additional 15 per cent tax on the superannuation contributions of higher income earners, without the adverse consequences identified here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably fair to concede that this collection of superannuation bills is controversial. I was interested to listen in the chamber last night to the shadow Treasurer, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans), make his contribution to the debate. If you take out a lot of the words and the rhetoric that he threw in, and for which he is renowned, you will find that he actually made some rather interesting and, I might concede, telling points.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some questions about this package of legislation which, it is a well‐known fact, we on this side have been asking and which we have been concerned about. As I have said, if you take out some of the words of the shadow Treasurer's contribution, on balance you will find he made some debatable points.

A lot of the difficult decisions that we on this side have had to make since coming to government have to be put in the context of the fiscal situation as we found it at that time. Of course, it would have been much easier to come to government with a clean slate and with the opportunity to not only do things which needed to be done but also continue those many programs which had some merit and were introduced by the previous government, which spent with impunity on so many programs for so long, and we are now bearing the cost of that. You could name lots of programs which had considerable merit, such as the Commonwealth Dental Service.

We came into government with the enormous task of turning this country's finances around. That was a difficult task and it affected every portfolio area. I notice that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) is in the House at the moment. His portfolio was particularly affected. But all areas were affected because of the need to get the fiscal position in order.

BREAK.PARA: In that context, we have been looking to raise revenue. I take it that the main thrust of this measure is to achieve that objective. I think there are some other arguments for it. Some of my colleagues—I note that not many will be speaking on this bill—will probably make some of those points. The measure is intended to raise something in the order of $450 million. From the government's budgetary point of view, it is a very important measure.

I notice that the opposition is not intending to oppose the measure outright, although it has moved an amendment. If one looks at the amendment on a point by point basis, breaking through some of the rhetoric, one will find that it seeks to condemn the government for breaking solemn commitments, made before the election, not to raise the rate of existing taxes or introduce new ones.

We did make that commitment and by and large we have maintained it in very difficult circumstances. We can deal with the semantics of this issue as to whether it is a surcharge or whether it is a tax, but in the end I do not think it is terribly productive to do that. In the context of the fiscal difficulties we faced when we came to government, it is understandable that we had to take some steps. We could not do it with our hands entirely tied behind our backs. So this is one important measure which is intended to raise $450 million.

We wanted to raise it in a way that was fair. It is reasonable to argue that this measure is essentially a fair measure. It is intended to impose an additional commitment on those who can afford to pay—essentially high income earners. Those earning $75,000 and above would be classed as high income earners. It has the virtue of equity, which is an important argument for taking this measure.

The opposition amendment suggests that we are attempting to deceive the Australian public by not admitting that this measure is a tax. Once again, I say to the opposition that that is semantics. It is a pointless argument. I make the point again that, in the budgetary context, we have honoured our commitment, if not entirely to the letter then very sub stantially to the letter and in the spirit of the commitment that was made to the Australian people. I think that is widely recognised.

The amendment makes the suggestion—again, it reflects the shadow Treasurer's garrulity—that the government is `deliberately inflicting on the superannuation industry an impossibly cumbersome, inefficient and expensive collection method'. That may be so. Certainly, it has been a concern raised not only by the industry but by others. They have suggested that the administrative complexities will be enormous and pointed out that the costs will be directly or indirectly borne by all members of funds and their employers. They are saying that there is going to be an administrative expense involved—I have heard a figure of perhaps as much as $30 million—in collecting it.

Perhaps there are other ways of collecting the surcharge but, on balance, in the discussions that we have had with the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on this matter, this appears to be the best way to collect the levy. Any other way of collecting it would place a burden on a larger number of either individual taxpayers or small businesses. In the end, it comes down to what the most effective way of collecting it is, and this appears to be the answer to that. Part (d) of their amendment restates that point, using a number of other adjectives and adverbs, and, as I say, in the shadow Treasurer's best style, and (e) and (f) do not contribute much to it. The important point is that the opposition recognises that this is an important revenue raising measure and ultimately, I think, recognises, as I understood what the shadow Treasurer was saying, that it had the merit of largely being imposed on high income earners.

I suppose the point ought to be made that it has the virtue of impacting on members of parliament. I suppose, as far as the public at large is concerned, it is a considerable virtue. In fact, when you think about it, it is probably its most potent selling point. I do not think any amount of self‐inflicted pain is likely to attract even the mildest applause from the public because there is a perception out there that our salaries and benefits are generous. I have sought, on occasions, to win an argu ment on that, but I have never been successful. I do not think even the most verbally dexterous member of this place could win an argument with anybody on that issue, so I will not even attempt to.

The point should be made that, quite deliberately, all members of parliament will be affected by this legislation. We deliberately included ourselves in that. The Treasurer has made a point of ensuring that that fact is well known. The concern I have, which I ought to put on the record, is that we are not certain what the effect will be on us. In a sense, we are all signing a blank cheque here. I do not say that lightly but the complexity, which I concede is a factor, is making it very difficult for us to get an accurate determination of what the actual impact might be on members of parliament. It is likely to be substantial and it is certain that we will be paying at least our fair share, if not more, of the superannuation surcharge.

I am, I think, able to say to the parliament that this, hopefully, will be the end of fiddling with superannuation for a number of years to come. I do not say that lightly because there have been a lot of changes in superannuation over the years. Over 13 years of the former government there were numerous changes and prior to the last election we had got to the point where people, if they had not lost confidence in superannuation, were fairly close to losing confidence in it and giving up on it simply because, even if it was a good investment—and it was and is, despite the surcharge, I believe—there is nevertheless an element of complexity about it and, dare I say, an element of a lack of trust, that it is seen as a milch cow and an easy target for governments of any complexion to seek to raise revenue from it.

We are certainly not pre‐empting any budgetary announcement here, but I believe I have detected in the Treasurer's comments on this subject some sort of commitment, which I hope will be put in cement at budget time, to let the superannuation scene settle down, let there be stability for the foreseeable future—and I am talking 10 or 20 years ahead—so that people can regain their confi dence in superannuation, because it is so important.

Since the 1970s, there has been a revolution in superannuation in Australia. Up until that time, superannuation was the province of a limited number of executives, mainly men I would say, and I suppose public servants, but from the early 1980s, when the extent of Australia's ageing population problem became apparent, superannuation has been encouraged as the principal means of saving for retirement. Many people have had the opportunity to do that.

In the context of our ageing population, it needs to be pointed out that the prediction of the Bureau of Statistics is that our population of over 65s will increase from 2.1 million in 1993 to 5.1 million in the year 2035. That makes the point very clearly that not only is the Australian population ageing but it is ageing at an increasing rate, in fact, at a great rate. It accentuates the importance of making people aware of the fact that they will have to save for their own retirement.

The other point in this context that needs to be understood is that people can expect to spend up to one‐third of their lives in retirement and, very clearly, because of that long period in retirement—25 or even more years—it is a lot of years in which they will not be working when they will not be able to depend on the government to provide for that retirement. So once again, it accentuates the importance of people understanding that they will have to save for their own retirement and that superannuation has been and will continue to be the main avenue for that particular saving.

I believe people must be weaned off—that is what it will require—an unrealistic expectation that somehow it will be okay when they retire, somehow the government will provide. The fact is that the government cannot provide and certainly, by that time, will not be able to provide full support for people in their retirement. If you do the maths of it—and I have not done that, but I can guess—there will just not be enough people in the work force able to pay enough tax to provide for the 5.1 million people by 2035 who will be over 65. It is going to be a mathematical impossibility.

People must be encouraged to save. In saying that I mean that they must be encouraged to invest for their retirement and to use those savings for that purpose. That is a radical change. It is a change that has only dawned on us in the last five or 10 years. I think it was a change that the former government brought about. It brought us to that point although it was controversial and difficult. I notice the former Treasurer, the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), is in the House at the moment. Obviously he realised, as the government of the day did, that we had to get people to a point where they understood that they had to save for their retirement and be prepared to use those savings to support themselves in retirement.

We have also learnt to understand—the former government went well down that track and we are moving further down that track—that middle class welfare is no longer an option. Ironically, we could not afford it before; we certainly cannot afford it now. People who can afford to save and invest for their retirement must be encouraged if not coerced into doing so.

We now find ourselves in a situation where people are not just encouraged to have superannuation, but it is mandated. Whilst that was a controversial decision at the time—and I think in opposition there were a lot of aspects of that compulsion which a number of us in the coalition had some difficulty with—we now accept that it is a fact of life. I believe we are committed to the ongoing success that that system should have in getting people to contribute, although we recognised at the time that it was a very long-term project. Once we get to the year 2030—when I say `we' I suppose I mean those who are still around—this will probably be looked at as the right thing to have done at the time. As the level of employer support grows from five per cent to I think it will be nine per cent in the year 2001 that system should really start to kick in and begin to be seen to be working.

By June 1996 there were 140,000 superannuation entities operating in Australia. It is a very substantial industry. Assets at March 1996 were $243.8 billion, which is around 60 per cent of our GDP. Perhaps now it has reached $260 billion. There are various estimates going around about what it might be by the year 2000, but it will certainly be a large amount of money compared with, say, 1983 when it only added up to $35 billion.

Superannuation has been an attractive investment option up until now and it has contributed significantly to Australia's pool of savings. We need more savings in order to finance investment. We need investment if we are going to have the economic growth that is necessary to provide employment. That is an important component of the solution to the large and totally unacceptable levels of unemployment that we still have.

Superannuation is also needed to avoid any further movement into debt. We have a net national debt of over $200 billion and it seems that it is going to be very difficult to wind that back. If we in this country do not provide savings for investment purposes from our own sources then the only way we will be able to achieve those goals and create growth and employment is by borrowing from other people's savings. One of the real imperatives we have in government in this country is improving Australia's abysmal record of national savings, and superannuation is an important part of that.

In summary, I concede—and I have been one who has at least been reasonably aware of what is going on in this very complex area that I think is a challenge for most members of parliament and certainly most members of the public to get their minds around—that these pieces of legislation are difficult and controversial. Some of the points made in the opposition's amendment, which seeks to take out some of the words, I think we would concede up to a point because of the fact that it is clearly not possible to deny, at least in some aspects, that there are some questions concerning the implementation of this legislation.

I think there are some questions about how much money it will eventually raise, particularly if people lose confidence, as they have done in recent years, about superannuation as an investment. I believe it is a good invest ment and, as I said earlier, in spite of the surcharge it will continue to be a very good investment. It is important that we now bed down the superannuation system, let people have confidence in it and stop making changes to it and then it will continue to be an important part of Australia's savings pool.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the second reading amendment to this superannuation contributions surcharge legislation moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans). The professed aim of the bills now before the House is to improve the equity of the tax system in relation to superannuation. The source of the alleged inequity in the present system is that we have a system which essentially taxes at a flat rate and gives greater benefits to people on higher incomes. The bill proposes to redress that by proposing a surcharge or an additional tax, to give it its proper title, on people on higher incomes in respect of their superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say firstly that we do not oppose increasing the equity of the superannuation system. Clearly Labor in government demonstrated that amply because the system we inherited from the previous government when the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer was one which had virtually no tax on superannuation at all. The only tax on superannuation was the five per cent tax on the superannuation lump sum and you paid that at marginal tax rates. At 60c in the dollar, which was the top marginal tax rate in those days, you paid three per cent tax. That was John Howard's tax regime for superannuation—three per cent.

We changed that in many respects. It was also, I must say, a system which was there mainly for higher income earners, because low income earners did not have superannuation. It was not something that was available to them, except for those who worked for governments. But for the ordinary, run‐of‐the‐mill private sector employee, there was no such superannuation available—40 per cent of the population had superannuation, and most of them were higher income earners.

So we did two things. We made superannuation generally available, which improved the equity because then everyone was entitled to superannuation. We did that through awards, the super guarantee system—the legislative approach—and then, of course, by changing the tax regime. The tax regime was eventually changed so that we had a 15 per cent tax on the contributions and a 15 per cent tax on the earnings on the fund. For lump sums, they were free of tax up to what is now $86½ thousand and then 15 per cent tax on the rest.

For pensions, they were taxed at the marginal tax rate minus 15 per cent, reflecting the 15 per cent that had been paid at the contributions and earning stage. So the tax rate, if you took a lump sum, was between 15 per cent and 30 per cent compared to the three per cent under the now Prime Minister when he was Treasurer. For a pension, there was simply no concession. You paid tax effectively at your marginal tax rate.

In relation to unfunded schemes, tax was only on the end benefits. For lump sums, it was 15 per cent on the front $86½ thousand and then 30 per cent. For pensions, tax was at the marginal tax rate. So, again, the total tax rate was between 15 per cent and 30 per cent for the lump sums and no concessions on pensions. That is the system on which all of this is being added.

In addition, we sought to limit the extent to which people could utilise the concessionality that was in the system through the introduction of RBLs—reasonable benefits limits—which set limits on how much you could take as a lump sum and how much you could take in terms of the total package, including pensions. So it was not there for complete exploitation with people with very high incomes being able to milk this for all it was worth.

So they were major steps towards improving the equity of the superannuation system, enormous steps compared to what was there before. Now everyone benefited from superannuation and the tax regime was far fairer. So we have very good credentials in that respect, but also we proposed to build on that through another system which was to provide for compulsory employee contributions, up to three per cent, from July 1999 and a matching means tested government co‐contribution of up to three per cent of average weekly ordinary time earnings for employees' contributions. This also applied to the self-employed in respect of their undeducted contributions.

So we had the second leg of the tax cuts being converted into a payment, a matching co‐contribution, into superannuation payable only to low and middle income earners. The top income earners were not going to get a penny out of that, not a cent out of the second leg of the tax cuts because they had been means tested out of it. It was all going into private sector savings, through superannuation, matching contributions to low and middle income earners.

So we were certainly going to add to the equity of the system in a very big way by that approach, an approach which I think has effectively now been abandoned. Of course, that would have boosted savings. Treasury estimated it would increase savings by one per cent of GDP by the year 2005 and 1.7 per cent by the year 2020, and of course it also considerably improved the equity of the system.

Now we have a government adopting a different approach. I must say, we see considerable problems with the way the government proposes to increase equity in the legislation now before the House. Firstly, there is the suggestion of unconstitutionality by certainly an eminent person—Dennis Rose, the former Chief General Counsel to the Attorney-General. Whether he is right or not, I do not know. All I know is that there is certainly a substantial chance that there could be some unconstitutionality involved in the approach taken here. There is also, obviously, the problem with the states. I do not want to go into that in any further detail because it has been well covered by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

We also see considerable problems with the way the government proposes to increase equity, and some of them are directly related to the way the government has designed this measure to try to avoid the tax label. It is petrified of labelling the thing as a tax because it promised not to introduce any new taxes—and clearly this is a new tax, along with various other new taxes. It is trying desperately to dress it up as something other than a tax.

This is a tax, quite clearly, and Dennis Rose said it clearly was. Although this tax is supposedly levied only on higher income earners, one of the really bad effects of this approach is that many lower income earners will be forced to pay the tax because, if they do not supply their tax file number to the super fund, which is to be reported to the tax office, they will pay the 15 per cent tax.

It is highly likely that many low and middle income earners will not supply their tax file number to the fund. They will not do it because they do not understand the consequences of not doing so, or because they are lost members. Lost members can be as high as 20 per cent of members—that is, people that the fund has lost touch with. So they cannot notify them to say, `If you don't give us the tax file number, we can't pass it on and you'll be liable to the tax.' They cannot even tell them that, and many of those they do tell are not really going to understand the implications.

There will also, of course, be people who will have supplied the tax file number to their employer and think that that is adequate. So they have already given it to someone and think, `Why can't the employer pass it on,' or think he is going to but, in fact, he cannot because of the privacy provisions around the tax file number. So, for various reasons, you are not going to get the tax file number passed on by many low and middle income earners who will, therefore, be subject to this tax.

If only 10 per cent of them did not put in their tax file number, you would be looking at something like three‐quarters of a million people who would be involved. The industry estimates about a million. Of course, they have some experience in this. They have been trying to get people to give them their tax file number. There has been a situation where there has not been the added incentive of a tax if you do not, but they have had very poor results—up to about 20 per cent at best, five per cent to 20 per cent of returns. So they are not getting the kind of return from their members that gives them any confidence at all that they will get everyone providing the tax file number. This is terribly important because this whole thing is supposed to be about equity but, if there are vast numbers of low income earners paying this tax, it is going to have very inequitable effects.

All employees at whatever income level will be adversely affected by the cost of administration that this measure will foist on the super funds. Estimates of these costs are around $100 million in the first year and $30 million ongoing. It is a tremendously high administrative cost to raise around $500 million, which is the supposed revenue from the tax. And that does not include the ATO's admin costs, which are also going to be very high.

Why are these costs so high? It is because the super funds have to gather and pass information to the tax office in respect of over 16 million accounts, just so that 355,000 higher income earners can be subjected to the surcharge. What an incredibly crazy administrative approach. Sixteen million accounts have to be processed in order to tax 355,000 people. It is just absurd. And this is from a government which parades itself as being here to cut the costs of red tape for small business.

The fact is that many small businesses wear the costs of their superannuation schemes and they cover those administrative costs themselves directly rather than putting them om the fund. And they will wear these costs and they are going to scream. They are going to say, `How does this fit with your promise about cutting red tape by 50 per cent?'

Through lack of time, I will not go through all of the ways in which the super funds bear these costs. But they are considerable administrative costs and they are going to have this ridiculous impact on the funds because what they do is reduce returns, therefore the fees are going to have to be higher. They are going to have to cover those higher costs by increased fees or reduced returns to members, and so you have an outcome where all members of superannuation funds, even if they all supply their tax file number, are going to be adversely affected, because they will wear those higher charges.

Also, eligible termination payments—that is, golden handshakes, retirement bonuses, redundancy payments—will all be caught up in this tax net. Of course, with redundancy payments there is an allowance for the tax free area which is, I think, $4,348 plus $2,174 per year. But anything over that gets caught up in this net. Many employees who have been sacked and then get a redundancy pay are going to find that that additional redundancy pay takes them into the bracket of high income earners. Therefore, they will be subject to the surcharge; therefore, just at the time that they get sacked they get hit with an additional tax, and then of course they are facing unemployment. And then the government says, `Hang on. Before you can claim any unemployment benefits, we are going to take your super benefits into account as well.' It is like a triple whammy—you got sacked, you got hit with extra tax and then you got means tested on your superannuation. It seems as though there is a vendetta against these sorts of people. This is surely incredibly inequitable.

There is also the fact that the transitional arrangements for golden handshakes last only five years, till 2001. After that, any golden handshake you get, which might be in respect of service that goes back 20 or 30 years before this legislation came into effect, gets taxed in full. It is real retrospective taxation. It is an outrage.

Furthermore, the way in which this legislation proposes to deal with unfunded defined benefit schemes is absolutely bizarre. An unfunded scheme of course has no annual employer contribution to tax, so what this legislation proposes is that such funds should for each member maintain a surchargable debt account, which will be calculated each year by use of a notional surcharge contribution rate obtained from tables currently being prepared by the Institute of Actuaries and agreed by the Australian Government Actuary and the Australian Taxation Office.

So the funds will be keeping these notional accounts—only notional accounts because there is no contribution while the person is actually in the fund—so they have the administrative expense of keeping that each year and putting an interest rate on it as well. And then they will inevitably find at the end of the day that it is not the right amount because the right amount can be determined only by the circumstances of the person when they retire. Whether it is voluntary or involuntary retirement, how long they have been in the system and so on will change the type of benefit they take. So just why there is a need to keep these notional accounts is beyond me.

Furthermore, these actuarial tables have not been prepared yet. So no‐one in such a fund, which includes many public servants and members of parliament, knows what the impact of this legislation will be, as the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) said. And most importantly, the government does not know, but it is bringing legislation into this House, saying, `We are going to impose a tax and we don't know what the impact is.' They cannot even tell us what the impact is on us—let alone tell anybody else outside in respect of these unfunded schemes. They simply do not know. So this is a bizarre state of affairs. What an incredibly poor legislative approach it is to bring in legislation when you have no idea what the impact is on those whom it is going to affect.

In respect of the parliamentary super scheme, the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) is saying. `Well, this might have an impact of around 13 per cent, we think. But we don't really know.' But there are calculations being made in the industry which say that this impact could be more of the order of over 50 per cent reduction in the end benefit. That is before normal taxation cuts in. So those calculations are out there, and what is the government saying about that? What is it saying to the public servants about their unfunded scheme?

It is simply incredible gall to bring in legislation not knowing what the impact will be. It is just incredible legislative laxity. It means the government does not know what it is doing, does not know what the revenue impacts are—because it cannot know them if it does not know what the impact will be on individuals—and it cannot say what the impact is on people whose lives are affected by this very legislation.

This tax will also have the perverse effect of discouraging many people from putting their money into superannuation, as the member for McPherson acknowledged, because they will see very little tax advantage. Indeed, there will be no tax advantage if they take a pension. That is because those subject to this new tax will be taxed at rates higher than the top marginal tax rate.

For those with funded schemes, the contribution rate will now be 30 per cent, there will be an earnings tax rate of 15 per cent and a pension tax rate of the marginal tax rate minus 15 per cent. So if you are on 48½ per cent, minus 15 means you are on 33½ per cent, but you have already paid 30 per cent on the contribution rate and then you are paying 15 per cent on the earnings. So what was actually in the fund is taxed somewhere between 15 and 30 per cent but closer to 30 per cent, then you have 33 per cent on your pension, and you are paying something up towards a 63 per cent tax rate. That is the effective tax rate that is going to apply in these circumstances—way over 48½ per cent, the top marginal tax rate.

For those with unfunded schemes, pensions will be reduced by this tax on retirement by the application of the 15 per cent surcharge and will then be subject to full marginal tax rate. Although the pension itself will be reduced at the outset by a process that I do not have time to go into, it will then be subject to the full marginal tax rate. But the full effect of that is that it is being taxed at way over the top marginal tax rate, at around 63 per cent. If you are going to be taxed above the marginal tax rate, where is the concessionality? Who in their right mind will take a pension? If you are going to get taxed at 63 per cent, why would you take a pension if you can avoid it?

As for lump sums—those in funded schemes—there will be 30 per cent tax rate on the contribution, 15 per cent on the earnings, a tax-free lump sum of up to $83,000 plus 15 per cent thereafter, which means that the tax will be at 45 per cent for amounts over $83,000. That is close to the top margin al tax rate—still some concessionality but not much. So people, after they get over the $83,000, will not see much value in staying in these schemes. For pensions, people will not see any value because they are going to be taxed at the full marginal rate. So why bother being in them?

We now have a situation where we have great incentives to get out of superannuation. We are seeing such articles as `Get out of super'. The message that the Institute of Chartered Accountants is having its member accountants tell their clients is that they should choose other investments over superannuation in the near future. I expect that will be a very wide reaction—which, of course, raises the question about the revenue. If they do get the money, it is much more likely that the money will come not from the high income earners it is proposed to tax but from the people who are the unintended consequences of the surcharge—the collaterally damaged lower‐middle income earners who are going to have to wear the impact through not supplying their tax file numbers.

Of course, the better approach to have taken would have been to pursue what the Labor government had announced in its 1995 budget, and that was to greatly improve the equity of the tax system in the way that I mentioned earlier. That would have certainly meant that we would have had an administratively simple scheme. The government, of course, could say right now that it is going to pursue that scheme. It certainly said at the election that it would, except that it maintained the right to vary the mechanism. But in fact the government has destroyed the whole way in which that scheme could have worked by taking superannuation out of awards. So the whole process of requiring employees to make contributions cannot be maintained now because superannuation will not be an award condition in a couple of years time.

Clearly, the government has in mind, in any case, using the second leg of the tax cuts not as matching co-contributions for employee contributions but by setting up some medium‐term savings vehicle which is not going to be superannuation at all. That will be less equitable, because it will be utilised mainly by higher income earners who have the savings rather than by lower income earners who are unlikely to put their money into such a vehicle in very large numbers. So equity is not going to be improved by that process.

With the process that we have here in this legislation, we have an administrative shambles of the first order which is going to be very inequitable, largely because of the approach taken—but not just because of it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McDougall, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened last night to the shadow Treasurer, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans), and in his typical fashion he trotted out the tired old story: it is not a surcharge; it is a tax. He then went on to a technical explanation that I am sure he did not understand himself. It was all meant in typical Labor fashion to scare and frighten the community—typical Labor tactics.

SPEECH.PARA: I can imagine the next bit will be direct mail letters being sent out to everybody in the community with misguided information which will continue to frighten people. Any further comment to the shadow Treasurer's contribution would be giving him, I believe, too much credit. This is obviously the way that the opposition is trying to object but not vote against the legislation.

What did Labor do in their 13 years with superannuation legislation? The member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) mentioned a few things a while ago which I will come back to. What Labor did was make it more complicated by continually adding to the complexity.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is less complicated?

—No. I will come back to the member for Gellibrand. They are the ones who have already burdened the industry and individual superannuation contributors with legislation that I can say the majority of the legal profession in this country—who look at this in a special way—do not even know how to read.

SPEECH.PARA: Many times I have had discussions with members of legal profession who have said, `Here are three passages. You read them, I will read them, and between us we reckon we might be able to work out what it means.' But at the end of the day they say, `No, it is too difficult.' That is Labor's legacy.

The member for Gellibrand referred to prior to 13 years ago and talked about the five per cent that was paid on lump sums and the benefits that accrued to people who invested in superannuation. Prior to 13 years ago, the former Liberal government offered incentives such as tax deductions for contributions made by an employee, and the member for Gellibrand referred to that as being not equitable.

The Labor Party comes to power 13 years ago and takes over what was a very simple and very positive system and gave people a great incentive to invest—and what do they do? They foul it up. They totally rewrite the act in a way that nobody understood, and they write it under the guise of a superannuation guarantee levy. Even they found another word for a tax: they called it a levy. But that is the part of all politicians: they will all find another word.

What did they do by doing that? They destroyed what had been a very good system. I heard the member for Gellibrand comment that it really wasn't such a good system because it didn't apply to low income earners, that it only really applied to high income earners and people in government employment.

I went into superannuation earning $7,000 a year—I would call that a fairly low income—in 1964 as an employee in the corporate sector and I have never been out of it since. Many thousands of other people in this country also have been in superannuation systems.

I acknowledge that one of the great tragedies in this country was that most superannuation in the early years was not offered to women. That was something that I certainly would not blame the Labor Party for and I don't think they would blame the Liberal Party for it. It was a problem of our society and culture of the day. That has been rectified and that is a very positive thing.

The question we should be asking about this surcharge bill is: whom does it affect? We continue to hear all these wild stories. Whenever you cut into the hip pocket nerve, the reaction is fierce and discussion is usually driven by emotion.

I too have been listening to the financial planners who tell me the administration costs will be formidable. I have had constituents of all shades of the political spectrum tell me they will look at other ways to invest their funds. Then there are members of my electorate who are fair game to the opposition when it starts its campaign to discredit government policies. These are the people who have been led to believe this surcharge will mean they lose all or most of their savings. This could not be further from the truth.

I come back to a comment made by the member for Gellibrand that 15 per cent was going to be payable by low income earners because they will not pass on their tax file numbers. All I will say to that is that members of the opposition and all members of the government through their connections with the community at all levels should be ensuring that that information is got out. It is an affront for the member for Gellibrand to infer that they will not get around to it and that it is going to be a problem. If we and the funds and the superannuation managers all do our jobs properly, it can be done.

The only people who will be charged this levy on their superannuation, other than those the member for Gellibrand has no confidence in, are those with an income of $70,000 and beyond. It must be clearly said and repeated that it starts at one per cent at $70,000 and does not reach 15 per cent until $85,000 and beyond. We should continue to say that. Don't just refer to it as 15 per cent from $70,000 because that is what we continue to hear and it is not accurate.

I also doubt if enough people realise that, for a PAYE taxpayer, this surcharge is only payable on the tax deductible component. Let's tell all the facts. Whose is the tax deductible component? If it had been prior to 13 years ago, it would have also included the employee's contribution. But the Labor Party got rid of that. Now it is on the employer's contribution, not the employee's contribution. This is the amount that the employer contributes. For the self‐employed the surcharge is only deductible on the component of their personal contributions.

We have heard from the funds and some of the financial world that the surcharge is going to cost millions of dollars—we have heard all sorts of millions. I say to that: rubbish. No‐one is denying that it won't cost some money. But what the financial advisers and fund managers are not pointing out is that the surcharge will be collected in the same manner as that already in place for collecting their existing 15 per cent tax on superannuation funds. Some adjustment may need to take place but a mechanism is already there. All they have to do is adjust their software programs.

The major burden of collection falls on the Australian Taxation Office. For the financial planners, who have established wide‐ranging self‐managed fund programs, very little change needs to be made to their current administration system. Let's be honest. Have a talk to them. Ask them what has happened to the administration of their funds over the last 13 years and they will tell you very loud and clear. The many administrative charges and compliances on them are some of the reasons that the difficulties already exist.

Let's take a self‐employed person whom this is going to affect. The member for Gellibrand made quite great play that the person who was self‐employed and running their own managed funds through a financial adviser was going to be greatly affected. Let's take someone at 50 years of age who draws from his business $30,000 a year. I will ask anybody to deny in this place that the majority of people who are in their own business, and who operate a self‐funded system, draw much more than that—and we all know that—because they minimise legitimately and correctly what they have to pay in taxation.

The same person at the end of that year throws $50,000 into their superannuation kitty, and they can do that every year. Of that $50,000, $38,000 would be a deductible contribution. If you add that $38,000 to the $30,000, you come up with $68,000. That is $2,000 under the threshold of $70,000. Where are they going to pay their one per cent up to 15 per cent on that? Let us not run away from the fact and deny that those sorts of schemes exist legally and exist right around this country.

What we are saying here is that the person who contributes to his or her own superannuation can take the $30,000 a year in salary, pay their income tax on that, place another $50,000 a year into the super fund, and they still pay no surcharge. It has no impact on the PAYE earner who takes home under $70,000 a year. I think we have got to keep being reminded of that.

I understand full well why the surcharge is unpalatable to many people. Any impact on earnings, savings or investment income is uncomfortable. But, if we are asking everyone in the community to tighten their belts, to help us get out from under the crushing national debt that was left to us by the previous government, why should those who enjoy incomes over $70,000 a year be exempt from making their contribution?

Those who are complaining the loudest and the longest are doing so through their financial advisers. I wonder whether some of those individuals would cry as loudly and as long if they understood the full story rather than the sanitised version that they get from their financial advisers. These advisers have let us know in no uncertain terms that they will discourage their members to continue with current superannuation and will encourage them to find alternative means of investment and tax minimisation. The member for Gellibrand made that comment. This comes as no surprise, and it should not come as any surprise. That is the business of the fund managers and the accountants. That is what they have been doing for their clients for years. That is how they earn their money.

I question how many in this self-employed bracket actually meet the $70,000 level. I would say that not too many declare $70,000 a year as a cash income. I am certain that, as I said before, most have already effectively reduced their income to well below that figure. The important thing here is that, contrary to what the member for Gellibrand says, low income earners and PAYE taxpayers earning under $70,000 will not be affected. I call upon the member for Gellibrand and all the other members in the opposition to be honest and to do their job and to ensure, through their communications, that they get people to file their tax file numbers.

During the last decade we have seen the widening gap between the rich and the poor in this country, mainly brought about by the last 10 years of economic management. We have seen what was once a solid middle‐class society being reduced today to the haves and the have nots. We have seen the PAYE worker pay his and her due amount of tax. As I said earlier, we have seen working women finally benefit from superannuation—a form of saving that had been denied to them for far too long.

Now, to protect the workers, to protect the savings of those who cannot adopt the tax minimisation schemes, to protect those who cannot afford financial managers to establish trust funds and self‐managed funds, we are looking to build equity. Until we do this, all of Australia will continue to suffer financially and therefore socially.

I am not the only member of this House who has called for simplification of our superannuation system or, should I say, multitude of systems. I will continue to agitate for review and for simplification. But I believe that at this time in history we have to face the fact that we are broke—more than broke—and that we are deeply in debt. That debt has been left to us by our predecessors. However unpalatable it may seem, we must make serious inroads into that debt before we can ever hope to generate the concessions to reduce levies and charges that we would all like people to receive. Today it is a case of those who can afford to pay must pay, and that includes all members of this House and the other House.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 November 1996 the Sunday Age carried a story with the headline `The news on super—not all bad'. I think that is at best an arguable summation of the superannuation bills before the House. While there are a number of issues in these amendments causing concern amongst superannuation fund members and institutions, superannuation remains a worthwhile investment vehicle in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: That said, I, like many other members, have reservations about the new tax—and let us be frank: the government is merely dabbling in semantics in calling the impost a surcharge rather than a tax. I am concerned about the impact the additional impost may have on national savings. I am equally concerned that the tax could adversely affect people not originally intended to be caught in its web. It is questionable whether this proposed impost passes the three criteria of a good tax, that is, a tax delivering equity, efficiency and simplicity.

Australians are not good savers, and many tax experts fear that the additional tax on superannuation will further erode our alarmingly low level of national savings. Home ownership is still the preferred savings option of most Australians, and experts agree that superannuation will not be used more than necessary unless people are confident that governments will keep their fingers out of a very tempting cookie jar. It is likely that many Australians will be swayed to divert part of their moneys into higher risk investments as a result of this impost. The introduction of the surcharge will almost certainly see a movement of moneys away from super funds and into equities and negative gearing—this at a time when they should be encouraged to provide for themselves in their twilight years.

A recent article in the Australian Financial Review reported that chartered accountants are advising up to 60 per cent of their clients to avoid this new tax by moving out of superannuation. Mr David Brown, the superannuation spokesman for the Institute of Chartered Accountants, ICA, signalled that as many as 60,000 people would be advised to consider shares, equities or negatively geared property as an alternative to superannuation. Mr Brown emphasised that this figure of 60,000 was a conservative estimate.

The superannuation tax is meant to apply to only 300,000 high income earners nationwide and is reckoned to generate $500 million in additional revenue for the government. If Mr Brown's figure is accurate, then one‐fifth of those who are being targeted by the impost will tailor their investments to avoid paying it. The government is relying on this revenue to help balance its books in the future. Its gung‐ho attitude will certainly see a further blow‐out in the national deficit if it does not review the administration of the super tax.

As I suggested earlier, the new impost fails all three tests of a `good', or at least a palatable, tax. Some may argue in favour of the additional tax on the grounds of equity, claiming that those who will be hit by the tax are those who can afford to pay it. This was the argument presented by the then Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short, in an article in the Australian Financial Review on 25 September 1996. He said then that in introducing the surcharge the government was acknowledging that concessional superannuation arrangements benefited higher income earners to a much great extent than lower income earners. However, the Taxation Institute of Australia, the TIA, makes the point in its submission on the super tax that the cost of collecting the impost from high income earners will be spread across all members of funds. Fund members could therefore be forgiven for feeling duped by the government, given the former Assistant Treasurer's commitment in October last year that with the introduction of the impost `there will be certainly no imposition on fund contributors'.

One tax expert likened this tax slug to the introduction of the fringe benefits tax in 1986 by the then Labor government. While the FBT was sold to the Australian people as a cost to employers, it is in reality a cost on employees. In this case, the cost of the new super tax will almost certainly impact on pretty well all fund members even though it is aimed at fund managers. While the proposed tax may only apply to those with an income above prescribed levels, the cost of its collection will be borne in part by those members of a fund who are not paying and who may never be likely to pay the surcharge. There is also the potential for serious inequities between protected and private super funds under the current legislation. To date, no‐one on the government benches has explained how the government proposes to levy the super charge against a constitutionally protected fund. As the law currently stands it cannot. This paves the way for significant discrepancies between the treatment of protected and unprotected funds. That can hardly be described as fair.

On 29 September 1996 the Australian newspaper suggested that `the lack of equity is the most damaging aspect of the surcharge'. But I submit that the issues of simplicity and efficiency in the collection of the surcharge are of equal importance. The Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Michael Carmody, has described the proposed method of collection of the surcharge as `an administrative nightmare'. When one considers the administration of the surcharge and the compliance costs associated with the additional 15 per cent tax rate that will be created, this description appears more than warranted.

On 27 September last year the Australian discussed the `massive deadweight cost' that will be created through compliance with the surcharge and indicated that much of the $500 million additional revenue will be `swallowed' in compliance costs—well, if not quite swallowed perhaps more than matched by the costs of compliance. The Institute of Chartered Accountants has branded the method of collection as `extraordinarily expensive and cumbersome' and has suggested that this method is being pursued in an attempt to avoid the surcharge looking like what it really is—a tax increase.

Mr Peter Foxten, the President of the Association of Superannuation Funds Australia, ASFA, is also critical of the proposed method of collecting the surcharge. One would have to agree that these people represent a fair cross‐section of the financial fraternity. Surely the coalition, which has made such a fanfare about its commitment to a more open, consultative and accountable government, cannot ignore those concerns.

Several alternative methods of collecting the surcharge, including the PAYE system, have been proposed. A Queensland actuarial firm, Buck Consultants, suggested that tax deductible contributions to superannuation be reduced to produce the same net savings that the surcharge is supposed to generate. The ICA has also supported the collection of the impost on the basis that taxpayers return their contributions with their personal tax return, which are subject to assessment. The ICA asserts that this would be a much simpler and less costly method of recovering the surcharge.

The Taxation Institute of Australia proffered several methods of collecting the levy which would allow the government to achieve the same policy and revenue outcomes by other means more efficiently. One suggestion is to collect the surcharge directly from the individual member or allow the member to deduct the tax amount from his or her superannuation account on the provision of adequate documentation to the fund.

Mr David Connolly, a former parliamentary colleague of ours, outlined a fourth option in the November 1996 edition of Personal Investment. In his article, Mr Connolly referred to the government's promised review of the mechanism for delivering the l-a-w tax cuts as a matching contribution on the proposed compulsory superannuation contribution up to three per cent of income. He predicted that the coalition will announce in its May 1997 budget that it will not proceed with Paul Keating's policy of introducing a compulsory levy to achieve the employee contribution, after receiving advice that that may be unconstitutional.
Mr Connolly suggested that the Howard government is likely instead to introduce a voluntary scheme which will attract a government co-contribution. He says:

The question of how the co-contribution should be paid and to whom, has created the opportunity for the government to review the front‐end taxation of superannuation and trade off the co-payment for the 15 per cent tax on employer contributions.

Mr David Connolly points out that this option would be revenue neutral because the tax on the surcharge on higher incomes could continue at the present 15 per cent rate and would not need to be increased to 30 per cent as proposed. He went on to say:

People on incomes below $70,000 would in effect pay no tax on employer contributions, and the government could still meet its budget objective of making the superannuation tax system more equitable at no cost to revenue.
Surely it would be in everyone's interest to simplify and combine these changes.

Surely indeed. Both the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Taxation Institute of Australia have expressed concern about the privacy issues involved with the supply of the tax file numbers—the TFNs—to trustees. In the words of the institute:

The current surcharge proposal provides the potential for breaches of privacy in a number of fundamental ways . . . Privacy concerns involve an important policy decision about whether funds should be held responsible for the security of information which was once solely within the domain of the ATO/taxpayer relationship.

The general consensus among tax professionals is that they would like to see the government agree to a cooling off period until further consultation with industry occurs. By way of example, I refer to an article which appeared in the Herald-Sun in October last year. It discussed the possibility of new self-funded retirees copping the surcharge if they choose to take a lump sum from their super, which pushes them above the $70,000 threshold for that particular year. These are not high income earners. They are people who have opted to provide for themselves in retirement.

It is absolutely necessary that the government define clearly all the elements constituting annual income before this bill is passed by this parliament. Although the surcharge has reduced the advantages of superannuation, it remains an effective tax savings option for many. But, as the superannuation spokesman for the Institute of Chartered Accountants has made clear, the impost has `exacerbated the uncertainty in the super area . . . additionally, it will eat into the benefits provided by membership of superannuation'. Ms Susan Ryan, a former colleague, echoed this sentiment when she said:

It would be a great irony . . . if the government allowed the garnering of additional revenue to achieve its deficit reduction target to destroy the long-term savings policy of the nation and jeopardise our retirement incomes policy.

Earlier this year, I received a facsimile from a respected actuary practising in the field in Western Australia. This professional woman advised me that her company had collected information on the number of changes to the rules governing superannuation since 1 July 1994.

She observed that since July 1994 there have been legislative changes, or insurance and superannuation commission releases, affecting the operation of superannuation funds once every 6.5 days. That actuary said:
This is a frightening statistic and shows the desperate need for some stability in the system.
She suggested that:

Everyone working in the industry accepts that there are aspects of the existing system which still need to be improved. This needs to be done gradually to rebuild after the uncertainty and distrust caused by this incredible pace of change.

The government has stated that this super tax will target a relatively small number of taxpayers, but many financial advisers point out that there is no longer any confidence in the community that others will not be targeted in the future.

Only two weeks ago, the Retirement Savings Account Bill was debated in this place. The government introduced that measure to encourage domestic savings by offering a wider choice of savings options to the Australian people. A fortnight later, we are debating legislation that is likely to dissuade saving because of the uncertainty the super tax has created.

Little consideration has been given in this debate to the impact that the super tax will have on the small business sector. Chartered accountant Mr Graham Connolly, not to be confused with Mr David Connolly, argued a very good case in a letter to the Australian Financial Review on 17 March this year. He questioned why small business owners were to be `penalised' by the impost when they take reduced salaries, reinvest profits and generate employment. Mr Connolly points out that it is only in their later years that these proprietors have adequate funds to set aside and provide for their retirement. These people who constitute the engine room of the Australian economy will be hard hit by the super tax.
Mr Connolly's argument is supported by Hughes Fincher Services Pty Ltd, chartered accountants. I received a letter from them dated 4 March. The author said:

Small business will be badly affected (by the surcharge). For years small business people take big risks struggling to make reasonable incomes. When they do, those incomes are often limited to only a five to ten year period. For the few years they can contribute to superannuation in a meaningful way, they will be penalised by high taxes on that saving.
This is how the small business community is to be rewarded for its efforts by a supposedly sympathetic government.

There is another aspect of this debate that has been conspicuous by its absence. It relates to the application of the surcharge to the proceeds of the sale of a small business where the proceeds are converted into an approved superannuation fund. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall that that is a promise of the government, although it has not legislated to that effect yet. I do not recall anyone calling on the government to make it clear whether the impost will apply in that particular instance and, if so, the date it becomes effective.

The proposed legislation suggests that the super tax will be applied to the proceeds of the sale of a small business if it exceeds the threshold amount. No wonder the government has studiously avoided any debate about that so far. I invite the Treasurer (Mr Costello), when he responds in the second reading debate, to come clean and advise the House on the effective commencement date and whether the super tax will apply in that particular instance. In the meantime, I oppose these measures in their present form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The people of Lindsay love this measure. They think it is fantastic. It means that $500 million of revenue does not have to come out of their pockets. It does not come out in sales tax, which is the way that Keating raised an extra 40 per cent off the people of Lindsay. When the battlers in Lindsay go to the supermarket and spend their hard earned cash, they are paying sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure means that they do not have to pay it in their income tax, capital gains tax, provisional tax or fringe benefits tax. Finally, the people of Lindsay, whose average income is around $40,000, or probably more likely $35,000, do not get to pay. They think that is pretty good. People living in Lindsay on $85,000 who have to contribute are a bit too red faced to complain about it.

The people of Lindsay are doing it really hard. We can sit here in Canberra and have a really good time in very flash surroundings. The capital of the nation caused the recession, but the people in Lindsay wore the recession. They are pretty pleased that the government is finally spreading the burden evenly.

It is not the unions and the leaders of the ACTU doing deals with big business. As you have seen, numerous members of the opposition have stood up and fought for the funds. I wonder what sort of party contributions they are getting. They are standing up for these big funds managers, saying, `Woe is me. We'll have a terrible time administering this tax, not to mention the 10 people we just replaced with computer technology.' Are you telling me they do not have the technology and the information systems to deal with this tax, that they are going to be so stingy about things that they are not even going to put in a bit extra, quite negligibly, out of their massive profits?

These are funds that you have to contribute to. Wouldn't the people of Lindsay love to have that job. They would say, `You have to come and buy from me. What a great job. What a great industry. You have to pay. They've got a guaranteed source of income.' Those opposite have the gall to whinge and say, `Oh, our costs are going up. We'll have to pass them on.'

I tell you that the people of Lindsay, contrary to the statements of the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), do not know a whole bunch about the share market. They do not know a whole bunch about negative gearing. They do not know a whole bunch about those complex things. This is the reason they pay a fund to do that for them. They expect certain increases, certain guarantees and a certain percentage increase in income from the funds. That is what funds are paid to do, and they do it very well.

BREAK.PARA: These funds have access to the latest program on the market, Wizard, which is guaranteed to get you gains in the share market between 14 per cent and 15 per cent. Another program came on the market recently. For about $2,000 you can get gains in the share market—guarantee 14 per cent since December 1995. These funds have access to those sort of resources. They are actually, once they get these contributions, making money.

The member for Curtin is exactly right. In contributing to a fund, an 18 per cent tax haven is available, not to mention what the funds are going to earn for you. If the funds are not doing that—if they want to talk down their own product and think that they are so lousy about it—then good. The people of Lindsay will go shopping. We will find another fund. We will find someone who is going to give us that 18 per cent tax haven, and more, on our input.

If you decide not to contribute to super and you pay your 48 per cent to the government and try to find a better return than 18 per cent plus on your money, I do not think you will be able to. Superannuation is still an immensely attractive option. It is still the premier option to take advantage of. A lot has been said about small business owners. To answer the member for Curtin: no, the incentive does not apply to the rollover nor to superannuation of $500,000 by small businesses. That has been made clear.

The only people who really seem to be affected by this are judges and politicians. And, boy, aren't they all terribly cranky on the other side. Politicians are going to be affected. The members on this side of the House are quite prepared to wear that. If the people of Lindsay have to wear it, we will. If the members of the opposition want to get up here and come out with mumbo‐jumbo and support the superannuation funds and the judges and then say, `Look at that—we benefit too,' it shows that they have no idea why they lost government on 2 March and the by‐election on 19 October. It is quite clear to me.

This is fair. Saving measures were implemented right around Australia in the last budget. Money was taken from all depart ments. That was spread right across the board evenly—child care, aged, R&D, the Public Service, Medicare, you name it. In this instance, all we are asking is that the funds pay their fair share. If they want to use their clout and their lobby group and say, `We are going to make it hideously expensive and pass it on to contributors,' woe betide them. Because, if they want to talk down their own product, no one is going to lose from it except them.

There is a lot mentioned about the constitutional challenge to the act. It is said that you cannot get the funds to pay the fund members' surcharge. The opponents to this bill are relying on section 51, subsection (xxxi) of the constitution to do that. That section basically says that the Commonwealth may acquire:
. . . property on just terms from any State or person for any purpose in respect of which the Parliament has power to make laws
They are hanging their hat on that clause, saying that, according to that clause, you are taking money away from the funds without just compensation. It is their money!

It is not the funds' money; it is the employers' contribution on the employees' contribution to a superannuation fund which has a responsibility to make a decent profit on those contributions so that people can rely on a lump sum or pension benefit to take them out of dependence on the government in their twilight years. The people of Lindsay do not want to be dependent on the government. We are as keen to save as the next person. We will do the right thing.

By 2030, we will have five million people over 60 and things will be looking pretty grim for the younger generation who will have to fund these people. Before I came to parliament, I had never been into a nursing home. All my grandparents were dead before I was five and, moving in the circles I did, which were from my own age‐group, I had not had a huge amount to do with older people. My first experience of a nursing home was an eye‐opener. You are looking at quite an expensive industry in terms of the enormous amount of care and the workers per aged person needed in these homes. Running a nursing home is a big effort and a very expensive task. We are going to have fewer people wanting to work in that industry—because it is very specialised and personality specific—and a greater number of people relying on it. People are going to have to take responsibility now for their aged life and fund that themselves.

All we are doing is encouraging that process and saying, `That is fair.' Thanks to the previous government, it is terribly complex to administer, and we should not be hampered in our wish to make these changes simply because it was already complex. The funds which are crying foul about the complexity now probably should have done so earlier. We should not be worried about making the measures we want to make because what has gone before us makes it so complex. Those complexities were already in the system.

We are asking for a minor adjustment—the collection of tax file numbers. Again there was a big cry from the opponents of this bill, saying, `But 20 per cent of the members are lost and the fund is no longer in contact with them.' It has been estimated that there are billions of dollars swanning around unaccounted for in the slush funds of these superannuation funds. No one is making a claim on them. What happens to those funds and the interest on them? What are these fund managers doing? It is almost a genuine requirement that we say, `Collect tax file numbers. It is better for you if you collect everyone's tax file number because, the next time that tax file number comes through, that person can be found, and you will not have lost 20 per cent of your members.'

There is also a terrific incentive now for people to give their tax file numbers to superannuation funds. If they do not, and they earn over $85,000, their employer contributions are going to be taxed at 15 per cent. They will be anyway, but if they earn less than that and do not give their tax file number over, they are going to be taxed at that rate. So there is a terrific incentive there for people who are forward thinking.

I do not think it is valid to patronise people and say, `They will not be aware of it,' `They do not know about it' and `Things will not happen.' Most people change jobs every six to seven years, and when they do they tend to change superannuation funds. People are aware of their superannuation funds. They are monitoring them. They are getting monthly or yearly statements from them and are keeping track of how much they are going to be worth on retirement. Everyone is aware of savings. I do not see it as being the problem. If it is, then this government will fix it. We are not inflexible on things.

The member for Curtin came up with numerous other avenues, ideas and ways for saving. But who is to say that they would not have similar problems? Who gave them the right to stand up and say absolutely that this is how it should be done? The point is that, whatever change is made, it is going to carry with it certain discomforts. It is going to step outside someone's comfort zone. If it puts someone outside their comfort zones, well, I am terribly sorry, but it is all about progress and the progress of the nation. And go forward we will.

The administrative costs should be able to be kept fairly minimal given the high technology and the software available to the funds. It is the industry that is complaining. It is the fat cats at the top who are complaining. You really do not hear the average person on the streets in Lindsay coming up and saying, `Listen, Jackie, about that superannuation bill—' It does not affect them. Yet we have seen incredible lobby power.

It is wrong that they should misuse their lobbying ability and come to government with such a mealy‐mouthed, stingy appeal and say that they should be exempt in some way from contributing to the almost $10 billion hole that has been left by Labor. All of us have put our hands in our pockets. It is about time that the super funds contributed as well.

We have had some advice on the constitutional challenge that is proposed. There are ways to reorganise the act, such as deleting section 34 and making various changes to the regulations of the superannuation supervisory act. That would get us around a lot of the legal technicalities that the super funds use to find a loophole to get out of their obligations. They can try to loop through loopholes as much as they like, but we will make the effort and we have the willpower to carry through with this legislation.

I do not see why the opposition are trying to score brownie points on a bill that they will be supporting. I do not see why they should still be trying to score points in that fashion. They must support it because it is fair. It is as fair as our work for the dole scheme. They came out and opposed that scheme but then realised, `Hang on a minute, the average person on the street likes it. They think it is fair.' All of a sudden we saw a backflip and they said, `We will go back and reconsider that and we will change our position to reflect something that is fair.' Again, they recognise that this is fair. They support it on one side but then flip flop to the other side. `Hang on, let us put up a weather balloon and see which way the public opinion is flowing and we will jump on that bandwagon.'

We on this side of the House have a vision to get Australia out of debt, to have some solid government savings by the year 2000 and to put Australia back in the black. We are well on the way to achieving that vision. This bill will play a substantial part in doing that. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Ms Macklin) adjourned.
