SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) claimed credit for improvements under his government in the conduct of question time. He claimed, with complete justification, that question time was no longer the farce that it undoubtedly became under his predecessor. Although debatable, the Prime Minister also seemed to imply that what now prevails in this place is the epitome of parliamentary reform. In returning to a time honoured approach to question time prior to the aberration created by Mr Keating, I put it to the House that it hardly constitutes reform.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the only one that goes any way towards improving the relevance of members in the conduct of proceedings in this House. The wide‐ranging changes promised to achieve that end have yet to materialise. In some ways, the influence of this House on the executive has diminished. Ministers responsible for legislation rarely attend second reading debates. The responses of ministers who deign to sum up second reading debates—which are almost as rare—demonstrate that they mostly have not even monitored debate on their office television sets. To those few ministers who do not offend in the manner described, I apologise.

Quite often, despite the presence of advisers, technical matters raised during debate, particularly in the detailed hearing stages, are either ignored completely or answered inadequately. Then there is the practice—prevalent under the previous government and almost the rule with the coalition—of a raft of government amendments to legislation already before the House arriving sometimes only a matter of hours before the bill or bills are to be debated. Is it any wonder that so much of legislation passed is subsequently found to be defective in one respect or another? These practices certainly do not enhance the relevance of this parliament vis‐a‐vis executive government.

Nor do practices which the government observes in the conduct of business before the Main Committee go any way towards bettering our relevance. Up there, only the most conscientious ministers put in an appearance. The government rosters chairmen of committees to witness proceedings on its behalf. Those chairmen are not even chairman of the relevant committee—just any old chairman will do!

TALK.START.PARA: —They're all good chairmen.

—Yes, but, of course, they are not authorised to and cannot respond to the concerns raised by members in debate. It boils down to this: the only improvement in parliamentary procedures under this government is to be found at the one time during the day that the Prime Minister is in attendance. So, while the Prime Minister can be justly proud of his efforts to improve question time, conduct of other business of the House leaves very much to be desired.

—Withstanding the test of time, going back to the early 1980s, Rutherford residents within my electorate of Paterson may soon see green rather than amber or red over the need for safer local roads. Last month, I publicly announced my commitment to seek funding from the federal Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr John Sharp, to deliver on the long‐mooted requests by local Rutherford residents for urgent attention to be given to the intersection at Arthur Street and the New England Highway, and calling for the construction of pedestrian traffic lights. A similar traffic hazard also confronts residents and motorists at nearby Alexandra Street.

BREAK.PARA: These intersections and general traffic conditions around the Rutherford area pose a stark reminder that words and more words, traffic study upon traffic study, and further community consultation can drag on for years and years, without a hole being dug or a RTA surveyor in sight.

This reminder is etched in the memories of both long‐term Rutherford residents and local business people within the burgeoning Rutherford shopping precinct. The commitment and drive of Mr and Mrs Lloyd Gregory has been something to behold. They have lobbied up hill and down dale for a better and safer deal for local pedestrians and motorists for many years now. I hope to make their efforts seem worth while in the months ahead.

I note, too, people such as Lyndon McLeod, who runs the local family pharmacy at Rutherford, Tom and Marie Bullen of Bullens Supermarkets, Ian Turner with his newsagency, and Rotarian Arthur Dawn, who has, incidentally, just been awarded the Paul Harris Fellow Award, are just a few Rutherford residents who are keen to see the light finally for a safe intersection at Arthur Street.

To my way of thinking, Rutherford shopping centre now has the unfair distinction of being one of the largest shopping areas of its kind not to have a working set of traffic signals to help regulate traffic and better pedestrian access to shoppers. That has got to change. The situation is even more disturbing when the very popular Maitland City Bowling Club, and parents and young children and teenagers utilising the nearby neighbourhood centre and child‐care centre in Arthur Street, as well as Rutherford High School, are putting more and more pressure on the intersection.

In fact, upon the public statement last month over my commitment to concentrate on lobbying for federal funding, this pressing road issue has again been raised to the prominence it has long deserved. Indeed, I am very pleased that, on this pressing local roadworks issue, Maitland City Council, which has gained some notoriety for some of the decisions emanating from its chamber in the last year, is 100 per cent behind the Arthur Street lights option, as outlined in their 1996 traffic study. Its own studies found that upwards of 155 pedestrians and cyclists per hour were crossing the highway during peak periods within the vicinity of Arthur Street.

The federal government is now awaiting the outcome of a joint Maitland City Council and state RTA study of traffic management needs of the New England Highway at Rutherford for consideration of whether additional highway upgrading could occur. Stage 1 of the traffic management plan for the New England Highway between Regent Street and Dunkley Street has been completed, but more work was considered necessary on traffic solutions for the stretch between Dunkley Street and Wollombi Road, including pedestrian lights at Arthur Street.

My fight for safer traffic conditions along the New England Highway, be it for Rutherford, Metford or East Maitland residents, will continue. My full support for a major upgrade of the Arthur Street intersection at Rutherford is part and parcel of that. A shopping precinct of this size, which underwent further expansion in 1995, needs a set of traffic signals to regulate pedestrian and vehicle traffic. That is an issue which my transport minister will be made well aware of.

I believe there is real scope for work to take place to install a set of traffic lights, and I will be urging the minister to examine council's position and the state RTA's position on the matter. Unlike the years and years that have passed by without the former federal government or the former Labor representatives representing Rutherford residents addressing the issue or coming to any solution, I am downright determined to do the opposite and actually deliver. I have taken the case for Rutherford residents right up to the minister, and I have an inkling that he is listening to their concerns.

The federal transport minister, Mr John Sharp, has responded to my request by confirming that he is waiting on the traffic management study from council, before committing federal dollars to any further upgrade. Arthur Street, as the main thoroughfare for the local shopping precinct, bowling club, high school and child‐care facilities at Rutherford, has been long overdue—since the mid‐1980s—for consideration of new road works.

Let's face it: name a shopping centre larger than Rutherford's that does not have effective and safe access for both motorists and pedestrians. For people like the Gregory's of Rutherford, their red‐light wait of some 15 years for a solution may soon turn green.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) is claiming that he is losing so much weight. It is not speed walking, it is speed talking that is trimming him down. Good luck to him.

SPEECH.PARA: It is said that if you live long enough you will see and hear everything. Even at my tender years I am getting to that point with this piece of correspondence from the office of the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp). It is a letter that has been written to Neil Hammond of Ferny Creek, Victoria concerning the fact that earlier this year Mr Hammond's house was unfortunately burnt down in the Victorian bushfires.

He wrote a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) requesting some relief for the reconstruction of his house—a temporary sales tax exemption on the building materials. That letter was sent to the Prime Minister on 27 January. A response did not arrive from the Prime Minister. It was sent on to the Treasurer (Mr Costello), who in turn sent this minor request on to the Assistant Treasurer. A letter addressed to Mr Hammond came back on 7 March and I believe it deserves to be written into the full record of the parliament and the Hansard. It states:
The Assistant Treasurer has asked me—
that is, Virginia Lo Pilato, the adviser on taxation—
to respond to your letter.

I sympathise with the situation that now faces you and your family. However, the Government receives many requests for reductions in tax burdens. To agree to individual requests would often only have a small impact on the Budget. However, if all of the requests were to be granted it would increase the budget deficit by billions of dollars. Such a blowout in the deficit would be unacceptable, as it would place pressure on interest rates to rise (thereby increasing unemployment and reducing economic growth) and would reduce national savings (and could therefore further increase Australia's foreign debt).
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
Virginia Lo Pilato
Adviser (Taxation)

The information is of no assistance to Mr Hammond. It is a letter of a mean spirited, mealy‐mouthed government that does not have the commonsense to respond to a request for compassion in sensible terms. There is no sensible response here. It is a response of the absurd. It is theatre of the absurd to say to Mr Hammond that his minor request for a concession on sales tax to help rebuild his home that had been burnt down will blow out the budget deficit by billions of dollars, will send up interest rates, will increase unemployment, will reduce economic growth, will reduce national savings and could further increase Australia's foreign debt.

The minister at the table, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), should have a word with his brother about this standard of absurdity coming out of his office. I have seen some economics in my day but never the economics of chaos theory. This is like saying that if a butterfly flaps its wings in Brazil there will be an earthquake in Western Australia. It is like going back to the old domino theory used in economics.

Instead of having the downward flow of communism into Australia, it is the downward flow of national bankruptcy: if a fellow receives a taxation concession to rebuild a house that was burnt down in a bushfire it will send the country broke. That is to say that if Mr Hammond sneezes Australia's 17 million people will catch colds. The office of the Assistant Treasurer is saying that if he builds his house one day the next day the IMF and the World Bank will be knocking on his door to blame him for national bankruptcy.

This is a response of the absurd. If a government cannot give a serious response to a family and a citizen who has suffered under the very sad circumstances of having their house burnt down then they should give no response. If they cannot give a serious response in a compassionate situation it is better to say nothing.

What sort of government is so mean spirited and absurd that they cannot write back in proper terms to Mr Hammond giving him a sensible response. Instead of having Costello-omics, we have got chaos theory in the economics of government policy, we have the domino theory—that one person's small taxation concession on building materials will send the country broke—we have Mr Hammond sneezing and the nation catching colds and we have him being told that if he builds his house one day the IMF and the World Bank will knock on his door the next and say that he has sent the country broke.

This is a government that is mean spirited across the board. It cannot even come up with legitimate, sound reasons to justify that set of attitudes. It has to go into the absurd. If this is the best that the Assistant Treasurer and his office can do, then they will be headed the way of Senator Short not too long from now and off overseas where they belong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am particularly pleased this evening that the honourable member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) is in the chamber because I hope what I have to say he will agree with. I want to raise once again an issue not only as the member for Groom but also as the patron of a local community support group for those affected by myalgic encephalomyelitis or chronic fatigue syndrome, a potentially disabling and chronic condition affecting the immune and central nervous systems. There is no known single cause, although for many it may be a viral trigger. Some patients may have a sudden onset whilst for others it may be a slow and gradual process with no easily identifiable trigger. It can vary greatly in severity and duration. There is no specific diagnostic test. It is a complex illness and the list of symptoms can be extensive and profound in the more severe cases.

SPEECH.PARA: Current research suggests that a dysfunction of the immune system and the central nervous system is involved. The complexity of the illness means that the prognosis can be very difficult to predict. Some patients will make slow and gradual progress over several years to a full recovery. The majority will make variable progress with relapses which may be severe and prolonged. They may reach 70 to 80 per cent of their former functions.

Others remain severely disabled with little progress, needing a lot of help with their personal needs. A smaller percentage may deteriorate and be bed bound for much of the time. Peak incidence appears to be in the 20 to 40 years age group with a slight predominance to females and cases, unfortunately, involving young children are increasing. Clearly, it is a very real and for many a very debilitating illness. The consequences of living with ME for the sufferer, the carer and the whole family unit need to be understood.

I again take the opportunity to pay particular tribute to two pioneering local Toowoomba women, Joan Sheath and Lyn Wilson, both as sufferers and as support group leaders, without whose persistent efforts the community group would not be what it is today.

I am pleased also that the minister and the medical profession are now starting to do something substantive about the problem and its associated research. I also welcome Australia's active participation in International CFS Awareness Day last year. Furthermore, I am pleased that a working group has been established under the auspices of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians with the aim of developing clinical practice guidelines for the assessment and for the treatment of CFS.

The working group has received a grant from the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services to develop and distribute the guidelines to all medical practitioners in Australia. This is a landmark development in CFS clinical management. The major task of the working group is to evaluate the rapidly growing body of scientific literature on CFS and to make recommendations to medical practitioners and to the community.

BREAK.PARA: The guidelines will provide a major resource for all concerned and will help to dispel much unfounded speculation and misinformation currently provided. A draft document is expected to be circulated to all interested parties for comment by the middle of 1997, and the finalised guidelines will be published as a supplement to the Medical Journal of Australia later this year.

In making my final comment, can I say that I hope that we have left behind unreasonable perceptions that this condition—that is, CFS—is a condition of the mind rather than of the body. It is undoubtedly a debilitating illness which we cannot and must not ignore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight in the adjournment debate to speak about the reconciliation process leading up to the Australian Reconciliation Convention, which is to be held from 26 to 28 May 1997 at the World Congress Centre in Melbourne. It is significant that this is being held some 30 years after the referendum which actually made our indigenous people proper and full citizens of this country and which addressed the outrageous racist history of this nation, which some would like to paper over.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to commend the reconciliation process tonight to all parliamentarians and, indeed, to all Australians because it is an issue which is important for all of us as a nation. It has never been more important, particularly given the climate of intolerance which has been fostered since 2 March 1996. In particular, we all sit in this chamber with the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), who has stated that she would not represent Aboriginal Australians. That is an outrageous comment and one which I do not think would have been tolerated had she mentioned any other group other than our most oppressed group, indigenous people.

The chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, Patrick Dodson, has stated that `to effect deep and lasting change in this country, reconciliation has to be a people's movement'. To this end, Australians for Reconciliation have worked hard all around the country with community groups and individuals at the local level. Their activities have been very much in the social justice tradition of thinking globally but acting locally. Reconciliation is a global issue. Its anti-racism message is one that must be taken seriously if we are to combat the narrow, red-necked views of the outspoken minority because it is still the case that indigenous Australians suffer from a great level of discrimination.

I am pleased that the Labor Party has put as our representative on the council the member for Banks (Mr Melham), the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. I think that it is unfortunate that the government does not have the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) on the council. The representative of the government, the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), is no doubt someone who is committed to the improvement of the lot of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. It is no reflection on him whatsoever, as I am sure there are many on the other side of the House who are committed to the reconciliation process and I congratulate them for that. But, nonetheless, it sends a very bad message that the minister is not represented on the council.

Also, when I heard the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on radio this morning, it struck me once again that he is a very good performer on radio and knows how to address his audience, but there were two sorts of addresses to the audience. When he spoke about native title, he said, `I want to address a message directly to the farmers, and I say to you that I will represent your interests.' He spoke to them directly, but when he spoke about indigenous people, it was indirect. He was not speaking to them. There was no, `And I say to Aboriginal Australians, I actually think that I am going to uphold your rights as well.' The fact that you have a campaign from some people in this parliament to extinguish native title is an outrageous attack on all of us, and I wish those in the government who have a more progressive and enlightened view on these issues the best of luck in combating it.

BREAK.PARA: In terms of the racism issue, as well tonight I wish to draw people's attention towards an ongoing community campaign against racism against indigenous Australians and, indeed, against racism wherever it exists. On 12 April there will be yet another rally in Sydney in Hyde Park against racism. It is being organised by community groups, by churches, by people who are concerned about the increasing level of intolerance. That, as part of the process of the lead-up to the reconciliation convention in May, is something that all of us should participate in in our local communities and all of us should encourage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received the following letter from a constituent of mine, Ms Lara Stevenson, which I would like to bring to the attention of the Australian people. It begins:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Hockey,
I am writing to you as a twenty year old female who is concerned with a problem in our society, which I believe has gone beyond our control. DRUG ABUSE.

I have never taken much time to deal with issues such as drug and alcohol abuse because it rarely concerned myself or family and friends, and I am not a person who is out to `save the world'. I am just an ordinary girl who cannot believe how available, cheap and widely used hard drugs are becoming.

Since the universities and schools have been on their summer break I am finding that I cannot go out on a Saturday night without somebody telling me they are on the `best high' due to taking speed or ecstasy.

When I attended high school there was always a group of people who smoked marijuana, whether it was everyday or only on weekends, I had a firm belief that they would "grow out of it" and were only experimenting. These people have now turned to hard chemicals to get a more exciting `high'. Unfortunately it is no longer a minority group taking chemicals, from what I have observed for myself `pot' is boring so everybody has now decided that ecstasy and speed are the way to go.
This habit has been justified to me by many people, I will give you some of these examples;
. Cheaper than a night out drinking. ($30‐$60)
. Gives you a boost of energy and therefore you can dance all night.
. You don't get a hangover.
. You don't get hungry.
. You lose weight.

Admittedly twenty year olds should be old enough and responsible enough to make their own decisions, however once someone feels the first exhilarating hit from a line of speed or an `eccy', they want that feeling again and although they don't realise, they're already mildly addicted. It affects their way of thinking, and they no longer think like responsible twenty year olds. This is not hearsay, I was at a BBQ yesterday and heard one of my friends say exactly this.

I work for News Limited, and I was working on The Daily Telegraph news desk the day Anna Wood died from taking an ecstasy overdose. Believe me, it scared all of us. Many people thought that The Telegraph was making an example of Anna Wood and that it was only a good story. Yes, it was a good story, because with Anna's parents and friends, the Telegraph tried to educate people on the dangers of MDMA. I originally thought Anna's death would frighten people and deter many from taking drugs, it has done the opposite, people think they are immune to side effects and even death.

We think the drug problem is confined to Kings Cross, Oxford Street and Cabramatta but it isn't. I was at a nightclub on Sydney's North Shore on New Years Eve, when two fifteen year old girls and their friends approached me, I was their babysitter some time ago. Imagine my surprise to see these young girls in the nightclub and then telling me they were all on ecstasy and wasn't it great. They assumed that because many people in the nightclub were drinking water and dancing they must have been on drugs also.

I realise that there will always be a drug problem in our society and there is only so much a government can do. Believe me I can go out dancing and have a great time with the best of them and I love going out with my friends. But how many more deaths, brain damage, accidents and drug overdoses do we have to see before people start to realise that it could be them next?

The purpose of this letter is to tell you, if you didn't already know, how severe this problem has become, and to ask you if there is a possibility of educating young people on the dangers of drug abuse. Why does education have to stop when we leave school? Most people start using hard drugs when they leave school, they're working so therefore they can afford it. I know of two people who use their AUSTUDY money to pay for drugs and alcohol, is this fair? In the end they're just hurting themselves. The television commercials for drink driving are so effective, they shock and scare people. Is this the only way to get through to our friends?

I am prepared to help in any possible way, but there is only so much one person can do. I propose that a new drug education scheme and tougher penalties for drug pushers and users be introduced. If it means saving one persons life or another persons sanity shouldn't we do it?
Lara Stevenson

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House—and in particular the attention of those members opposite—to something that they are very aware of, which is the fact that our offices are being inundated by people with problems. Those Australians who thought this was going to be a government to make them comfortable and relaxed are now finding out just the opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: We are finding out that the cutback in government services has meant staff in government departments are not coping either. I just want to go through some of the examples of the kinds of problems that are coming on a regular basis. A number of people have been in tears when they have spoken to me both on the phone and at my office.

The change to social security to become a more efficient system has meant that various offices have actually stopped the system of queuing by number, where they could talk to a departmental officer at a cubicle. People are now required to stand in a line and be dealt with one after the other.

I was speaking with a woman this week who spent 20 minutes in line. The woman is 65 years of age, with osteoporosis, but there were no chairs available so she could not sit down. And if she had sat down, she would have lost her spot in the queue anyhow. While she was in the queue she could hear the people ahead telling the officer their business. When it got to her turn, she did not want her affairs to be heard by all the people behind her, but that was what was required.

My staff have now dealt with the woman in some detail. The fact is that this woman did not have a problem. Incidentally, she had already rung up earlier and tried to make an appointment. The current waiting time is three weeks. She felt that she had a problem with her affairs which may have meant that she was frauding. She was extremely anxious, which was why she wanted to be able to talk to the officer face to face. When my staff then dealt with her in some depth, of course she had no problem. But now she has—because she is now very upset and very ill. And this is the kind of damage being done by those opposite who are talking about people being comfortable and relaxed.

A gentleman who came into my office on Monday afternoon has two daughters are on Austudy. He has a bankrupt company, but it is a company which means he goes through the actual means test. His wife has been told by her doctor that she can no longer work on the application because her illness, induced by trying to sort out and deal with the Austudy claims, is such that she can no longer cope. So now he is doing it instead. The fact is that these people are on benefits. They have two daughters—one at university, one at school. They are uncertain. Their Austudy has currently been refused.

A young woman came in who has an income of $20,000 a year. That got converted to $116,000 a year. She had her year planned out till suddenly she was told she was not eligible for Austudy. The fact is that those who are not eligible for Austudy are eligible for social security. And what is happening? They are being forced to take it. The savings that are supposedly being made are not going to be available because it will be another part of the budget where the spending will come from. We are going to see a cut and a saving in Austudy but, equally, we are going to see an increase in the number of people on benefits.

Turning to benefits, people put in their income declarations on a regular basis—every month, every fortnight—and it is absolutely exact, absolutely accurate. There is now a computer error. So one constituent this week now has a debt of $4,000. The department said, `Look, I'm sorry. It is our mistake, but pay up.' These are people with no money. The government will trumpet this as a saving—`Here we are. We have caught some frauds. We have saved some money.' Who are they saving it off? People who are impoverished.

You government members all know this because I have no doubt that you are all getting the same problems and in the same volume, if not more so. Because you are in government, I do not doubt that people will be coming to you thinking you can help. I also know how powerless you are, as your constituents are finding out. And what is tragic is that you have done so little to make any difference.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 March, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity of joining in the debate on the Trade Practices Amendment (Industry Access Codes) Bill 1997. This bill amends the access regime for the so‐called essential facilities. The amendments will seek to streamline the process for access undertaken by service providers, and are specifically directed towards the electricity industry. That is a point that was entirely missed by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) when he spoke yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will promote competition in infrastructure sectors by providing very substantial benefits to consumers, businesses and the overall economy. This bill is about responsible micro‐economic reform. It is about making the Australian economy more efficient and more effective, so that it delivers even greater benefits to the Australian community.

This bill improves on the access provisions contained in the Competition Policy Reform Act of 1995, and demonstrates our ongoing commitment to the national competition policy and our ongoing commitment, without apology, to micro‐economic reform. The bill underlines our determination to continue to cut unnecessary red tape and administrative duplication through simplifying and streamlining the procedures for improving access arrangements to essential infrastructure services in network industries.

Honourable members will be well aware of the election commitment given by this government to cut red tape with respect to small business. This is another indication of how we are continuing to remove unnecessary red tape, unnecessary duplication and unnecessary bureaucracy from part of the Australian community.

This bill will help establish a national, competitive electricity market. That is very important. The Industry Commission has estimated that the annual benefits through this establishment will be in the vicinity of some $5 billion. That is $5,000 million dollars, or approximately 25 per cent of the total benefits expected from the national competition policy reforms.

The honourable member for Werriwa referred to some last gasp amendments moved by the Labor Party in the Senate. The simple fact of the matter is that those amendments were to require petrol companies to allow access to terminals, but it is fairly clear that the amendments moved in the Senate and foreshadowed by the honourable member for Werriwa are nothing to do with this particular bill.

This bill, as I said a moment ago, is specifically directed towards the electricity industry. This government has a determination to improve competition in the petrol industry, and I will point out what the government proposes in relation to the petrol industry. Perhaps the honourable member for Werriwa and his colleagues missed the joint media release issued by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) on 11 December last year when the new approach by this government to the petrol industry was outlined.

The amendments which the Labor Party will seek to move to this bill, the amendments which they sought to move in the other place, are amendments which are nothing to do with this particular bill. It is simply using this forum, using the parliament, as an opportunity for point scoring. It is a cynical attempt to criticise this government's approach to petroleum industry reforms.

After 13 years of Labor government, the Labor Party has nothing much to be proud of in this area. The Labor Party did nothing much in relation to the petroleum industry or, for that matter, the electricity industry. So it really was a case of crying crocodile tears for the honourable member for Werriwa to come into the Main Committee yesterday and tell us that he is going to move amendments to this bill—amendments which are nothing to do with this bill at all. It is obvious that the 13 years of Labor neglect with respect to the petroleum industry have adversely impacted on the situation in rural and regional Australia.

As a very effective regional and rural member yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be well aware of the need for the government's policies and changes with respect to the petroleum industry to be implemented as soon as possible. But we find that it is very much as though the Labor Party these days has had a latter‐day conversion on the road to Damascus, and that its members have gone from being tariff slashers in the former government to now being, in this parliament, proponents of tariff maintenance. The Labor Party has no policy consistency, I suppose one could say.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is `New Labor'.

—It is `New Labor'. But I tell you what: whether it is new or old Labor, at the next election they will be rejected once again by the Australian people. The Australian people actually respect consistency. They actually respect honesty. They actually respect the fact that people are prepared to say what they believe in and to proceed down that line. Every time we open the newspapers at the moment, we find that there has been an about‐face.
—You know nothing about consistency. What about Fightback?

—You have nothing to be proud of at all. The Labor Party, the party which you support, has done an about‐face in relation to so many areas, and the whole reform agenda of the former government is being jumped, media release by media release by shadow ministers—

—Order! The member for Wills will have his turn in a little while. While I have the attention of the member for Fisher and the other members present, I point out that there seems to be an increasing tendency among members to try and speak about anything when debating a bill. This bill is to do with reforms to electricity, as you will see if you look at the bill and the second reading speech, and so I direct the attention of all members to the need to refer to, and speak about, the bill we are considering.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you very much for highlighting the point that I have been making. The only reason I was referring to the petroleum industry was that just about the whole of the speech of the honourable member for Werriwa referred to proposed amendments which he will be moving to the bill, in effect to extend the terms of the bill beyond the electricity industry and, indeed, to the petroleum industry. So I am sure that in those circumstances I am in order in referring to the speech by the honourable member for Werriwa, because he is saying that he is going to be moving petroleum industry amendments to the bill currently before the committee.
—I thank the member for Fisher and I advise him and the committee that we have not yet seen those amendments.

—They were, I understand, moved as last‐gasp amendments in the Senate. But certainly in this place, Mr Deputy Speaker, you are entirely right. They have not yet been moved, but the honourable member for Werriwa has foreshadowed his intention to do so. In doing so, though, he is suggesting that the Howard government is not interested in petroleum industry reform. He is suggesting that the Howard government is somehow welshing on its responsibility to bring about equity in the petroleum industry. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, nothing could be further from the truth. I mentioned a few minutes ago the joint media release issued by the Treasurer and by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism on 11 December 1996, when it was pointed out that the government would:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . implement new measures in 1997 to promote increased competition and benefits to consumers in the petrol industry.
The joint statement went on:

In responding to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission Petroleum Products Declaration report, the Government announced that petroleum products would be removed from prices surveillance in 1997, once the Treasurer is satisfied of pro‐competitive developments in the market. One of the measures required to put this in place will be commitments from the oil majors to allow open terminal access and price transparency for the purchase of petrol by distributors and retailers.

The amendments which are going to be moved by the honourable member for Werriwa in fact refer to access to petroleum terminals. So I suggest that the honourable member for Werriwa should go off and have a cold shower. He should realise that the government has reform of the petrol industry firmly in its sights. We have a statement made by two of our most senior ministers confirming that we are committed to delivering major reforms in the petroleum sector, consistent with our election commitment. The ministers have also pointed out that progress has been made towards this end, and that the government moves to implement deregulation `will promote greater competition which will lower prices over time.' So, after 13 years of inactivity, we find that, belatedly, the Labor Party has moved amendments in the Senate and will, in this place, move amendments to this bill, amendments which are entirely irrelevant, amendments which miss the point.

This bill is about improving access to essential facilities such as electricity grids. It is a reaffirmation of our determination to have responsible micro‐economic reform in Australia. The bill will promote competition and we make no apology for that. It is interesting that the Labor Party is not actually opposing this bill but what it intends to do is to seek to expand the ambit of the bill beyond the electricity industry, to which it is specifically addressed, so that the petroleum industry can be included.

BREAK.PARA: It would be more orderly for the Labor Party to wait for the reforms of the government to be implemented. The government's proposed reforms to the petroleum industry have received widespread support in the Australian community and I think it will be much better for the Labor Party to defer its comments on the petroleum industry until such time as the government continues to proceed with its reforms concerning that industry. I commend the bill to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Amendment (Industry Access Codes) Bill 1997 is designed to streamline the formal procedures for granting access to third parties to infrastructure facilities and networks of national significance by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. The bill proposes to amend the Trade Practices Act 1974 to incorporate a general industry access code approval process as a basis for access undertakings in network industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the current legislation, the ACCC has to conduct both a public consultation process for the industry code and separate public consultation for each access undertaking made by a service provider. It is considered that that is an unnecessary duplication of effort for the ACCC and for relevant stakeholders and could lead to difficulties for the ACCC in assessing whether separate access undertakings will achieve single coherent industry wide access arrangements.

This legislation incorporates legislation which was considered by Labor in government and I think accepted by Labor in government but was not announced. The proposals improve the efficiency of the access regime approval process, we believe, without diminishing consumer or service provider protection. On that basis, it is supported by the opposition. It ought to be able to simplify and streamline the procedures for approving access arrangements to infrastructure services in network industries and build on the access regime established by the former government.

Under these arrangements, third parties can seek access to services provided by essential infrastructure facilities of national significance. In network industries, such as electricity, the emerging pattern is for an industry code to be developed governing access arrangements which form the basis of undertakings to the ACCC by individual service providers.

This morning, I want to call for this industry access code to go further and cover the petroleum industry. The reason I do so is that the petroleum and electricity industries in Australia have been remarkably similar in their structure and performance—that is, an homogenous product within a vertically integrated industry with natural oligopoly features at the point of production. Their only substantial difference has been that we had public ownership of electricity and private ownership of petroleum products.

At a time when, under the banner of Hilmer and competition policy, state governments are vertically separating their electricity operations—generation, distribution and retail—why should petrol be any different? At a time when houses with solar energy units can join the national electricity grid, why should service stations not be able to buy their product from the most competitive source? Why should the Hilmer principles governing vertical industry separation and open access regimes not be applied to Australia's petroleum industry?

My colleague the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has set out how this could happen. He said that a starting point would be to declare petrol refineries and terminals as an essential facility under the access regime. The terms and conditions of access would then be administered by the ACCC. The parliament has delegated authority for these declarations to the relevant minister, now the Treasurer (Mr Costello), following a process of third party applications and National Competition Council assessment.

In the case of petrol, it would not be inappropriate for the parliament to make its own declaration, just as in the 1995 Competition Policy Reform Act it determined to exempt coal rail transport for a period of five years. Declaration under the access regime would represent the first and most significant step towards the vertical separation of Australia's petroleum industry. It should ensure open access to terminals on reasonable terms and conditions. Other aspects of vertical separation should logically follow, based on the competition principle that an access regime should involve more than a company simply providing downstream access to one of its own subsidiaries.
Importantly, I would argue that petrol meets the three criteria set out for declaration in the ACCC's access regime guidelines in November 1995. They are:
1. natural monopoly, duopoly or oligopoly characteristics such that, due to economies of scale, it would be uneconomic to develop another facility.
2. access to the facility services is a prerequisite for businesses to be able to compete effectively in markets upstream or downstream of the facility.
3. a facility of national significance, with regard to its importance to international and interstate trade.
The member for Werriwa has pointed out that an access regime for petrol will become increasingly important as the industry continues to seek greater economies of scale.

Each of the oil majors argues that the petrol industry in Australia is overcapitalised at both the wholesale and retail level. In its submission to the ACCC, for instance, Ampol argued that the industry should down‐scale. It talked about 30 per cent fewer service stations, no more than 300 depots nationally, no more than three or four refineries, greater use of pipelines to distribute petrol between capital cities and major centres, and one shared seaboard terminal in each out port. If you look at that situation, it would seem to me that this strengthens the case for it being covered by the kind of industry access code to which we are referring this morning.

I want to point out to the parliament that the Shell National Action Group has expressed concern about the direction in which petroleum retailing is going. It has written to Professor Fels as Chairman of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and referred to a transcript of a radio interview between Professor Fels and Neil Robins on 24 February when Professor Fels was asked whether he thought that elimination of what are referred to as the `Sites Act' and the `Franchise Act' would strengthen the oil companies' position to control retail and wholesale prices. In the transcript, Professor Fels said:
We have doubts whether the two bits of legislation you're talking about—the sites act and the franchise act—are really doing that much good at the moment.

We think this is a bit of regulation that hasn't really served a useful purpose. That doesn't mean we aren't concerned about Shell's move to have multi‐site franchising, but I do think it's unlikely that oil companies would try to take over and run every service station in town if the sites act left.

The Shell National Action Group indicated to Professor Fels that they differed with him on most of the points he had raised and expressed concern that, after the abundant industry information that they have tabled before the ACCC, he should take such a position. They go on to say:
The PRMF and the PRMS Acts—
the sites act and the franchise act—

BREAK.PARA: have most definitely served a useful purpose over the last 17 years. They have afforded an umbrella of protection for oil company franchisees who were previously, and quite often, at the mercy of the oil companies regarding tenure. Prior to these Acts, many franchisees were, at the whim of an oil company junior employee, given one months notice to quit their businesses—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am loath to interrupt the flow of eloquence of the member for Wills. But, as I did with the previous speaker, from the government side, I must remind you that there are no amendments dealing with petrol before the House of Representatives, the main chamber, or this committee, and that the bill we are debating refers to electricity. I do hope that the member will be able to direct his remarks to the content of the bill as it is, not to amendments which may or may not appear.

—The basis on which I seek to make these remarks is my view about what should be in this bill and what ought to be covered by the industry access codes, the subject of the bill. I do want to put a submission that the parliament ought to be looking at including petroleum as well as electricity and other things in relation to the industry access codes.

BREAK.PARA: It is my understanding that because amendments were moved in the Senate and because the member for Werriwa has foreshadowed his intention to move amendments relating to the petroleum industry, and because the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) has also spoken about these issues, it is reasonable for me and other speakers to take a position where we seek to expand the ambit of the bill and it is reasonable to debate these issues in that context. That is why I have chosen to make remarks about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what the member for Wills has said but I also maintain it is reasonable and proper for the occupant of this chair to remind all members of the need to observe standing orders. Please proceed.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Shell National Action Group has indicated to Professor Fels that they feel:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the remedy is not to repeal this act, but to strengthen and re‐mould it to incorporate modern terminology to prevent oil companies circumventing the original intention of this act. . . that is, to prevent oil companies from controlling more than a small percentage of their total sites, and thus controlling the retail price, as they currently have the ability to do with multi site franchising to the detriment of competition.
As franchisees, they have expressed concern about:

. . . the lack of protection afforded to us through the Trade Practices Act due to numerous constraints such as the cost of funding actions, the complexity of federal actions, the lengthy duration of any challenge and time consciousness of the system. The oil companies are well aware of this and it is only of recent times of agitation within this industry that a number of different branded franchisees have joined together to collectively take actions against their franchisors.
They go on to say:

The franchisees and the motoring public need these Acts in place. Without them the oil companies will control every franchised retail petrol outlet in Australia, as Shell have publicly stated, as their determined goal.
The oil companies are desperately attempting to have these Acts repealed. . .
and that repeal of the acts
. . . gives them more control and unshackles them from the very constraints which are currently protecting both franchisees and the public.
That is why I would express the view that there is a need for the industry access codes to be widened in the way proposed by the member for Werriwa.
The letter then goes on to say:

The true fix for this industry is not in repealing those Acts but in allowing all franchisees to play on a level playing field. If we could all have the ability to purchase fuel under the same conditions as Woolworths, that is up to 9 cents per litre cheaper than they are forced to purchase from our franchisors locked high prices. . .

Indeed, it is my concern that if the view taken by Professor Fels were to be followed then in many towns and cities there would be a Coles at one end, a Woolworths at the other and nothing in between—no newsagent, no service stations, no local baker, no pharmacist, no banks, no post office, and no motor mechanic. There would be just a Coles at one end and a Woolworths at the other.

We have a situation where downstream access is essential to fair competition in this area. We have Woolworths presently establishing itself as another vertically integrated major with access to cheap wholesale petrol and it is establishing horizontal alliances with other majors. Unless branded and franchised stations can also access cheaper petrol then they face closure at the hands of Woolworths. By making competitive petrol access a legal right, small petrol retailers would not need the resources enjoyed by Woolworths, rather, existing service stations in country towns, for example, would have the same terminal access rights as any new competitor.

This is not just an issue for consumers, the other part of this issue is the treatment of franchisees. I have had quite a lot of correspondence about Shell's treatment of franchisees. For example, one letter I had referred to Shell's `corporate thuggery towards its single site franchisees'. Another letter pointed out that under the multi‐site franchise system, any individual dealer who wanted to become part of this system with, for example, `between 15 and 35 sites would need capital of between $450,000 to $1,050,000 just to pay for each site's franchise fee'.

If you look at store stock levels—a realistic average of, say, $35,000 per site—then they would need another half a million dollars for 15 sites and a further million dollars for 35 sites. Fuel stock would be another $900,000 to $2 million. So for a 15‐site franchise, a person in that situation would need to raise over $1.8 million, and for 35 sites the figure explodes to over $4 million.

So, in those circumstances, it seems impossible to imagine that a multi‐site operator could function without Shell's active participation through a bank guarantee, and the only conclusion that the authors of this letter draw is that there is a strong relationship between the multi‐site franchisees and Shell and that, furthermore, 80 per cent of Shell's revenue and sales is controlled by a small number of dealers.

I have had information supplied to me by Charles Power of Holding Redlich concerning the operation of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act which does provide certain basic protection of tenure for lessee service station operators and requires disclosure of relevant information by oil companies to prospective franchisees. But it does not apply to commission agents or distributors, nor to resellers who occupy their own premises, and oil companies typically require service station dealers to operate as commission agents in respect of sale of fuel and, thereby, put such franchisees outside the protections of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act. So, the end result of this is that franchisees are greatly disadvantaged.

For example, here is a case that was brought to my attention. Back in 1980, Mario and Robyn Suprano accepted Shell's offer to operate Shell Wallsend in the Newcastle area as a self‐serve commission agency in return for which Shell would upgrade the site. In mid‐1989, the Supranos who were dissatisfied with waiting for Shell to upgrade the site, said that unless Shell gave assurances that Shell Wallsend would be refurbished in the near future, they would pull out of the site.

In October 1989, Shell showed them plans to refurbish the site. They were to become Shell Force franchisees and were promised 10‐year tenure in two five‐year terms. So, they stayed there. But Shell departed from its representations regarding 10 years tenure some three years into its term of franchise. In September of 1990, four weeks before the re‐opening of the refurbished Shell Wallsend, the Supranos were told by Shell that they would be commission agents, not dealer franchisees, putting them outside the protection of the franchisees act. They still signed an agreement which gave them 10 years tenure in three terms of three, three and four years. Shell said that they would only refuse to renew the agreement if the Supranos were consistently in breach of it, which they had never been.

In July 1993, Mr Suprano sought to renew the agreement for the second term, more than two months before his first term was up. But Shell did not respond until nearly 18 months later when they informed the Supranos that they were not prepared to renew because they had not provided written notice of their desire for a further term. Absolutely extraordinary! The Supranos ended up being forced to sign, agreeing to a 12‐month extension of the agreement and only in line with Shell's current policy. That is to say, there was no guaranteed tenure because their livelihood depended entirely on their being allowed to continue to trade at Wallsend. Furthermore, in March of 1993, Shell reduced the commission paid for sales downwards. These commission and royalty payment arrangements are extraordinary. An increase in litres sold, as a result of franchisees' efforts can, in fact, put franchisees in a worse financial position than those achieving lesser sales.

Other franchisees have also experienced similar treatment. Charlie Qasabian and Simon Totonjian have a Shell service station at Doyalson and the Greta Roadhouse on the New England Highway. After getting a letter confirming 10 years at the Greta site, they entered into a $90,000 loan to purchase the business from Shell. They spent $250,000 endeavouring to turn the site into a profitable business, but Shell refused to renew the lease after its expiry on 30 June 1996 and offered them far less than appropriate compensation.

So what we have are situations highlighting the inequality of bargaining power between service station operators and petrol companies. If there is any dispute the petrol companies simply cut off supply. As a result, there is a need for better legislation to protect both consumers and franchisees. That is why I support the remarks made by the member for Werriwa concerning the need to expand this area of the Trade Practices Act and the operation of industry access codes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur, Stewart, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), who I see in the Main Committee room, will generally agree with the thrust of my remarks. I am delighted to see such a large gallery.
—They knew you were speaking!

—That is right, they knew I was speaking, as the member for Fowler says. This trade practices legislation is fundamentally about competition, which the member for Werriwa would be very keen about. The Productivity Commission's stocktake of micro‐economic reform had this to say about competition:

SPEECH.PARA: Getting more competition across the economy is now seen as a key to better performance. It provides a powerful stimulus for private and public firms to operate efficiently and respond to what consumers want.
It encourages firms to search continuously for improvements in the way they operate, and is therefore vital to the process of productivity improvement through time.
Competition is also central to ensuring productivity gains are shared with the wider community through lower prices.

I entirely endorse those sentiments of the Productivity Commission. Regulation and monopoly and protection all encourage inefficiency and a misallocation of resources. Competition promotes efficiency and continuous improvement leading to consumer choice, better quality and lower prices.

Most Australians are familiar with the benefits of competition in the sporting field. As Australia is a great sporting nation, it is appropriate that the Australian economy should be based on the principle that all sectors are exposed to the rigours of competing with each other and with the world's best.

The sporting analogy helps us to understand the nature of competition—the way the competition encourages improvement, the way fair competition helps us to understand and respect the verdict of the umpire, and the way competition encourages cooperation between team members. The two concepts are not in conflict, as some people would claim. Nothing could be more removed from the Australian psyche than a desire to escape or avoid healthy competition. The most significant reform for the Australian economy over the past 15 years has been those reforms which injected greater competition.

Two fundamental reforms stand out: the lowering of protection which exposed Australian firms to greater international competition—I note that the member for Werriwa has been supportive of the general move by the former Labor government to a lower protection regime—and the injection of competition into a number of the sectors of the domestic economy.

Examples of this include the ending of the two‐airline policy—all members would be aware of the improvement under the newer regime—the entrance of competition in the international, STD and mobile phone markets through Optus and Vodafone, the reduction in Australia Post's monopoly position, and state government moves to open up the electricity market to greater competition.

I have had personal exposure to Australia Post's operation, and I say that they have become very competitive, both on an Australian market position and in comparison with other nations. I think that is because they have been open to genuine competition in some sectors of their markets whilst they do maintain a monopoly of the standard letter rate.

This bill is part of a next step to a policy reform process. The Hilmer competition reforms are also known as the national competition policy and it dates back to the special Premiers conference in 1991. Until then the focus of micro‐economic reform was on individual industries, for instance, the aviation industry, the automobile industry—which is now a focus in the current debate—the textiles, clothing and footwear industry, postal services, which have been the subject of a number of government inquiries, Telecom and higher education.

The national competition policy, flowing from the Hilmer report, is by contrast a national cross‐industry initiative. Broadly, the policy requires governments to undertake the following initiatives: structural reform of their public monopolies; ensuring competitive neutrality—a level playing field is a term that a lot of people like to use—between the public and private sectors where they compete; conducting a review of all legislation which may limit competition; and ensuring access to essential infrastructure services for third parties. It is this final element which is dealt with by this bill.

Under the Hilmer reforms, governments are required to look at the public businesses which have been traditionally regarded as natural monopolies. These industries, such as rail, electricity, postal and telephone services, have been traditionally regarded as services which only the government can provide. There can only be one rail network, one set of electricity wires and one set of telegraph poles. However, in the last few years we have come to question whether all these services really need to be monopolies and whether government really needs to be the provider.

Under the competition policy, governments are asked to look at the possibility of separating aspects of these businesses which are natural monopolies and those which are potentially competitive. For example, railways have traditionally been regarded as being the domain of governments because of their natural monopoly characteristics. In other words, it is uneconomic to duplicate rail networks, and thus competition between rail tracks would be wasteful and costly. However, rolling stock, passenger and freight services are potentially competitive. Just as private cars, trucks and buses drive on public roads, there is no reason why private operators cannot use public rail tracks and compete vigorously with one another.

By doing this, the natural monopolies—the roads, rail tracks, telephone wires or electricity poles—stay in government hands, but the private sector is allowed to offer services in the area where competition is possible. The greater the competition, the greater the incentive to raise quality, lower prices and give consumers choice. Competition between the STD telephone companies Telstra and Optus has had this result. Optus makes use of the Telstra network, just as different truck operators make use of the Hume Highway. This is the nature of what is called third‐party access under the national competition policy. The bill before the House helps to streamline the mechanisms by which access can be negotiated and the terms and conditions of access to essential infrastructure like telephone networks, rail tracks and gas pipelines might be determined.

It is pleasing to bring to the committee's attention that the electorate of Corangamite has been among the pioneers of private sector access to public rail facilities. In my electorate, West Coast Rail is among the first ever private passenger rail operator in Australia's recent history. The company negotiated access to the track between Melbourne and Warrnambool and runs a private service which was once run by the government owned V‐Line.

West Coast Rail now provides the only service from Warrnambool to Geelong, with three trains per day each way, and competes directly with V‐Line on the Geelong to Melbourne route. We have a situation where this privatised service has integrated into the V‐Line network throughout Victoria. So on the one hand we see the public monopoly position operating, but with the new West Coast Rail service providing a service efficiently and effectively, and saving the government some $5 million.

BREAK.PARA: The Victorian government was actually going to close that line. Now West Coast Rail has provided the service to the electorates of Corangamite and Warrnambool and provided a new concept of the way in which a private operator, owning its own rolling stock, might operate on the publicly owned track. We also see that TNT and the Specialised Container Transport Company are competing with National Rail on the standard gauge between Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth, which incidentally runs through the electorate of Corangamite.

Yesterday's Financial Review foreshadowed the possibility of the stevedoring firm Patrick's also becoming involved in rail freight operations on this route, which I commend as a desirable possibility. The Commonwealth's share of National Rail is set to be privatised, along with the passenger service of Australian National and its freight arms in Tasmania and South Australia. But the standard gauge rail itself will stay in government hands and will be run by Track Australia, a specialist track management agency. This is a clear example of the separation of the functions which is possible, even under the traditional natural monopolies, under the Hilmer competition reforms.

This bill deals with the rules about determining the terms and conditions of access to essential services, such as, the rail networks, electricity grids and gas pipelines where access is now being seen as an important prerequisite for real competition and, ultimately, lower prices. Under Part 3A of the Trade Practices Act, the relevant minister may declare certain essential infrastructure. This would require the infrastructure to be offered to those third‐party users, potential competitors, under certain terms and conditions. Alternatively, the owners of this infrastructure, usually the government agencies, may offer access undertaking which would set out the terms and conditions under which it would offer infrastructure access to new players. The undertaking would set out all the terms and conditions that any new player would need to meet to be granted access. This undertaking would be submitted to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. The ACCC would advertise the offer, take submissions from interested parties, and undertake public consultations on the process.

Of course, there would be industries where the access undertakings would be best done on a national scale. Instead of negotiating a series of different, independent access undertakings each with its own period of public consultations and submissions, it would be possible to have a national overall industry access code. This bill will facilitate that administrative change. The ACCC will be able to conduct public inquiries and take submissions on a national industry access code without going through the wasteful process of conducting a number of individual inquiries, consultations, and submissions from the public.

The glaring example of where this approach is required is in the electricity market. Part of the national policy agreed to by the Commonwealth and the states requires the creation of a national market in electricity. The national market will soon commence involving New South Wales, the ACT and Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Queensland? You'd better get on to your Queensland colleagues.

—South Australia will follow suit at a later stage and, as the Member for Werriwa says, participation of Queensland remains in doubt at this stage, so I accept the interjection of the honourable member.

BREAK.PARA: If there is to be a national electricity market then access to electricity grids in each state should be determined by a national industry access code, not a series of individual access agreements as submitted to the ACCC. The latter would be an excessively cumbersome approach. Thus, this bill will be of vital importance in setting the arrangements for the national electricity market. The national market will provide consumers in different states with unprecedented choice in where they source their power.

Once again, Victoria has led the way in this reform by splitting up the old SEC into an electricity grid which remains in public hands. There are six electricity distributors, all now operating as private companies, such as Powercor, United Energy, Solaris, and Citipower. There are also a number of separate and largely privately owned electricity generators, such as Yallourn, Loy Yang A and Loy Yang B, all of which can compete to supply electricity along the government‐owned grid.

Of course, if the private sector operators are to compete with the public sector on public‐owned infrastructure, then we need a competitive neutrality. Competitive neutrality really means a level playing field between the public and private sectors. Often, government business enterprises enjoy some unnatural advantages over their private sector competitors. Many have traditionally been exempt from sales tax and other government charges. Others have had the benefit of government guarantees over their borrowings. State and federal governments are now being asked to neutralise these advantages so that public and private sectors can compete on an equal footing. The Victorian government has moved to impose debt guarantee charges on major government enterprises to remove any advantage they may have from the government guarantee over their debts.

Another aspect of the competition policy is the requirement of conducting a legislative review. State and federal governments are supposed to look at any rules and regulations on the statute books which restrict competition. The governments must identify anti‐competitive laws and determine whether those laws can be justified in the public interest. The public interest should include a broad range of factors, such as, the social welfare, ecologically sustainable development, regional development and occupational health and safety. Thus, even the Hilmer reforms recognise that unfettered competition may not always maximise the broad community welfare in all cases, although there is concern that governments are exempting certain industries from the Hilmer reforms even before they conduct the relevant reviews of the legislation.

The National Competition Council, set up to advise the government on the progress of the competition policy, has already expressed doubts about decisions made by some governments. It has questioned the New South Wales government's decision to retain the existing arrangements for rice marketing. The honourable member for Werriwa and I would have some concerns about the monopoly position of that particular organisation; I have challenged it in the past. It has also questioned the ACT's shopping hour restrictions. These restrictions are the complete opposite of the Victorian government's decision to allow 24‐hour trading, thus liberalising the market and removing several anomalies under prior restrictions.

At the Commonwealth level, there are a number of industries which have also been exempted. The Wheat Board's single desk export monopoly is something that there is a considerable amount of debate on, on our side of politics, but in the broad thrust of discussions I think that, over the next 20 years, that monopoly position will certainly be questioned. The regional monopoly of local newsagents and the restrictions of home delivery of newspapers may be exempted from the scrutiny of the Trade Practices Act. Again, that is another quite interesting argument as to the monopoly of the newsagents that has been maintained after a considerable amount of debate on both sides of the parliament.

So the government needs to be vigilant about encouraging competition in all aspects. I notice that the honourable member for Werriwa is very keen on encouraging genuine competition between the oil companies and making sure that there is a fair and level playing field between the big majors and another couple of new entrants. I share some of those sentiments with him.

I conclude by referring again to West Coast Rail. That concept of running a privatised rail in Victoria is leading the way and other state governments might follow the example and integrate, in a sensible and practical way, the operation of a private company using rail track—either government owned rolling stock or their own rolling stock—and develop an integrated service within the total passenger service of the states or the Commonwealth. Then, over time, we can move away from this so‐called natural monopoly of railways which has been the mind‐set of governments and, I think, of the Australian people since Federation. So I commend West Coast Rail on its very good performance over the last three years in providing a service and, more importantly, providing an idea and a concept that the Commonwealth can follow.

I recognise the one‐track initiative of the previous Labor government in standardising the gauge throughout Australia and putting forward the concept that access to the standard gauge would then be available to private sector operators. It was a step in the right direction. I am very confident that the new Howard government will follow on and make more accessible the whole idea of using the national standard gauge, like the national highway system, for access by private operators. In that way, the rail systems in Australia will become more competitive, more efficient and provide better transport for very heavy agricultural goods to the seaports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my duty to respond on behalf of the government. As I represent the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) in this portfolio today, I would like firstly to thank all those who have contributed to the debate on the Trade Practices Amendment (Industry Access Codes) Bill 1997. One thing about this committee room is that we often hear debate in a much quieter and—
—Erudite.

—Perhaps a more erudite manner than we do in the House. I understand that this bill will be further considered in the House so it is probably inappropriate that I add anything further to the debate. I thank those who have contributed to this debate. It has been interesting just listening to those who were contributing to the debate. We look forward to further consideration of this bill in the parliament. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.
