PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 December 1996, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought for one frightful moment there that the minister was going to apply competition policy to the veterans' community. I think even my colleague the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) would agree that that is going a bit too far, but the minister held off. He flinched at the comments about the Wheat Board but he held off on the veterans, so that is a good thing.

BREAK.PARA: The Tax Law Improvement Bill 1996 reflects the second tranche of the complete rewrite of the income tax legislation embarked upon by Labor through the tax law improvement project in 1994. On Monday, I am pleased to note, the Senate passed the first package of three bills that commence the rewrite. Labor supports this legislation as it is essential that the large and complex income tax legislation laws must be simplified, hopefully to reduce compliance costs for both taxpayers and the tax office, and to take the opportunity to improve certainty in cases where there is currently a great deal of tax law uncertainty.

This whole process is necessary because the old legislation, the 1936 parent act, has been amended and expanded so often that it has lost an overall coherent structure. Because of the sheer enormity of the task, the rewrite has to occur in tranches. This ongoing rewrite process, piece by piece, provides its own challenges as it is not possible to repeal the entirety of the 1936 act and replace it in total. Labor does not criticise this process. Naturally enough, we understand it is the only realistic option.

However, this process has produced some disquiet in some sections of the industry. There is a variety of opinions. Some believe that there should be absolutely no policy changes at all in the rewrite. For example, Price Waterhouse, as reported in the Financial Review in October last year, argues that the resources of the tax law improvement program should be redirected towards a tax reform task force—that is, change policy first and then rewrite the legislation.

Clearly, Labor favours the current process which we instigated when in government. The Assistant Treasurer has the authority to make some small limited changes, especially to clarify the tax laws. However, this process should not be used to significantly alter policy more or less through the backdoor. Labor initially understood that the government agreed with this policy neutral project. However, this legislation, as introduced to the parliament, goes beyond a simple and neutral rewrite role.

This particular tranche is being rewritten to address matters concerning assessable and exempt income, deductions, trading stock, depreciation and gifts. The more specialised areas include entertainment expenses and primary production. As with earlier bills, this bill was sent to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for consideration. The committee's report on the legislation, No. 348, was tabled in the House on 6 March. I am pleased to see in the chamber the chair of that committee, Mr Somlyay. I pay tribute to the work of his committee in the rewrite project because, in the parliamentary scrutiny, the rewrite brings forth a whole range of very complex and detailed matters in our taxation laws. To have a joint committee that so capably gets across all the detail and complexity, and provides due parliamentary scrutiny to the project, is absolutely critical.

From time to time, there is too little public appreciation of the active role of committees such as the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in that parliamentary scrutiny. It is a very good thing that we have a committee that is well‐led, well-resourced, and very active in making sure that the work of the tax officials in the rewrite project, and the involvement of the private sector, receives due parliamentary scrutiny. I pay tribute to the work and the report of the joint committee in that regard.

I also endorse the way in which the committee appreciates that the best type of rewrite is a policy neutral rewrite. I note its concerns about the significant policy changes proposed within the bill. In particular, a concern arises about the proposed alteration of the depreciation provisions concerning hire purchase transactions, and the proposed alterations to the trading stock provisions where assets change their character from normal business assets into trading stock, and vice versa.

There is also a large number of minor technical amendments to ensure that the bill accurately reflects the existing law. Accordingly, the government has circulated numerous amendments; 83 in total. The opposition will not oppose any of these amendments. However, while being supportive of the project, we are concerned about the volume of amendments being presented to the parliament, and I am sure that that concern is supported by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and its chairperson. Perhaps part of the problem relates to the resourcing of the tax law improvement program. A vacancy has existed in one of the two private sector positions within the program since December 1995, 18 months ago—a vacancy for private sector resources to the program—and I note that the joint parliamentary committee has expressed concern about this delay.

The joint committee has also suggested that additional resources be made available for the hiring, on a short‐term basis, of private sector experts in particular areas to supplement the general program team. Labor supports this recommendation wholeheartedly. I note with concern, however, the cost to the public interest of the inadequate resourcing of a core government function—that of the major revenue authority, the Tax Office—and of private sector resources being harnessed for this particular program. I urge the government to take corrective action as soon as possible.

It is an important point that too often in the public commentary, and too often under this government's budget management, it is assumed that every single budget cut and every single reduction in public resourcing is a good thing. But, clearly, the private sector can suffer much greater costs than the small public costs that are being saved. The cost to the private sector—to the accountancy and tax law industries and the small business sector, in particular—of delaying this tax improvement project is immense.

For the government not to have filled a vacancy for some 18 months in the private sector resources that can be harnessed for the project really is an opportunity cost of folly. It is far better to resource this program fully, get the rewrite happening as fast as possible, have it approved by the parliament under the scrutiny of the joint committee, and allow certainty and simplicity to take hold in the tax law industry around Australia and in the understanding of those laws by private citizens and the private sector, particularly small businesses. The government needs to act on the recommendations of the joint committee to give this rewrite process full and adequate public sector resourcing. Other than making those comments, I will say that Labor will be supporting this bill and the circulated amendments, and we look forward to the further success of the rewrite program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few observations, especially after reading the second reading speech by the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles), in which he said that the 1936 act was `on the verge of collapsing under the weight of 60 years of constant and largely piecemeal amendment.' I have spoken to accountants about the income tax act, and they all say the same thing: it has become so heavy to lift that some of the staff are looking at putting in claims for back problems. It is about time it was reviewed and rewritten to make the act shorter, easier to understand, and with as few loopholes as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to pay tribute, as the former speaker did, to Mr Somlyay, who was here beside me today as Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I am advised that both New Zealand and Britain have a strong interest in looking at this project and undertaking to look at what they can do to amend their tax laws in line with the changes that we are proposing to make. That is a great tribute to Mr Somlyay and his committee, who have reviewed the bill.

The rewritten areas that, in particular, I want to talk about are the areas that cover expenses, primary production deductions, the recoupment of deductible expenses and the sale of leased cars. I am advised by the accountants that I have spoken to about these issues that these are the issues that are most open to debate. As a result of that, of course, it costs the taxpayer money to have the matters resolved and costs the taxation department time, effort and money in trying to determine who is right and who is not right and in trying to interpret the intention of the act.

I want to mention five points in particular. They are minor policy changes and I note that these changes have the support of the opposition. The five specific points that will make it easier, simpler and less burdensome for the taxpayer are: replacing the rules with which one facilitates taxpayer compliance; simplifying the rules which are unnecessarily complex; deleting unnecessary rules; removing anomalies; and clarifying ambiguities. Anyone who has anything to do with the income tax act will be very pleased that these changes will occur.

The only other thing I would like to mention is that this will have no impact on revenue. It is basically a broadly neutral impact on revenue. It is about time that this has been tackled and, as I said, I want to pay tribute to Mr Somlyay and his committee for reviewing the changes and for making this possible. It will, in time, save us all a lot of time, money and effort and the taxpayers of Australia will be very pleased with these changes, not to mention the accountants, and those who go to them to seek advice and to understand the interpretations of the act, which have become very complex.

I know in one particular case—my own case—I have sought a clarification from the Australian Taxation Office on matters that my accountant and I would like to dispute, and we have asked them for an interpretation of the act. We chose not to put in my tax return and to say that we have taken the deductions. If the ATO disagrees, they should advise us accordingly. We have decided that the best thing we can do is to ask for a clarification of the matters and then we will put in an amended return. It has now been close enough to six months and we still have not had a response from the Australian Taxation Office. I can understand the difficulty of the complexity in which they find themselves, trying to interpret something that should have been cleared up a long time ago. I fully support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing new about calls for a substantial overhaul of our surfeit of tax legislation. What is different is that this message is now being driven, not only by industry and employer groups which have long championed tax reform, but also by social welfare groups, including the Australian Council of Social Service.

SPEECH.PARA: The government finds itself in a position a little like Aladdin, inasmuch as the tax reform genie has been released from the bottle and simply will not go away. While the government has chosen to continue to grant two wishes, that is the rewriting and renumbering of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the clarification of ambiguities, it has, as its predecessor in government did, baulked at the third and unarguably most critical wish, and that is an overhaul of our byzantine tax policy. We are left, Mr Deputy Speaker, to tiptoe through the TLIPs, without even a suggestion of falsetto help from Tiny Tim.

This bill is the second instalment of legislation to result from the tax law improvement project, which was established by the former Labor government on 1 July 1994. It deals with the rewrite of deductions, trading stock, accessible and exempt income and depreciation and gift provisions in the principal act.

My support for the efforts being made by the tax law improvement project team is qualified. However, I reaffirm my belief that it is absolutely essential that the terms of reference for this project should be extended by the government to include and allow for a review of some policy matters.

The progress to date by the project team is not really significant. It is a start, but nothing more. There should be absolutely no easing of pressure on this parliament to implement substantive changes to tax legislation. It is very clear that this country needs a bipartisan commitment to total tax reform if it is to remain competitive in an increasingly globalised economy. Moreover, the commitment must be to rapid but thoughtful change.

If the current rate of progress by the tax law improvement project is anything to go by, it will be something like 25 to 30 years before the rewrite is complete, given that there is no major rewrite or change to policy in the meantime. That is plainly unacceptable.

One of the criticisms being levelled against the current rewrite of corporations legislation is the length of time involved. Mr Richard Humphry, Managing Director of the Stock Exchange, recently commented that the simplification of the existing laws was not solving the problem because the corporations legislation needed to be rewritten from scratch. He suggested that `Corporations Law would not stand up to any form of competitive analysis against international law.'

Mr Humphry concluded by saying that the corporate law simplification project was progressing at the speed of an old-fashioned steamer while the global marketplace operates at an electronic level of speed. His comments might apply to the TLIP project.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts, in its recent report into the tax law improvement project, revealed an opposing anxiety. It stated that it was concerned that `TLIP's process may be suffering in the rush to have legislation introduced into the parliament.'
The committee chairman, the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), went on to say:
The committee has not had time to review the bill as comprehensively as it would have liked.

The committee acknowledged that while the mass of the second instalment of TLIP had been embraced in general terms, there were two divisions that had earned strong criticism by tax experts. It indicated that the government would have to `schedule sufficient time for parliamentary debate and review of the next tranche of legislation,' to ensure meaningful consultation and scrutiny in the tax law improvement project in future.

The government would do well to heed the advice of the JCPA, given that the government went to the last election on a platform of improved levels of consultation and accountability. It is of real concern that the JCPA is unhappy with the amount of time it has had to liaise with tax professionals on this instalment of TLIP.

It seems to me that an imbalance now exists between allowing for adequate consultation and the timely delivery of TLIP. If the government cannot strike a balance for the simple renumbering and rewriting of 16 divisions in the tax act, how does it expect to assure the community that real tax reform will be dealt with in a decisive manner?

The Financial Review reported on 28 May 1996 that Australia's international competitiveness had deteriorated over the previous year, and cited our weak performance in the category of internationalisation as particularly alarming. Six months later another report found that Australia was losing ground because of relatively high taxes.

An improved structure, simpler language and a better numbering system are certainly a step in the right direction in terms of tax reform. But this is at best a partial solution. It is merely another example of treating the symptoms rather than effecting a cure. So while the member for Braddon (Mr Miles), in his speech during the second reading debate, talked about the benefits of reduced compliance and administration costs that business can expect to enjoy because of the tax law improvement project charter, I seek to remind him and others that tax experts are far less effusive when it comes to the project.
As Mr Geoffrey Lehmann, a partner of Price Waterhouse, was reported in the Australian of 5 July last year to have said, the tax law improvement project:
. . . is an attempt to simplify the language and arrangement of tax legislation, while doing nothing to change the underlying complexity of tax laws that cause the real problems for taxpayers.

In a nutshell, plain English and improved drafting are not in themselves a substitute for simpler tax law with lower compliance costs. True simplification of the tax system is linked inextricably to a review of tax policy.

The JCPA made explicit its view on this matter. Its second recommendation stated that the TLIP should have its terms of reference expanded by the government to allow it to consider a wider range of tax policy simplification issues. Section 3.6 of the JCPA report reads:

The committee had received considerable evidence that unclear or unworkable sections of the 1936 act are being perpetuated in the bill because changing them is beyond TLIP's very limited mandate to make policy changes.

By ruling out any review of tax policy, at least in its first term, the current government, like its predecessor, has made it clear that it will not make the wide ranging changes to the tax system that are needed to make it as simple, fair and economically efficient as possible.

The Taxation Institute of Australia presented a paper at the 1996 tax summit titled `The quintessential tax system, reform: the impossible dream'. In it the TIA argued that, for a tax system to achieve the three essential goals of simplicity, equity and efficiency:

A tax system in its design, legislation and administration, ought to be able to be complied with by ordinary taxpayers, having regard to the complexity of his/her affairs, without resort to professional assistance.
It is an indictment of our income tax system that approximately 70 per cent of individual taxpayers now turn to tax professionals each year to prepare their income tax returns.
The Industry Commission's Office of Regulatory Review noted, in a report released in July 1996:
It would not be surprising if broad surveys of compliance costs or attitudes to the tax system fail to show major falls in tax compliance costs after the tax law improvement project is complete.
This was a government instrumentality predicting that the four years, millions of dollars and countless man‐hours pumped into the hallowed tax law improvement project could be for naught.

At the same time, the JCPA concluded that TLIP's rewrite will go only halfway to meeting the goal of the simplification of the 1936 act because of its narrow mandate. It said that the cost of compliance, and the burden of administration of the tax law, will not be reduced until the Commonwealth and state governments commit themselves to a `comprehensive review of tax policy'.

Is it any wonder that two presenters at the 1996 tax summit referred to Australia's tax reform process as being almost entirely captured by the bureaucracy. Messrs Phillip Anderson and Richard Vann assert that Australia is desperate for an independent inquiry into the entire tax system. They argue convincingly that, until this occurs, the past practice of legislating ad hoc changes to a system that is ill‐equipped to sustain them will continue. As far as they are concerned, the tax law improvement project `demonstrates over and over again, we will not get the fundamental review of the income tax act that is absolutely necessary . . . while the tax policy process remains the preserve of a bureaucracy' obsessed with tax avoidance.

Soon after the election of the coalition government, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) went on record as saying that those on the right side of the House recognised that small business was the engine room of the Australian economy. He said that the coalition would make things `a darn sight better' for small business than did his Labor Party predecessor. The centrepiece of this commitment was the establishment of the small business deregulation task force. In December last, the task force released 62 recommendations on how the government should reduce the compliance burden on the small business sector. Many of these proposals were reliant on an overhaul of the fringe benefits and wholesale sales tax systems.

Likewise, in a joint submission to the government on the tax law improvement project, the TIA, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Society of Certified Practising Accountants have made it clear that plans to cut business compliance costs could not be addressed without substantial reform to the capital gains tax. As for the coalition commitment to reducing the paperwork burden on small businesses by half, in February last year the Business Review Weekly had this to say:

The unanimous view is that a 50% reduction can be achieved only if the legislation that caused the paperwork—primarily tax legislation—is overhauled. Tinkering at the edges, getting rid of one form here and another form there, will not even come close to achieving the coalition's promised revenue‐ neutral 50% reduction.

The small business deregulation task force makes no reference in its report to the positive impact that the tax law improvement project will have on small business, because it sees it for what it is: yet another fits and starts attempt at questionable reform.
At a tax summit, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the ACCI, warned the then Labor government about the danger to small business of tokenism in the tax reform process. It said:
Piecemeal action should be avoided at all costs. This is the fundamental flaw we have faced since the wheels fell off the tax reform cart 10 years ago.
The lack of true tax reform, the representative of ACCI went on to say:
. . . is why small businesses in particular are feeling alienated and under siege from compliance imposts which have been calculated as worst than virtually any other country in the world.
It would seem that neither the former Labor government nor the current coalition government have heeded that warning.

While the minister for small business may bleat about promises kept, including changes to capital gains tax rollover relief, it is worth while remembering that this came at the price of what one tax professional described as 25 pages of `brain numbing legislative amendments'. In the words of Mr Graeme Samuel, the President of the ACCI, `Why does the tax office invest millions of dollars in a tax law improvement project if it cannot staunch the flow of legislative gobbledegook' in one particular amendment.

The ACCI made it clear that consecutive government reviews have accentuated the anti‐competitive ramifications of the current tax system on Australia's small businesses. It stated that one of the key strategies to shoring up business confidence was for the three levels of government to reach agreement on a process to overhaul revenue raising systems. It would seem that business is going to have to continue to wait for the government to bite the bullet. The question is: how long can business afford to wait, given that the economy continues to remain somewhat flat and bankruptcies in the small business sector are at an all‐time high? Not much longer, I would suggest.

It is worth noting that the TLIP senior management team includes two positions for private sector practitioners. One of these positions has been vacant for approximately 15 months. The whole point of having these two positions is to ensure that TLIP considers as wide a range of perspectives as possible when considering the simplification of our tax legislation. The positions exist to ensure that the business community has an opportunity to contribute to this essential process. The JCPA report recommended that the government fill this position `as a matter of urgency.' I also understand that the TLIP team has written to the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) requesting that this second private sector position be filled immediately. To date the government seems to have ignored that request. So much for the coalition's commitment to the private sector; so much for the government's promise to consult widely in an effort to stay in touch with industry's needs.

While some groups, including the AICD Taxation and Economics Committee, have called for `sweeping reform' to the Australian tax system, others have supported a more cautious approach. For example, Mr Robert Fitzgerald, the President of ACOSS, has said that Australia is in need of `genuine and progressive tax reform.' Tax experts have variously dubbed the income tax act as a super nova—a star bloated and about to implode—or as a gothic mansion to which new additions are constantly made without consideration as to whether the foundations can support them. Whatever the language used, the message is plain and simple: this parliament cannot back away from its responsibility to implement an efficient, simple and equitable tax system.
I conclude by quoting an editorial from the Australian of 4 September 1996 which sums up very succinctly the road ahead for tax reform in this country. It states:

. . . it is also inescapably true that the contorted and unresponsive nature of the current system is the product of a half century of tinkering . . . A suitably independent inquiry, with broad, sensible terms of reference and adequate time to consult and consider . . . might well be the best remaining opportunity for an Australian government to achieve an honestly negotiated, worthwhile and electorally acceptable tax reform package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Tax Law Improvement Project Bill, I say that there is a fairly hackneyed phrase that there is nothing more certain in life than death and taxes. What should be tacked onto that phrase is that nothing has been more certain in recent years than continuous additions to the Income Tax Assessment Act. The phrases that have been used expansively and colourfully over a number of years are certainly very appropriate. I am indebted to the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) for some remarks that he has made. In general, I agree with what he says. He did speak about the need for bipartisan support for tax reform. I endorse that sentiment wholeheartedly. Indeed, I commend the initiatives of the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in trying to get an all‐party committee together to address this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: But always lurking in any initiative of that kind are the opportunistic in the community, particularly on the other side of politics, but it is not necessarily confined to the other side either if a situation arises. However, in recent times the opportunistic approach has been confined exclusively to the other side. The Leader of the Opposition exemplified that during the Western Australian election campaign when he suggested, in a somewhat contorted fashion, that the Western Australian government was trying to implement some sort of GST. Yet again, the initiatives that need to be taken are constantly being mired by opportunistic politicians, particularly in the opposition.

The comments by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) about treating the symptoms rather than effecting a cure are very appropriate. The failure of fundamental reform has spawned the burgeoning act. The burgeoning act did not come about because of technical problems; it came about because of the underlying problems. In fact, the feet on the act have never really been properly addressed. It is the top-heavy nature of the act that is constantly being played with: it is rickety, it is rumbling and it is falling. Consequently, although this piece of legislation does go some way in the right direction to try and redress some of the problems, the underlying problems are the ones that ultimately must be addressed because they form the base upon which the act is erected.

The comments by the honourable member for Curtin are relevant to consider in relation to the need for professional assistance and I will do that shortly. Not only is there the need for professional accountancy assistance to about 70 per cent of the population but frequently taxpayers have to seek counsel's advice, in addition to their accountant's advice, because the accountants cannot provide the sort of advice necessary in some areas because of the complexity of the act. So that tacks on an additional cost.

The act, as has been said in the parliamentary secretary's second reading speech, is on the verge of collapsing under the weight of constant piecemeal amendment. It is true that the rewrite will make the act more user‐friendly, more understandable, hopefully shorter, clearer and less burdensome. The amendments include the rewrite of assessable and exempt income, deductions, trading stock, depreciation and gifts. Other rules included in the bill are entertainment expenses, primary production deductions, the recoupment of deductible expenses and the sale of leased cars.

There are about 30 minor policy changes. I need not go through those in whole other than to mention references made to replacing impractical rules with ones which facilitate taxpayer compliance, the simplification of rules, deleting of unnecessary rules, the removal of anomalies and clarifying of ambiguities.

The valuation methods for livestock will bring them in line with those for other kinds of trading stock. The change will have a revenue cost of up to $10 million in most years, and over $25 million in the occasional year where there is a large fall in stock prices. The proposed change in the use of trading stock taken for personal use will result in a gain to the revenue of about $30 million in 1998‐99 and $25 million in each subsequent year.

When I was studying taxation law in 1980 I can remember carrying around a CCH version of the act but I needed a reasonably strong wrist to do so, and the paper was not much thicker than rice paper at that time. Having observed a very strong table on which my accountant's Income Tax Assessment Act sits, and being reminded that he needs to take weight lifting lessons to carry it around, one can see and feel the enormity of the problem. I would hate to be a law student trying to wield that act between lecture theatres. I am told by a law student that in 1994 at the QUT the sections of the act that the students used—it was just too heavy to carry around—were about the same size of the act that I was using. That was not the complete act—the relevant sections that they were focusing on in their studies were a microcosm of the act itself. If only those sections were relevant to a law course, it makes me ask the question as to what use the other sections were to the public, but that is probably another manifestation of the great debate about the Income Tax Assessment Act.

It is interesting that the complexity of the act is causing more and more members of the public with taxation problems which, on the face of it, are relatively easy, to resort to the assistance of an accountant. Yet again you can see an anachronism in that sort of approach. People have to go to their accountant, they are in effect taxed again—they have to pay a fee to do that, so that is a form of tax out of their money—and then they get a deduction for doing so. So the revenue is depleted by that very complexity. Then you see the seeds of the problem.

Why are we not looking at a situation where the tax rate is dropped and there are no deductions? Would that not make it easier for everybody? We would probably drop half the act in the process and we would drop the necessity for all of this resort to advice and professional assistance. Maybe it is too simple, but it seems an obvious way of addressing the problem: take out the deductions and drop the tax. In the process, we would eliminate much heartache and anguish, the problems that go with that, the resentment that is felt by the community and the resorting to tax avoidance.

Sure, we are always going to have people who will try to avoid tax. But when you are looking at compliance costs, when you are looking at the keeping of records and so forth, you realise that all of that impacts on the Australian community. All of that hurts small business. All of that, in my view, is grinding our economy in a negative direction when we should be looking at turning it in a positive direction. We need to do that by the simplification of our tax laws. I say again that this is a step in the right direction but we certainly need to go much further.

I can recall the Tax Pack in the 1970s being a couple of pages. Look at it now. The Tax Pack is now an enormously complex document in itself, for some people. Admittedly it is a question of time for many people, but I would not fancy having to go through the Tax Pack to see precisely where I, as a taxpayer, am at with it. When one looks at the reasons for the complexity, one could spend a long time in this debate. Let us, however, look at the methodology in calculating depreciation, as just one example.

We are, in effect, so concerned with deductions that we are losing sight of what the act should be doing. It is there to make a simple, just, fair and equitable collection for income tax, and to provide a system that will assist the community in developing an economy that is generating income, employment, adventurism in decision making and an entrepreneurial spirit, not stifling it—not providing the plethora of rules and regulations and exceptions that stifle the movement in the economy that is needed to get the country going.

While again I emphasise my support for the proposal in principle, as one that will get us one step along the way, I shiver at the thought that it is one step in a 25-year process, as the member for Curtin mentioned. I do think that, with the enormous support in the community, right through from practising accountants to ACOSS itself, the messages are there. They can no longer be ignored; we can no longer fudge the issue. We have to tackle tax reform. We have to have bipartisan support. That is why the initiatives of the member for O'Connor are to be commended.

In essence, I support these measures. I hope that contributions that have been made to this debate will be looked at by those who should finally convince themselves that the messages are loud and clear and it is time to start a full and thorough reform of the system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tax Law Improvement Bill 1996 is one of the bread‐and‐butter, non‐controversial, machinery of government type bills, which this parliament is properly occupied with. I note that the first instalment, the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996, was passed through the Senate earlier in the week without opposition. I rise to support the bill. It is a commonsense reform. It reflects government's continuing obligation to make its legislation easier to understand, and easier to enforce and comply with.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the result, in part, of a response from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts led by my colleague, the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay). He has got that particular cast of mind which is rich in commonsense and practical insight. Pretty much whatever goes through his jurisdiction or purview, such as the recent amendments to the Auditor‐General Bill, reflects his capacity to recognise the anomaly and introduce commonsense where previously it had not existed.

The practical amendments to this bill, we should acknowledge, did not originate on this side of the House but originated under the previous government in its tax law improvement project in July 1994, with the goals of restructuring, re‐numbering and rewriting in plain language the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. As previous speakers have mentioned, it is a herculean task. Before we came to government, that particular act expanded in size in those 13 years from 1,328 pages, which we thought was already a pretty enormous act, to 3,792 pages. The word around town is that tax accountants now measure the act not by the page numbers but by the kilogram.

All of us today have got up and basically applauded the work of the bill in relation to assessable and exempt income, deductions, trading stock, depreciation and gifts. It is a helpful change. It communicates to small business and others that the government is working to reduce the compliance burden which they face.

The member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) raised the question of the number of amendments being proposed. The advice to me from the minister is that the large number of amendments proposed reflects the procedural requirement for each textual change to be dealt with separately. For example, the minister says that 23 amendments are needed to implement the single JCPA recommendation to omit the provisions allowing hire purchasers to depreciate plant.

The fact that 23 amendments are required to introduce one change reflects the deeper underlying issue that we have touched on this morning. The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) appealed for the terms of reference for this exercise to be extended into the realms of substantive policy. We accept that, to date, it has been essentially policy neutral and essentially revenue neutral. The member called upon the parliament and the government to expand the terms of reference and get into the real areas of difficulty in the tax act, which I think most of us would accept.

The great difficulty we have here is trying to make simple what is an inherently complex set of concepts. It is not surprising that the complexity of the underlying concepts revolves around the fact that our system of taxation is weighted so heavily in favour of the taxation of income. And income is a complex beast which is difficult to wrestle to the ground.

If we look, for example, at the recommendations of the Small Business Deregulation Task Force—they made 60 recommendations which are currently before the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and we expect a response from his office perhaps next week—the first 11 of those 60 were all tax related, in terms of how the government can reduce the impact of compliance on small business. That reflects the sense of urgency which the small business community, in particular, feels about these issues.

All the studies which have come back from small business say essentially the same thing: they do not resent having to pay tax but they resent the volume of regulation and legislation governing tax. They resent the complexity of the rule structure of tax and the frequency of changes to that rule structure. Those three messages consistently come back from the small business community. It is true that the complexity of the current regime impacts in a kind of discriminating way against small business, because these are the businesses which have not reached that critical mass where they can appoint someone as a full‐time compliance accountant. Larger businesses have that luxury. All the time spent in complying with the government's tax requirements is time that cannot be spent in marketing, selling product, building relationships, networking, R&D and all of those other productive areas of the economy.

We then get back to this question: should we then be making a much bolder, broader sweeping response to the problem? Let me put it on the record that I, like every other member who has stood, support this bill as far as it goes. I believe that it is an appropriate reference that has been undertaken by the tax law improvement project, but the bill inevitably raises this broader question of whether we ought to be approaching this in a more robust way.

There are moments in history when we sense that there was a critical decision that had to be taken by a nation and a community, and the decision taken will have a very long‐standing impact on the quality of life of a very large number of citizens. As I look back over this century, the Treaty of Versailles at the conclusion of the First World War is one about which I feel a great sense of sadness. I think that there was a situation where we had started the century off on a bad foot, if you like. We had had a civil war in Europe with millions killed, and then the statesmen, the elders of the nations, came together to hammer out the peace.

It was one of the few occasions in his life when I would agree with John Maynard Keynes. He was arguing for a much more gracious peace, if you like, and for a rebuilding of the German economy. But the leaders of the victorious states did not have that broad‐mindedness, that grace, that sense of statesmanship and they imposed a peace which most of us in retrospect would say was unjust.

Their lack of leadership at that moment, in my view, was one of the principal causes of the subsequent conflict in the Second World War. It sowed the seeds of resentment and the rest of this century, in effect, has been very much a result of that. Like the pebble in the pond, the waves have continued to flow out, largely due to the failure of leadership at that moment.

When I look at our own country's history over the past 50 years or so, I feel a sense of sorrow at the McEwanist high tariff policies in the 1950s and 1960s; at our failure to really latch onto and develop the technology when the CSIRO developed the first computer, and the sense that we drifted along as a primary producer without really value adding or really getting onto the front end of the technology wave. But I also feel a great sense of sadness for that moment in history when we had a key decision to make and we failed. I feel a sense of sadness about the 1993 election when John Hewson went to the Australian people with this incredibly ambitious but completely transparent package for national reform. It was a critical issue which everyone in the room would accept had to be one of our top national priorities.

If you pick the top three priorities, you would probably say something like: employment, health finance and tax reform. There may be a different order around the room, but tax reform has to be in the top two or three challenges we face as a nation. And there we had this moment in time—
A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 11.50 a.m. to 12.03 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the division, I was talking about those moments in history at which we define ourselves. To me, the 1993 election was one of those moments. So often people are cynical about politicians and believe that we are motivated by base motives, that we are unwilling to take the long‐term view, that we are not concerned about matters of principle. Here we had an Australian politician who said, `I am not cynical about the electorate. I am going to put a very high level of trust and faith in the electorate. I am going to go to the Australian people with this comprehensive package of reform. I am going to give them that package a year out from the election and I am going to let them go over it with a fine toothcomb. I am going to totally expose myself to public scrutiny. I am not going to pull something out of the bag when we get into government; I am going to have faith and confidence in the good judgment and good sense of the Australian people.'

SPEECH.PARA: I get a little bit irritated when I hear all the murmurings and rumblings about introducing a GST and how we have no stomach for it. When we went to the Australian people and offered them that deal, they did not have the stomach for it. I have a certain impatience with all of those accountants and experts and people who are now coming out and calling for this reform. They watched us get mowed down when we came out of the trenches carrying the GST, and they sat silently back in their comfortable bunkers and said, `We will derive the benefits of this reform once it goes through, but we will not share any of the risks.'

Even in the business community they were coming out and saying, `No, we do not want it. It is too hard and too complex. We do not want to have to collect it.' And then you had Keating—the absolute duplicity of the man—who, having fought tooth and nail in cabinet for this fundamental change and having lost, in a completely cynical electoral exercise turned that election into a referendum on the GST, knowing that in all of Australia's history since Federation we had never passed a referendum except with bipartisan support. Clearly, we are in the same position today. So there was that moment in time when we had this great opportunity as a culture for decision, and we failed.

Now we are locked in; we are all standing up and giving obeisance to this good piece of essentially technical housekeeping legislation when, in our heart of hearts, we all know there is a job to be done but we do not have the national will to do it. So I challenge groups like the Taxpayers Association of Australia, the accountants and the whole industry out there who are calling for reform. I say, `Why don't you go out and recruit the Australian people to that concept and get their commitment and come back to the parliament?'

National leadership in a parliament such as this is not just about initiating things and leading the people; it is also about responding to them and reflecting their views. When we have gone to the Australian people, only four years ago, with this exact proposal and been very clearly rejected, some could equally argue it would be presumptuous of any prime minister to relaunch that phoenix out of the ashes. I want to see the signing on the dotted line of those companies, corporations and small businesses who are all wandering around murmuring and saying, `Why don't we do something about it?' We went to the Australian people and they knocked us back because they did not have the stomach for it.

It is like the second airport: everyone is in favour of the second airport until they actually see that the flight path goes over their house; then, of course, they are implacably opposed to it. We have these moments of decision when reform is painful. I am not necessarily saying a consumption tax is the panacea. But we have to move away from this incredible reliance on income as the basis of Commonwealth revenue.

A GST is not the be‐all and end‐all. But it is a movement away from this preoccupation with income that actually stimulates savings and investment, encourages compliance because it is simple, is equitable because everybody pays it, and does not encourage a whole industry of tax evasion. That is what we need as a nation. It has got to be one of our top priorities. I am appealing to the business community and the Australian people to, if they want it, let us see the colour of the money; let us see them come out en masse.

Ross Perot, before he ran for the presidency of the United States, said to his constituency, `I'm not going to run until you can get 500,000 signatures saying you want me to run.' In a sense, it was smart politics—half the battle was won before he began. So I am saying to the Australian people: if you want a consumption tax, if you want fundamental reform of tax, I urge you to lobby the Australian Labor Party to a point where we know we can move forward with a bipartisan commitment, in the same way that we have had for this bill, for which I applaud the opposition. It was originally their bill.

If we are talking about real national leadership in this place, nothing would restore the integrity and stature of this parliament in the eyes of the Australian people more than a bipartisan commitment to fundamental tax reform. So I call on the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and the Australian people to rally together and demand it of us. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up a lot of the time of the Main Committee on the Tax Law Improvement Bill 1996, but it is important to make a few comments. I certainly concur with a lot of what the previous speaker, the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron), has said. This bill had its genesis way back in 1992‐93 when the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of the 36th Parliament and, subsequently, the 37th Parliament put together a report on the inquiry that it held. It was report No. 326, called An assessment of tax . A lot of people will recall some of the public hearings and the evidence that was received by the JCPA in putting that report together.

SPEECH.PARA: I was fortunate enough to have been on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts at the tail end of that inquiry, in the 37th Parliament, and I also participated in the drafting of the recommendations. Among the recommendations with regard to the legislative framework that came out of that report No. 326, recommendation 22 said:
The committee recommends the government establish a broadly based task force to redraft the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
Recommendation 23 was:

That the committee recommends that the government commits sufficient resources to the task force as will allow it to complete a priority simplification redraft within two years and the full simplification of the act within five years.

It should be noted that there was also a minority report, as part of report 326, and what I feel was a fairly important recommendation came out of the minority report with regard to rulings. That minority report, in recommendation 3, said:
That the relevant Commonwealth Tax Acts be amended to provide that general—
that is public rulings—
be issued as regulations under the taxation laws and subject to tabling and disallowance in the parliament.

As everybody would know, that recommendation in the minority report was not picked up, but it certainly is an area that way back then was of concern and, from my understanding of the private sector, at this stage is still of major concern. The existence of the ruling system and how it is applied and enforced is one of the areas of concern to the private sector and private practitioners. Obviously, the other area relates to the perception, following report 326, that the rewrite of the tax act would be addressing policy issues as well as the simplification of what is a very, very complicated bill. To a large extent that has not happened.

The TLIP process started under the former government in the 37th Parliament and it has continued under the current government in the 38th Parliament. It was interesting to note the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles), in which he said:

The first instalment of the new law, the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996, was passed by the House with bipartisan support and is presently waiting consideration by the Senate. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts reviewed that bill in detail, concluding that the bill was a significant improvement over the current law being widely regarded as far easier to read and understand.

That is quite correct, but it certainly did not address any issues of policy. I know that this is one issue that has been raised in the debate so far on this bill. In the second reading speech, the parliamentary secretary went on to say:
The rewritten rules include 30 minor policy changes which will make the law simpler, clearer and less burdensome for taxpayers. They will do this by:
. replacing impractical rules with ones which facilitate taxpayer compliance:
. simplifying rules which are unnecessarily complex;
. deleting unnecessary rules;
. removing anomalies; and
. clarifying ambiguities.

I believe the crux of what the previous speaker was talking about was addressing policy issues in taxation, trying to drag the Income Tax Assessment Act at least into the 1990s and push it forward so that it is a forward looking piece of legislation to take into the next century. Unfortunately, at this stage in this process, that is not entirely happening. In fact, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, in its report 348 on this bill, stated in recommendation 2:

Government should expand the mandate of the Tax Law Improvement Project to allow it to consider a wider range of tax policy simplification issues than the mandate currently allows. Such a mandate should be applied to TLIP for all future tranches of rewritten legislation.

And that is the most recent report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the whole TLIP process that has been taking place over the last couple of years. I support the process. I support the bill that is before the House. I believe that we should be going a little further, flexing the margins out a little further and having a look at addressing some of those policy areas.

BREAK.PARA: As an aside to that, quite apart from this process I note that the Australian Tax Office is having a look at some policy changes and flexing the margins in another area, which is also partly covered by this bill. In division 70, I think it is, the bill deals with trading stock and there are a few references in the EM and descriptions of natural increase of livestock as trading stock and how the Australian Tax Office will deal with those.

Just recently I had the opportunity of spending the day with a number of oyster farmers on the Hawkesbury River, and some of them were from Wallis Lake. The Wallis Lake farmers currently have an additional disadvantage which can be added to those that they are already burdened with emanating from the state government of New South Wales. Anyhow, I spent the day on the Hawkesbury River with a group of oyster farmers from there and from Wallis Lake and also with two officers from the Australian Taxation Office.

The Australian Taxation Office at the moment has a discussion paper out on how it can draw into the tax system a declaration of trading stock by oyster farmers. That is going to be an extremely difficult thing. I am just using this is an example. I am not criticising the ATO, but I am saying that the ATO is able to push things out at the margins in this regard yet the mandate given in the rewriting and the simplification of the tax act in the TLIP process has been fairly clearly defined.

Going back to the discussion paper and the assessment of how the ATO wants to deal with oyster farmers, it is a very difficult industry to operate in. It is very sensitive to climate changes—more so than a lot of other primary production—and it is going to be very difficult for the ATO to identify a point at which oysters actually become trading stock. The oysters are caught in the wild. It is the same as asking a deep-sea professional fisherman, `How are you going to assess your trading stock?'

I spent the day with the oyster farmers. We looked at the different processes of oyster farming from actually catching spats that are free and wild in the rivers, to putting them onto sticks, to growing them out, and how they take them from there to fattening paddocks.

The most salient point that was made by the oyster farmers—and I take this opportunity to put it on the record—was that only last year they lost millions of dollars worth of stock in a matter of one hour in one day. They had a lot of their oysters on beds in what they call fattening paddocks. It was extremely hot weather in the middle of summer. There was a low tide at the wrong time of the day and those oysters were exposed to extreme heat for an hour too long. As a result, the industry lost millions of dollars worth of oysters.

They are exposed to those sorts of things and now they are being faced with the dilemma of how they are going to deal with what may be imposed as far as the Australian Taxation Office is concerned in a declaration of open trading stock. At what point in the process of catching a wild animal on stakes—and the vagaries of that—going through to the process to fattening and marketing an oyster should they be declaring the level and value of their trading stock?

The point is that in this bill it is fairly clear and it makes it easy to enunciate the natural increase of livestock as trading stock, their value and how to go about it. It is all prescribed in here, but it is going to be a far more difficult exercise with the different operators in the oyster industry in Australia. I just flag to the officers from the ATO who are here today that it is an issue that those of us who represent areas with a major oyster farming industry are going to take a great deal of interest in. It is of concern to us.

To their credit, the oyster farmers accepted the offer from the ATO to look at how they operate their businesses and to discuss some of the issues that revolve around the businesses. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would know about that because you also have an oyster industry of sorts in Tasmania. It is not Sydney rock oysters but it is an oyster industry of sorts.

It is an important element and it has wider ramifications in so far as how people who are heading off into different ventures in agriculture are treated in the system. Every reasonable, thinking person in Australia expects that if you make a profit, you pay tax. That is our contribution to running this country. It is another question as to whether you agree how different governments from time to time spend that money, but any reasonable person will expect to pay tax.

I concur with the previous speaker with regard to the development of a tax minimisation industry in Australia. However, the reason it exists is because the tax law is so complicated. The average layman just cannot understand the majority of the tax act. That is why the industry has grown to the extent that it has.

There should be no reason why it should not be a very simple process. I also believe that, as we move towards the turn of the century, there is going to be an increasing demand from different sections of the community—not just from industry, the taxation industry, big business and small business, but from individuals, the PAYE taxpayers—for an overhaul of the tax system in this country. Sadly, it is going to get to the stage where that becomes a very loud cry before it is addressed.

I say that because, sadly, on a couple of occasions—one very public and one probably internal in government in this country—there was an opportunity presented in 1993 and previous to that in the mid‐1980s, to have a full and reasonable review of the tax system but on both occasions that was rejected because of a perception of it being too difficult. At some stage in the future, the general taxpaying public will demand that that take place. As I say, sadly we will have to wait till then before there will be a response.

I support the bill. I would like to see greater focus given to the possibility of policy changes. In a legislative manner, we seem to be bound to just rewriting and simplifying the tax act through what we are doing in TLIP. But the ATO still has the capability to look at those other areas of tax collection, as I highlighted with regard to the oyster industry. It is a dynamic system that we run. Let us be open-minded and look at the possibilities of looking at that issue in future projects. As has been set out in a recommendation in report 348 from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, let us have a look at addressing some policy issues in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the minister, I say thank you to all the speakers who participated in this debate. It is always interesting to hear people representing their electorates very well. Indeed, as my colleague spoke about the oyster industry, he highlighted some of the difficulties of having a very fair tax system in this nation. I could not help but remember that I like oysters; let us not kill off an oyster industry in Australia. So I thank those from both sides of the House who have contributed to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The government believes that the Tax Law Improvement Bill 1996 will be of significant benefit to the entire Australian community. The bill is the second instalment of legislation to replace progressively the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1936. It comes on the heels of the first stage of the new tax act that was endorsed by the Senate on Monday. That event is an important milestone because it means that the benefits of the tax law improvement project will begin to flow to the Australian community for the 1997‐98 income year. It is a major step forward in the progress of giving the taxation laws of this country back to the community in understandable language.
I would particularly like to acknowledge the extremely valuable work of the JCPA in its watching brief on the project, and especially of its chairman, the member for Fairfax, Mr Somlyay.

The 1936 act was in desperate need of a comprehensive overhaul. It is long and almost impossible to understand for anyone but tax specialists—sometimes I doubt if they were really clear on what it might have meant. Even then, it takes years of specialisation before a professional can offer confident advice. This bill will be of major benefit to the community and, together with the earlier bill, it makes an enormous improvement on existing law. The tax law improvement project has restructured, renumbered and rewritten the law so that it is easily understandable and can be followed completely.

Because the law can be more easily understood, compliance with it will improve and, very importantly, business costs of complying with it will also reduce. People will be able, for the first time in decades, to have a sense of confidence that they understand their rights and obligations and what actions they are required to take. There have been suggestions about the lack of readiness among the professions and the community for the 1 July 1997 start‐up date for the bill. The government believes that the community and the professions are now, or are at least becoming, well prepared for the start‐up date of 1 July this year.

I am aware that the commercial publishers are ready to go with material, including detailed commentaries on electronic databases, which will support the tax profession and the community. I am also aware that the rewritten law in this, and the earlier bills, is already being taught in many of the tax courses in our universities and other tertiary institutions. So the process is certainly well on the way: that extension of knowledge and understanding of this bill. Text books have been, or are being, written or updated to take account of those changes. The Australian Taxation Office is developing training material to support the implementation of the law. This material will be made publicly available in good time.

The extensive public consultation has meant that this bill has been exhaustively examined in order to identify any possible detriment to taxpayers. It has stood up to this extensive scrutiny very well. This is testimony to the high professional standards maintained by the tax law improvement personnel. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

The amendments that have been circulated on behalf of the government fall into three categories. The first block of amendments removes from the bill rules which for the first time would have provided an express treatment for the transfer of assets into, or from, trading stock.

The government has decided to postpone this change because there is no consensus on the technical expression needed to implement the proposal. The government will continue to consult towards an agreed formulation with a view to early restoration of provisions to deal with the issue.

The second group of amendments adopts a recommendation of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts, in its advisory report No. 348, by removing references to hire purchasers of plant as being entitled to deduct depreciation. The third group will make miscellaneous amendments of a minor technical kind.

The government is accepting all of the changes to the bill proposed by the joint committee except, for the time being, the recommendations about assets converted to or from trading stock. The government has also made changes to the explanatory memorandum along the lines recommended by the joint committee. The government is fully aware of concerns about private sector involvement and we will be taking action on this issue very shortly. The government is giving sympathetic consideration to other recommendations in report No. 348 that go to wider policy matters, and responses on these matters will be provided later.

Amendments 23, 39, 53, 55, 57 to 59, 61 and 63 to 69 relate to the changes in use of trading stock. The amendments will remove the proposed rules about converting trading stock into private or capital assets and converting private or capital assets into trading stock. The bill had sought to include express rules to deal with these events; however, there has been ongoing debate about the drafting of these rules. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts made recommendations on those issues, but some business groups still have concerns. Accordingly, the government has decided not to proceed at this time with these measures in the bill but rather to further pursue broad agreement with professional bodies.

Amendments 18 to 20, 33, 35, 36, 40 to 45, 47 to 50, 70 and 76 to 82 relate to depreciation by hire purchasers. These amendments will remove references to hire purchase in the depreciation provisions. The bill had sought to provide legislative backing for the longstanding practice of allowing persons who hold property under a hire purchase agreement to depreciate it. However, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts thought it inappropriate for the bill to deal with hire purchase in isolation from other kinds of broadly similar finance arrangements. The government accepts that recommendation. Hirers under hire purchase agreements will continue to attract depreciation deductions under the long‐established administrative arrangements.

Amendments 1 to 17, 21, 22, 24 to 32, 34, 37, 38, 46, 51, 52, 54, 56, 60, 62, 71 to 75 and 83 relate to miscellaneous changes. This third group of amendments will make a number of minor technical changes to the bill. These changes do not reflect any change in policy and are mainly to make drafting improvements and correct omissions, to better ensure that the new law accurately reflects the existing law. Each of the amendments is explained in more detail in the supplementary explanatory memorandum which I now present.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House with amendments.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Mr Prosser:
