SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 amends the Excise Tariff Act to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages containing distilled alcohol, including spirits, regardless of their alcohol content. It is a bill which the opposition supports. It closes a loophole that was created by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal ruling that, for example, Carlton United's Sub Zero alcoholic soda, which has an alcohol content of about 5½ per cent, could not be described as `spirituous' and therefore was not excisable as a spirituous beverage. This is bad news for drinkers of Sub Zero, but the closure is about protecting the revenue base and applying some consistency to the description of alcoholic beverages.

SPEECH.PARA: It also applies to a range of other packaged mixed drinks, so it is not just the trendies with the Sub Zero who will be affected, but people who are into mixed spirit drinks, such as the United Distiller brands of rum and cola, gin and tonics and all those sorts of things. I think all of those people who have tried these recognise they contain spirits, especially if they have a lot of them. If sold separately, those spirits would be excisable, but the AAT ruled that the mix, to use their terminology, contained less alcohol than the community definition of spirit. At least 37 per cent alcohol by volume is the community definition. It was therefore not subject to excise.

The mechanism which has been used to close the loophole is to redefine the rate of duty in the schedule of the act from an amount per litre of alcohol to an amount per litre of distilled alcohol. There are further applications for similar rulings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and the Commonwealth has lodged an appeal in the Federal Court against the CUB Sub Zero ruling. None of these is yet concluded.

The legislation acts retrospectively from 3 February to effectively quash all claims currently before either the AAT or the Federal Court. All disputed excise has been paid into a deposit account of the Commonwealth so there is no repayment or back payment of disputed excise duty to the Commonwealth.

The financial impact of this bill is that it reduces revenue by $290,000 for an, at this stage, still unexplained change to the excise on brandy based beverages, presumably to bring them into line with other spirituous beverages.

Further clarification is being sought from the minister but a response has not been received. I would simply ask in this debate that we get that clarification. It is an important one, because it involves reduction in revenue. But other than that, the bill avoids a contingent liability of $12.6 million from the AAT and the Federal Court actions.
The opposition supports the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join this debate on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No.1) 1997 and I note that the shadow minister, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) has indicated that the opposition will be supporting the amendments to the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the bill is to amend the schedule to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages containing distilled alcohol, including spirits, regardless of their alcoholic content. The important thing here is that this is a bit of housekeeping legislation and the intention is quite simply to close off a loophole.

The financial impact of this bill is virtually zero; there is no financial impact. The amendments proposed in the act only clarify the law as outlined and involve no change to the excise treatment of beverages containing distilled alcohol. As I said earlier, it will have no financial impact. However, conversely it could mean that, unless there is retrospective amendment to the act, the government will have a contingent liability of some $12.6 million. When I first saw the bill, there was a degree of retrospectivity about it. As someone who strongly voices concerns when the word `retrospectivity' comes into play, I must say that was a warning signal for me to have a look in more detail as to what it really means with respect to retrospectivity.

I believe in this instance that the amendments are justifiable on the grounds that they are backdated to 3 February 1996 because this will remove the technical loophole in the tariff act which was uncovered by the decision of the court to make the request by the company seeking the removal of the tariff acceptable. There is no reason to doubt that the court has acted in the best interests of the parliament in bringing down the decision that it has. This will not require the retrospective recovery of any excise duty from the manufacturers of the alcoholic beverages as the excise duty has continued to be paid by the manufacturers under deposit. This will protect the government under any claims for recovery of this duty. As I said earlier on, the bill is more in the nature of a housekeeping bill, and I strongly support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr PROSSER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the members who have spoken to this bill. As my colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) mentioned, the amendments that we are proposing here have been made necessary because of a challenge brought on by Carlton and United Breweries with regard to the product known as Sub Zero. But I would like to reiterate for the record—I did note that my colleague, the honourable member for Lowe, mentioned this—that the purpose of this bill is to amend the Customs Tariff Act 1921 to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages which contain distilled alcohol, including spirits, regardless of their alcohol content. It was the alcohol content that was the problem with regard to the Sub Zero case. This is really to make what we are aiming to do in legislation crystal clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Under item 2 of the schedule of the Tariff Act, spirituous beverages are subject to duties of excise which are calculated at a dollar amount per litre of alcohol in each of the beverages. In November 1994, Carlton and United Breweries, CUB, commenced the manufacture of a product known as Sub Zero alcoholic soda which had an alcoholic content of approximately 5.5 per cent. The Australian Customs Service considered SubZ ero an excisable product. Carlton and United Breweries appealed against the decision of the Australian Customs Service to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and the AAT determined that the product Sub Zero, with such a low alcoholic content by volume, could not be described as spirituous and was therefore not excisable. The Australian Customs Service is appealing against that decision in the Federal Court.

Since the AAT decision, Carlton and United Breweries has ceased the manufacture of Sub Zero using alcohol derived by distillation. However, there are several other manufacturers of beverages of low alcohol content, and the Customs Service has continued to impose excise duty on these beverages. In order to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages containing distilled alcohol, I have brought this bill forward to amend the act. The combination of these amendments will remove any connotation as to the strength that an alcoholic beverage must be before it is excisable.

It is proposed that the amendments will take effect on and from 3 February 1996. The effect of the retrospective commencement date of the amendments will be to extinguish all rights of appeal to the AAT in relation to the excisability of low alcohol beverages and all rights to refunds of excise duty in respect of such beverages. The commencement date of the amendments on 3 February 1996 would not require the retrospective recovery of any excise duty from the manufacturers of the alcoholic beverages. The excise duty has continued to be paid by the manufacturers under deposit, and the 3 February 1996 commencement date will protect the government against all claims for recovery of this duty.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 November 1996, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to speak only briefly in relation to this bill. The International Transfer of Prisoners Bill 1996 provides mechanisms through which Australians imprisoned abroad may be returned to Australia to serve out their sentences. The bill also provides for foreign nationals imprisoned in Australia to be returned to their home countries, also to complete their sentences.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill makes this provision both in relation to prisoners convicted of war crimes and also prisoners convicted of general offences. In the case of prisoners convicted of war crimes, the bill complements Australia's commitment to prosecuting international war criminals. Australia has vigorously assisted the international efforts in this regard through our participation pursuant to the International War Crimes Tribunal Act 1995 in the tribunals established to deal with war crimes committed in the former Yugoslavia and in Rwanda. That legislation was moved by the former Labor government and received bipartisan support.

Some concerns were expressed at the hearings of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into this bill. The concerns were that the bill might undermine the effort to fight serious crime, particularly drug related crime. These arguments seem to rest on the erroneous assumptions that the transfer of these prisoners will result in prisoners receiving less severe sentences. This is clearly not the effect of the bill. Whilst it is true that in being closer to home, family and friends prisoners are more likely to be held in more culturally sensitive conditions, these conditions are hardly likely to promote criminal activity. It would be a rather strange individual who decided that they were prepared to commit a serious criminal offence where previously they were not, simply because they knew that pursuant to this bill they might ultimately be returned home. Rather, this bill recognises that despite the serious wrongdoing these prisoners have committed, wrongdoings that are deserving of the gravest censure and punishment, those prisoners have rights to humanitarian treatment.

It also recognises that the best way to rehabilitate these prisoners is to return them to culturally appropriate and supportive environments, and as far as the general community is concerned surely this is one of the prime considerations we should be concerned about to minimise the prospect that criminals will offend again and that other innocent people will suffer from their actions. Punishment is an important part of the criminal process; however, punishment that increases the prospect of recidivism is not in the interests of society nor the prisoner concerned.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs provided an advisory report to the parliament on this bill and I think it is worthwhile reading onto the record page 5 of that report. I think that summarises the consideration in favour of international transfer of prisoners and really encapsulates my view of the situation. It says at paragraph 1.15:

The principal argument in favour of the international transfer of prisoners is humanitarian. The deprivation of liberty can be more harsh for prisoners imprisoned in foreign countries because of absence of contact with, and support from, relatives and friends, language barriers, differences in diet and health care, alienation from local culture, intolerance of religious practices, ineffective vocational training and general prejudice against foreigners. A prisoner can be adversely affected both psychologically and physically, and his or her rehabilitation might be impaired.

The international transfer of prisoners is said to enhance the prospects of rehabilitation of prisoners and their re‐integration into the community, as rehabilitation is thought to depend on the prisoner having the benefit of family or community support. This support is more likely where prisoners are in the same country as their families.
Those paragraphs out of the report encapsulate my view of the matter perfectly, and that is one of the reasons why we on this side of the House support this bill.

The bill also facilitates greater cooperation between Australia and foreign law enforcement and custodial agencies. This increased confidence and support of international law enforcement and custodial agencies will ultimately increase our combined ability to tackle the ever growing rate of international crime. This will help ensure that more criminals are brought to justice and help make the world, including Australia, a safer place.

The aspects of this bill relating to the transfer of prisoners convicted of non‐war crimes related offences will ultimately rely for their success on the cooperation of the states and territories. The state and territory attorneys‐general have given in principle agreement to the operation of the legislation. I urge all attorneys concerned to conclude the final agreements with the necessary legislative support as soon as possible.

Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, I note that the government's proposed amendment to the bill clarifies the wording of clause 24 in accordance with recommendation seven of the unanimous advisory report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The Australian Labor Party welcomes this amendment, just as we welcome this bill. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Bailey) adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 5 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the 5th session of the World Heritage Committee, held in the Sydney Opera House in 1981, informed that the Australian Government had withdrawn the nomination of the Sydney Opera House and its setting but hoped to submit a revised nomination in due course.

(2) Did the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and the NSW Department of Urban Affairs and Planning jointly prepare a nomination of the Sydney Opera House and its harbour setting for inscription on the World Heritage List by the Government of Australia in 1996.

(3) If so, (a) did the property nominated include the Sydney Opera House, the island of Fort Denison, the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the waterways of Sydney Harbour to the mean high water mark from Robinson's Point and Mrs Macquarie's Point in the east to Blues Point and Dawes Point in the west and (b) did the nomination state that the property illustrates the themes of twentieth century architecture and the cultural heritage of Australia, both of which are under-represented on the World Heritage List and that the inclusion of the property would assist in creating a more universally representative list.
(4) Did the Australian Government lodge the nomination with the World Heritage Committee on 1 July 1996 when it lodged the nomination of Australia's Sub-Antarctic Islands; if not, why not.
(5) Are preparations being made to lodge the nomination by 1 July 1997 in time for the World Heritage Bureau and the World Heritage Committee to consider it in 1998; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes

(2) The Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and the NSW Department of Urban Affairs and Planning cooperated, over the period of 1995 and 1996, in an assessment of the values of the Sydney Opera House in its Harbour Setting and the preparation of a World Heritage nomination. Preparation of the draft nomination was the responsibility of the then New South Wales Department of Urban Affairs and Planning. The Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories was represented on a steering committee of officials which oversaw the work. The Commonwealth Government has not lodged that nomination with the World Heritage Committee.
(3)(a) Yes
(3)(b) Yes

(4) No. The Commonwealth Government did not receive the nomination from the New South Wales Government until 26 July 1996, which was too late to allow submission to the World Heritage Committee for consideration that year.

(5) The Commonwealth Government has decided not to forward the nomination to the World Heritage Committee at this time. The Prime Minister wrote, in a letter of 19 August 1996 to the New South Wales Premier, that he would wish to ensure complete accord between Governments over funding and management arrangements, if a nomination is to proceed.

Uncertainties are raised by the New South Wales nomination of the building in its harbour setting, particularly the difficulty of establishing satisfactory management arrangements in a dynamic urban setting which includes a working harbour. Accordingly, the Commonwealth has decided that its limited resources for World Heritage matters are best devoted to the nominations we have in progress (notably the Subantarctic Islands), the assessments we have under way and the proper management of the eleven properties already on the World Heritage List.
